IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Stable housing is fundamental to mental and physical health, and eviction represents a major source of housing instability. The national eviction moratorium imposed during the pandemic recently ended, and housing experts are expecting a surge of evictions in the coming years. This surge could substantially imperil progress toward VA’s objective to eliminate Veteran homelessness. The proposed study fills major gaps in our understanding of how evictions affect homelessness and health for Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans living with spinal cord injury (SCI) experience devastating and costly pressure injuries (PrI) leading to preventable long hospitalizations and surgery. PrIs are local areas of damage to the skin and underlying soft tissue caused by pressure and shear commonly located over bony prominences. Veteran Health Administration (VA) SCI clinics provide an annual preventive care visit for Veterans living with SCI, but past research has shown that risks arise throughout the year requiring on-going preventive care. In collaboration with the VA SCI National Program Office and VA Office of Connected Care, this proposed implementation study will assess the efficacy and implementation of the new VA research- funded decision support tool, called the Community Acquired Pressure Injury Prevention Field Implementation Tool (CAPP-FIT) to prevent community-acquired PrIs at seven SCI outpatient clinics across the country to support and guide national implementation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The project will investigate the efficacy of a Veteran-peer-navigator-led decision coaching (PDC) program to promote Shared Decision Making (SDM) for prostate cancer screening among Veterans at the Veterans Health Administration (VA). Prostate cancer is commonly screen detected using PSA, a non-specific test which has led to modest population-level survival benefits at the cost of over-detection of low-risk disease. This trade off in outcomes is ideally addressed using SDM which can be challenging to implement in time constrained primary care office visits. We propose the evaluation of a PDC intervention to promote SDM for PSA screening to improve both access and quality of care for Veterans. Our results will enhance understanding of the efficacy, cost-effectiveness, and sustainability of PDC interventions for SDM promotion across communication formats in the VA. Lessons learned through this proposal will not only improve quality of care for PSA screening but also will suggest a paradigm for dissemination of SDM across preventive services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: OVERALL Persistent symptoms after treatment for Lyme disease occurs in a substantial proportion of people who get infected by the bacteria that causes this widespread tick-borne disease. The cause of the persistent symptoms is controversial but we believe that there are multiple factors that contribute to its development including prior or concurrent exposures to other organisms, immune abnormalities and specific traits of the infecting bacteria. This study will provide a broad investigation into multiple possible contributing factors in patients who are enrolled before it is known whether they will resolve their symptoms or have persistent symptoms in order to better understand how these symptoms develop, how to predict them and how to prevent or treat them.

PHR: NARRATIVE: ADMINISTRATIVE CORE Crucial to any complex clinical study is coordination of all of the different parts of the team that need to function together to make the project a success. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: CLINICAL COORDINATION CORE Persistent symptoms following antibiotic treatment for early Lyme disease cause debilitating illness in some patients. The CCC is designed to support a series of research projects targeted to determine the causes of persistent symptoms in Lyme disease. It will accomplish this goal by enrolling the largest number of persons with early Lyme disease ever studied in North America and by ensuring that the clinical information and research samples needed to answer the questions about the causes of persistent symptoms are available to be analyzed by leading scientists using state of the art technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Diagnostic Core Crucial to any groundbreaking study of PTLDS will be the availability of properly collected and stored human samples obtained from well-characterized patients with Lyme disease and control subjects. The Diagnostics Core will assist in comprehensive subject characterization by performing a predefined battery of laboratory diagnostic tests on each enrolled subject, the results of which will be correlated with clinical findings. We will also develop and maintain a biorepository of archived human samples from each well-characterized subject, for use by the project investigators to support research aims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Project 1, The Epidemiology of Post-Treatment Lyme Disease Syndrome The proposed project ultimately seeks to provide a biological basis for preventing and treating Post Treatment Lyme Disease Syndrome (PTLDS) by analyzing risk factors, particularly coinfections, within residents of deer tick-exposed communities. In addition, we shall place its health burden into context by comparison with that of well studied similar conditions, providing a metric for evaluating intervention methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Project 2, Immunology of Post-treatment Lyme Disease Syndrome The human immune response plays an important role in protecting us from disease but can also cause disease when not responding properly. In this Project, we will use new technologies to identify how immune responses may differ between people who recover from Lyme disease versus those who have persistent symptoms. Understanding the differences may lead us to new diagnostics and strategies for treating people with persistent symptoms after treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will help explain why even the strongest environmental and genetic risk factors have variable effects across individuals, and enable prediction of these differences in response. A specialized mouse model will be used to determine if preexisting epigenetic risk leaves a detectable signature in tumors. Defining such a signature will guide diagnosis and personalized treatment for future cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the results from this project will improve risk stratification of thyroid nodules using genetic data, reduce the number of invasive thyroid fine needle aspiration biopsies, and decrease the burden of a thyroid cancer diagnosis on patients and the healthcare system in the United States. PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT – PROJECT NARRATIVE The Rare and Atypical Diabetes Network (RADIANT) enrolls and deeply characterizes individuals with rare and atypical forms of diabetes. Whole-genome sequencing could help identify new genetic variants and metabolomics and transcriptomics analysis novel pathogenic mechanisms and biomarkers for atypical forms of the disease. Its ultimate goal is to enable a more precise, etiologically based clinical classification of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: A variety of mental health conditions can be considered disorders of generalization, e.g., overgeneralization in anxiety and compulsion, and undergeneralization in schizophrenia. Latent cause inference is a fundamental cognitive process that lies at the heart of how we set generalization boundaries in perception, learning and decision making. We propose a comprehensive characterization of individual differences in latent cause inference and their relationship to self-reported symptom dimensions and clinical categories, as well as their underlying neural circuitry, proposing latent cause inference as a new RDoC dimension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Increasing the number of researchers from scientifically-underrepresented groups will promote biomedical advancement in the United States. The proposed ESTEEMED Research Program will identify high-achieving underrepresented freshmen and support them as they develop as biomedical scientists. The students will engage in meaningful year-round biomedical research projects; receive mentoring, academic assistance, and personal and professional development trainings; and develop the credentials needed to enter UTSA’s MARC Honors Research Training Program as juniors, and later complete biomedical doctoral degrees and attain leadership positions in the scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: LSU ESTEEMED Scholars Project Narrative  The LSU ESTEEMED Scholars program will address the critical need for individuals from underrepresented groups in biomedical sciences and bioengineering. Given that we lose students out of biomedical/bioengineering education pathways early in their undergraduate studies, we must target interventions at this level to build a strong, multicultural, and diverse biomedical and scientific research workforce. To that end, the LSU ESTEEMED Scholars program targets high-potential students at the first-year (freshman) and second-year (sophomore) levels of undergraduate study, integrates them early into a biomedical research training ecosystem that cultivates their talents through holistic, student-centered approaches and prepares them for PhDs and MD/PhDs in biomedical science and bioengineering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Neuropsychiatric illnesses pose a significant societal challenge. Discovering more effective treatments is difficult due to our limited understanding of the brain. DART (Drug Acutely Restricted by Tethering) has shown potential in addressing this issue by enabling targeted drug delivery to specific brain cells in behaving animals. The DART.2 evolution has further bolstered this potential, offering an unprecedented thousandfold cellular specificity (Shields, et. al., 2022). With the development of DART.3, we aim to make another leap forward, potentially transforming how we approach treatments for these illnesses. This technology focuses on a noninvasive, programmable approach that could revolutionize our strategies for dealing with neuropsychiatric diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE - OVERALL This consortium project is based on the hypothesis that spatiotemporally-integrated neuronal small GTPase signaling at multiple organizational levels drives the formation and function of synaptic circuits that underlie cognition and behavior. We plan to map the spatiotemporal contributions of neuronal GTPase upstream regulators to cortical development, function, and behavior through a highly integrated and collaborative center framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), a hematological malignancy, remains stubbornly difficult to treat in both children and adults, with fewer than 30% of patients surviving five years after diagnosis. This project tests a novel treatment target (mitochondrial recycling—aka mitophagy) and novel small molecules identified using cheminformatics, in AML cell lines and primary cells. This project will facilitate the identification and characterization of promising leads for the development of future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Several studies show that α-crystallin binding to the lens membrane increases with age and cataract; however, the mechanism that initiates α-crystallin binding to the lens membrane is unknown. We hypothesize that deamidation and mutation of α-crystallin and oxidation of lipids and cholesterol promote α- crystallin binding to the membrane, and cholesterol and cholesterol bilayer domains inhibit such binding and protect against cataract formation and progression. These studies will determine the mechanism of α-crystallin binding to the lens membranes that will enable alternative strategies for preventing, curing, and slowing cataract progression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing prevalence and disparities in obesity, heart disease, diabetes, and obesity-related diseases pose a threat to current and future generations’ health. Excessive weight gain during infancy is an important factor in the development of obesity and obesity-related diseases, yet we do not have adequate strategies to help promote healthier weight gain among bottle-fed infants. Our study tests new interventions related to infant bottles that are designed to help caregivers feed more responsively and help reduce excessive weight gain during early infancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma (EHE), a rare cancer with no effective treatment, is caused by a protein produced by the fusion of two genes, TAZ (WWTR1) and CAMTA1 that we call TC (abbreviation for TAZ- CAMTA1). Using EHE cancer cells, we screened FDA-approved drugs and identified dinaciclib as a potent TC inhibitor. We propose studies to test the efficacy of dinaciclib in mouse models of EHE and to elucidate its mechanism of action, with the goal of repurposing dinaciclib for the first effective EHE treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL –NARRATIVE Organ transplantation has become a gold standard therapy for older patients with end-stage organ diseases. The goal of this proposal is to delineate mechanisms controlling transplant immunity in aging. A better understanding of the mechanisms by which aging affects transplant immunity is crucial for the development of aged specific immune therapies in transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: CORE C- Narrative  Core C will be responsible for performing expert microsurgical procedures assuring reproducibility as a pre-requisite of reliable experimental readouts. Core C will coordinate all microsurgical procedures among Projects 1, 2 and 3 to maximize the use of samples while minimizing the number/cost of animals needed for interlocked experiments. Core C will be also responsible for education, training, and animal care of all microsurgical procedures. This core will also provide support for IACUC submissions, amendments in addition to safety and humane animal care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Organ transplantation is the treatment of choice for end-stage-organ failure. Although aging affects immune compartments and functions in a complex and specific fashion, age-specific treatments have not been delineated. The goal of this proposal is to transform our understanding of age-specific alloimmunity and to improve the care for the rapidly increasing amount of older transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The process of aging rewires the immune system and alters mechanisms of solid organ transplant rejection. Despite substantial increases in the frequency of aged patients undergoing transplantation, little is known how these processes work. The proposed studies will identify how unique settings of aging control transplant rejection, thereby facilitating the development of new therapeutics to treat rejection in aged individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cancer typically takes years to go from one abnormal cell to a life-threatening tumor, but work in mouse models suggest that the kind of cell from which a tumor arises can have long-lasting effects on the behavior of the disease. In this study, we aim to develop methods to determine the so-called “cells of origin” of pancreatic and liver cancers, and determine if the clinical behavior of human cancers is also determined by features of those cells. We will use genetic information from human cancer samples to identify these cells and their relationship to tumor types and patient outcomes, with an ultimate goal of using these data as prognostic biomarkers in a clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Differences in how liquid biopsy samples are handled and preserved before they are analyzed can significantly affect the accuracy of testing results. This project will systematically study the factors involved in preparing liquid blood and bone marrow aspirates in order to optimize the measurement accuracy and reproducibility of live cell, protein functional testing and the use of these tests in clinical precision medicine trials. This work will further accelerate the widespread adoption of next-generation functional testing leading to more accurate clinical decision-making and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Warfarin (Coumadin™ and others) is a blood thinner that prevents venous and arterial blood clots but doubles the risk of bleeding. To reduce the risks of warfarin overdose and bleeding, the investigators will use personalized medicine and machine learning to develop algorithms to guide the initiation of warfarin therapy. They will put these algorithms on a free, non-profit website (WarfarinDosing.org) and integrate them into electronic medical records.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the development and validation of crucial new technologies for selective control of synaptically-connected circuit elements across the brain during behavior is essential for defining novel brain circuits and therapeutic strategies for treating devastating psychiatric disorders, such as depression, anxiety disorders, and schizophrenia, as well as neurological disorders including memory decline, stroke, and epilepsy, which currently have a profound negative impact on public health. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission in that it directly addresses the call for innovating and validating novel tools to facilitate the detailed analysis of complex circuits and to enable the immense potential of circuit manipulation (BRAIN Initiative).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Lung Cancer Screening (LCS) has been recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force and Veterans Health Administration (VA) since 2013 and 2017, respectively. However, most of the estimated 1.5 to 2.7 million eligible Veterans have not participated in LCS. VA has mandated that facilities must include high-quality components in their screening program or refer eligible Veterans to community care. Many patients who received LCS have had inadequate care coordination, may have little knowledge about the benefits and harms and may not have had their values and preferences assessed. These obstacles may lead to fragmented care, poor adherence, and personal regret about patients’ decision to participate in screening. Thus, it is important to understand processes for community care LCS and identify methods that VA can use to improve that care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Overall Select zoonotic RNA viruses within the Paramyxoviridae and Bunyavirales represent a continuous threat to global public health due to their ease of dissemination and/or transmissibility from person-to-person and result in significant morbidity and mortality, thus requiring special actions for public health preparedness. These viral threats to global public health are heightened due to the absence of approved vaccines or therapeutics. There is a clear unmet need for vaccines and antibody-based therapeutics to address these threats that can arise from natural outbreaks, epidemics, or bio-weaponization and deliberate release.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement  To meet the public health needs of our regional communities, the EOHS programs, Bachelor of Science and Master of Science, prepare students with a foundation in basic and applied sciences, including biology, chemistry, mathematics, physics, geology, and public health. The interdisciplinary application of training in the EOHS programs has led to the development of skills that trainees utilize in a variety of public health settings. Students graduating from the EOHS programs regularly pursue advanced degrees, and have become occupational safety and health specialists, environmental health and safety specialists, industrial hygienists, or work in closely related fields with emphases on human health protection and advancement in diverse worksites and in underserved communities across Kentucky, and beyond.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Environmental and Occupational Health Science Program at Western Kentucky University

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative This application proposes a continuation of our occupational safety and health (OSH) training program that focuses on strengthening the pool of qualified OSH professionals in New York and the surrounding region. The program aims to meet industry needs by providing multidisciplinary training that includes coursework and practical experience to develop technical skills in safety, industrial hygiene, and ergonomics, along with professional skills in management, effective communication, and regulatory affairs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: University at Buffalo, SUNY Occupational Safety and Health Training Project

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This project supports research and training of undergraduate and graduate students to become leaders in industrial hygiene and occupational safety. Through training and research, this program directly supports the CDC’s Healthy People 2030 goals of reducing work-related fatalities, injuries, and disease as well as multiple goals within NIOSH’s National Occupational Research Agenda, including: Construction, Manufacturing, and Mining Sectors as well as Cross-Sector Goals within Cancer, Reproductive, Cardiovascular, and Other Chronic Disease Prevention and Respiratory Health. In particular, this program addresses the need for increased numbers of highly skilled occupational health and safety professionals in the Midwest, a region with a substantial amount of industry yet, unfortunately, higher than average rates of workplace fatalities and injuries.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Occupational Safety and Health Training Grant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Both comparative and single-race studies suggest that Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias (ADRD) are becoming as prevalent among American Indians and Alaska Natives (AI/ANs) as they are in the all-races population with the reduction in life expectancy disparities experienced by AI/ANs. However, most of the small amount of work in this area was conducted in rural or reservation settings, even though over 70% of AI/ANs reside in urban areas. This study will address the epidemiology of ADRD in urban AI/AN elders aged 55 and older, and examine how mechanisms related to vascular brain injury may contribute to ADRD pathology with advanced imaging techniques and neurocognitive assessments, establishing a baseline cohort of urban elders for future longitudinal study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Throughout recorded history, humans have used natural products, including the cannabis plant (Cannabis sativa/indica), for medicinal purposes. However, like other natural products, cannabis is not a single chemical entity, but rather contains over 100 phytocannabinoids as well as over 500 other identified chemicals, including the terpenoids that give cannabis its distinctive flavoring and aroma. Recently, we have secured access to purified minor cannabinoids synthesized via a patented biosynthetic process in quantities that allow for preclinical in vivo testing. The goal of the proposed project is to provide a comprehensive evaluation of these compounds alone, and in planned combinations, to determine their potential efficacy as analgesics. In addition, we will conduct a parallel investigation of selected terpenes that have been identified in the cannabis plant. Discovery of non-opioid analgesics could have a major impact on reducing opioid-associated morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Inflammatory bowel diseases are characterized by altered gut microbial short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), upregulated interleukin-22 (IL-22) activity, and impaired intestinal stem cell (ISC) self-renewal and differentiation. The SCFA, butyrate, enhances IL-22 receptor expression and signaling in human colon cancer cells, and IL-22 is theorized to favor asymmetric division of ISCs into progenitor cells during intestinal wound healing, but robust in vitro methods to study this mechanism have yet to be established. This proposal seeks to investigate butyrate effects on IL-22-induced asymmetric division of primary human colonic ISCs using a novel planar crypt microarray (PCM) platform and reporter cell lines for live-imaging and transcriptomic analysis, shedding light on the potential role of butyrate-IL-22-signaling in IBD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative: Down syndrome (DS), caused by triplication of human chromosome 21, is the most common genetic origin of intellectual disability. Here, we propose to employ a novel human microglial mouse brain model that is created by using human DS induced pluripotent stem cells to study the role of human microglia in DS in vivo. Results from this study will unravel the pathogenic role of microglia in DS and identify molecules that can be targeted to improve microglial function for the treatment of DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Narrative Cardiovascular disease remains a leading cause of death world-wide. Immune cells (B cells, T cells, monocytes, and macrophages) are key protective cells in blood vessels. But, unfortunately, these cells can functionally change to increase cardiovascular disease. The goal of our Program is to understand how and why these changes occur in order to prevent them so that the immune cells continue to function in a protective manner. We will tackle these goals by studying human subjects with low and high CAD risk in three clinical cohorts, and in well-defined mouse models of atherosclerosis. The end goal of our studies is to identify safe new therapeutic strategies targeting immune cell function to limit cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Aging is associated with loss of lung structure, declining function, and increased susceptibility to lung disease, together termed senile emphysema. The goal of this proposal is to address this knowledge gap by first defining the mechanisms that result in loss of the novel adult mesenchymal vascular progenitor (ABCG2pos MVPC) function contributing to accelerated lung aging and increased susceptibility to emphysema in the aged population. Secondly, we will define whether progenitor rescue with cell therapy or interventional treatment will restore lung structure and function, attenuating lung aging and susceptibility to emphysema in the aged population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal would substantially expand our understanding of postpartum-related breast cancers (PRBCs) by: 1) defining proliferative and immune effects associated with pregnancy and healthy postpartum involution (PPI) after weaning; 2) assessing how breast cancer risk factors affect the intensity of inflammation associated with PPI, thereby identifying potential candidates for prevention; 3) defining an immune biomarker panel (i.e., PRBC Immune Score) that distinguishes inflammation associated with development of PRBCs from healthy PPI and 4) testing whether aspirin can reduce inflammatory changes in the breast linked to development of PRBCs (i.e., lower PRBC Immune Score). Further, by assessing the correlation of epidemiologic risk factors and inflammatory markers in blood and urine with changes in inflammation in breast tissues associated with a trial of aspirin, we aim to identify characteristics of women who may respond favorably to an anti-inflammatory PRBC preventive intervention. Thus, the knowledge gained from the three synergistic aims proposed in this application may help identify women at increased risk of PRBCs and identify candidates for short-term, well- tolerated preventive interventions with anti-inflammatory or immune agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use disorder is characterized by continued use of the drugs despite a knowledge of negative consequences. This project will entail careful investigation of prefrontal cortex circuits involved in opioid-induced risk-taking behavior in rats. Because the proposed experiments include recordings and manipulations of prefrontal cortex activity, a brain structure that can be targeted clinically through noninvasive technologies such as transcranial magnetic stimulation, the results may shed light on the development of novel therapies for psychiatric disorders characterized by risky decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Although quitting smoking is the most important action a smoker can take to prevent premature mortality, cessation has proven difficult. Observed relations between craving and relapse suggest that novel approaches to craving relief are sorely needed, and initial findings support the use of olfactory cues to control cravings. Integrating theory and research derived from three disciplines rarely applied to smoking research (olfaction, emotion, and cognition), the application combines brain imaging and behavioral research to understand how odors work to reduce craving and to identify ways of matching odors to individual smokers, setting the stage for future research testing its value as a component of a smoking cessation intervention and for testing the impact of olfaction on a variety of mind/body experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory pathogens such as influenza viruses constitute a major human health problem worldwide, resulting in up to 600,000 deaths every year. One approach to enhance protective immunity against these pathogens is through the generation of tissue-resident memory T cells in the lung that are uniquely positioned to provide immediate effector functions at the site of pathogen entry, but the mechanisms guiding their development and maintenance remain poorly defined. The goals of this proposal are to determine the cellular and molecular events that regulate the generation and longevity of lung-resident memory T cells in mice and humans in order to better guide future cell-mediated vaccine design against respiratory pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to understand the contributions of extracranial carotid artery disease (ECAD) to brain health and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. Using cross-sectional and prospective longitudinal studies, we will attempt to identify: 1) which early AD-specific pathological changes are associated with ECAD, 2) mechanisms of ECAD effects, and 3) whether ECAD-specific treatment improves/prevents relevant outcomes. This will help elucidate vascular contributions to AD risk and has the potential to greatly benefit two large patient populations: those with ECAD and those at risk for AD, which we hypothesize overlap more than is currently appreciated.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: RELEVANCE: Glioblastoma (GBM) is a highly malignant brain tumor, with documented increased risk in Gulf war veterans. Exposure to nerve agents in Iraq in 1991 have been linked with a higher risk of developing brain tumors, with distinct patterns of brain changes when compared with other Veterans. Additionally, Veteran GBM patients tend to have higher comorbidity burden and worse overall survival than the general U.S. population. There is currently an unmet clinical need for developing companion diagnostic solutions using routine clinical MRIs that can reliably (a) identify Veteran GBM patients who will or will not respond to conventional chemoradiation, and (b) differentiate benign treatment changes from tumor recurrence. We propose to develop Neuro-image risk classifier (NeuRisC), which when successfully deployed will pave the way for improving quality- of-life in Veteran GBM patients by (a) decreasing financial and therapeutic toxicity associated with chemotherapy, while (b) alleviating anxiety and unnecessary biopsies in patients with benign treatment changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This work will determine if the addition of ventilatory support and/or the drug Buspirone improve ventilatory exercise responses in high level SCI and result in greater improvements in aerobic capacity, pulmonary function, and cardiometabolic risk. The two approaches to overcome ventilatory limitations treat mechanical constraints of paralyzed pulmonary musculature and loss of serotonergic respiratory control, both of which may contribute to blunted ventilatory responses. The ultimate purpose of this research is to optimize exercise for a population that both needs and seeks the broad range of benefits that exercise can confer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Inappropriate use of antibiotics is linked to antibiotic resistance and life-threatening adverse events. Positive urine tests are a major driver of inappropriate antibiotic use. Asymptomatic surgical patients are often screened before surgery and positive urine tests treated with antibiotics, despite guidance that patients without infection symptoms should not have a urine tests performed and should not receive antibiotics if the test is positive. The overall goal of the proposed study is to develop and pilot-test a de-implementation tool to end a common long- standing practice of screening and treating urine tests in asymptomatic surgical patients. First, we will use VA data to identify factors associated with urine testing and antibiotic treatment in surgical patients and track these in real time. Second, we will visit 5 VA hospitals and interview surgeons and other providers to determine why urine tests and treatment are done and what interventions would be acceptable. Third, we will create a tool to stop unnecessary urine testing and antibiotic treatment and evaluate it in 10 VA hospitals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Many aspects of the neurosynaptic pathology that mediate the influence of TDP-43 on cognition and behavior are relatively unexplored. Similarly, the influence of microglia activation and immune alterations in this process are unknown. The proposed research will generate a great deal of information on the status of synapses and potential trans-synaptic spread of TDP pathology as well as the role of microglia in these processes and in immune alterations. The findings have the potential to illuminate pathways that can serve as therapeutic targets.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a highly innovative research plan to ameliorate the effects of aging and enhance the therapeutic potential of senescent cells and the regenerative capacity of aged skeletal muscle tissue. The proposed research is important and timely, given the surge in the aging population in the US and the world and the severe effects of aging on skeletal muscle and related frailty affecting the elderly. Successful attainment of this work will have significant impact in understanding cellular senescence as well as the development of treatments to restore tissue/organ function and ameliorate the negative effects of aging.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The long-term goal of the proposed research is to ensure that Veterans receive high-value care, regardless of whether this care is provided by VA medical centers (VAMCs) or in the community in non-VA settings. This study will advance VA’s understanding of which types of low-value health services (i.e., services whose costs or harms exceed their benefits) are most frequently provided to Veterans, which are most costly, and reasons for their use, in three care settings: within the VA in VAMCs, in non-VA healthcare settings accessed through VA Community Care, and in non-VA healthcare settings accessed through Medicare benefits. It will provide VA with critical information needed to prioritize and develop performance measures, policies, and interventions to ensure that Veterans avoid low-value care in VA and non-VA settings, as VA evolves as a provider and payer of Veteran care. It will also allow Veterans to consider the value of care when choosing to receive healthcare in VA versus non-VA settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Huntington’s disease (HD), with its single genetic cause, an expanded CAG repear in HTT, is an inherited neurodegenerative disorder that devastates entire families. This project uses genetic and genomic approaches to uncover other genes that significantly influence when diagnosable symptoms emerge and how rapidly they worsen. Using a combination of human HD disease subject sample collections, induced pluripotent stem cell lines and neuronal cells derived from them, we will home in on the precise genes and biological pathways that influence the distinct HTT CAG-initiated disease processes that lead to onset and worsening of disease, respectively. We will thereby generate the knowledge and experimental resources to support therapeutic development for the first time based upon targets already validated to alter the rate of HD in humans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cognitive aging is the decline in performance with age seen in otherwise healthy people free of even of asymptomatic degenerative brain disease. The anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) appears to be the principal site of hypometabolism in cognitive aging; this decline correlates with declining executive function. A hypothesis posits ACC dysfunction is related to oxidative stress that is seen universally in models of aging. Furthermore, emotional stress can contribute to oxidation thereby aggravating ACC hypometabolism. This project tests whether aging and emotional stress, the latter as indexed by PTSD, is associated with redox stress in the ACC. If demonstrated and quantified, use of antioxidants such as nicotinamide riboside or N-acetyl cysteine will be motivated to treat and prevent this aging-related cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The risk of treatment of brain aneurysms can exceed their rupture risk (which has devastating consequences) thus creating an urgent need to discriminate between fragile and robust aneurysms in order to make precise and personalized decisions about their clinical management. With the long-term goal of creating practical means of assessing aneurysm wall vulnerability and rupture risk, and having found that aneurysms with blebs (secondary outpouchings) can have different wall structures and failure mechanisms than other aneurysms, the objective of this project is to identify clinically measurable features that predispose some aneurysms to bleb formation and then determine which wall characteristics determine wall vulnerability in these aneurysms. The knowledge and results generated in this project are expected to have a positive impact on human health because they will improve risk assessment in cerebral aneurysms, provide targets for drug therapy and identify preventative approaches for aneurysm treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Resting fMRI is widely used, but there have been no robust biomarkers that have emerged for early prediction of Alzheimer’s disease. The emergence of methods that can capture time-resolved connectivity show greater individualized prediction accuracy than measures that rely on averaging brain connectivity over a relatively long time period. In this work, we will develop time-resolved methods that can capture multiscale dynamic connectivity as well as homogeneous subgroups of subjects and data and utilize these to predict future cognitive decline as well as tau and amyloid measures in a large existing dataset of adults including many with prodromal Alzheimer’s disease. 36

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preventing acute pain from becoming chronic is a promising therapeutic target. Astrocyte activation is an important component of the chronic pain state. This application proposes to use a combination of molecular, imaging, and behavioral approaches to investigate how astrocyte activation is modulated by microglia and the role of microglia-mediated astrocyte activation in chronic pain. The results from the experiments proposed in this study will elucidate the role of microglia in astrocyte activation and determine if microglia-derived differences in astrocyte state contribute to pain behaviors, providing new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Effective treatment strategies to halt ovarian cancer peritoneal metastases are still lacking, which is problematic as few ovarian cancer cases are diagnosed prior to this stage. In this proposal, we aim to understand how the omentum, the earliest site of peritoneal metastasis, supports ovarian tumor seeding and dissemination. Ultimately, the insight gained will allow us to uncover more specific therapeutic strategies to improve outcomes for ovarian cancer patients with peritoneal metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: High blood pressure is the most prevalent modifiable risk factor for dementia and cardiovascular disease among older adults in the United States; however, clinic-based blood pressure measurement is inaccessible to many older adults, especially in the COVID-19 era, often delaying hypertension diagnosis and treatment. While home- based blood pressure measures show promise for overcoming access barriers and promoting more timely treatment, there is a dearth of evidence informing the clinical interpretation of these measurements inolder adults in the United States, a population characterized by high blood pressure variability and discordance from clinic- based blood pressure. Our proposal will perform home blood pressure monitoring and 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring assessments in over 2,100 community-dwelling adults, aged 80-100 years, establishing the measurement performance, prognostic utility (for dementia and cardiovascular disease), and clinical interpretation of home-based blood pressure measurements in this vulnerable population in the United States.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Alcohol abuse exacts a major toll on health and health costs in Veterans. Even though there has been an “epidemic” of hepatitis C in the U.S. and the Veterans Administration, alcohol-related liver injury remains a higher cause of mortality. Studies from the Veterans Administration showed that patients with cirrhosis and superimposed alcoholic hepatitis had > 60% mortality over a four-year period of time, with most of those deaths occurring in the first few months. Thus, the prognosis for this stage of ALD is worse than many common types of cancer, such as breast, prostate and colon. Unfortunately, there is no FDA-approved therapy for any stage of ALD, and this makes the need for this proposed research even more compelling. The proposed studies will help to better understand the molecular mechanisms of alcohol-induced liver and intestinal injury, including alcohol-diet interactions, which may lead to identification of new therapeutic targets and potential dietary interventions for treating ALD, as well as help to explain why only some heavy drinkers develop clinically important ALD.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Serving a densely populated state with a diverse population of pets and livestock, the Animal Health Diagnostic Laboratory (AHDL) at the New Jersey Department of Agriculture (NJDA) has a responsibility to safeguard the health and well-being of not only the animal population, but also the human population. When animal food or drug products are contaminated, human health may be compromised either through consumption of contaminated products or by consuming ingredients used in both animal and human products. The equipment, supplies, personnel, and training supported by the co-operative agreement funding will improve the capabilities of the AHDL to a) respond to animal food and drug contamination events, potential outbreaks, and incidents needing surge capacity b) provide analytical data for regulatory purposes, and c) participate in interlaboratory method comparison, small-scale method development and/or validation, and matrix extension

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuropilin-1 (NRP1) is recently identified to be a prognostic marker in heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), but its role in the disease pathogenesis and the underlying molecular mechanism are still not well understood. This proposed study aims to identify NRP1 as a novel mediator of TNFα-induced endothelial cell dysfunction and reveal how the crosstalk of NRP1 and TNFα contributes to the disease initiation and progression of HFpEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pannexin (PANX1-3) are important ATP-release channels playing critically physiological roles ranging from blood pressure regulation, glucose uptake, apoptotic cell clearance, tumor metastasis, ischemia-reperfusion, human oocyte development to skin/skeleton development. The proposed study focuses on untangling the oligomeric state, channel assembly, molecular structure, gating mechanism, and pharmacology of the PANX1-3, taking advantage of single-particle cryo-EM, electrophysiology, and other functional approaches. The proposed research is relevant to public health and NIH’s mission because this work will provide a deep understanding and broaden our knowledge of the relationships between atomic structures and the complex biological and pathological functions of PANXs, paving the way for the development of therapeutics to treat pannexin-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Organization of the human genome in the nucleus is critical to maintain proper gene function and specific alterations in this organization are associated with many diseases. However, the fundamental principles controlling the three-dimensional (3D) genome organization remain poorly understood. This study is important to public health and aligns with the mission of the NIGMS as it will identify the regulatory elements that control genome organization and will contribute to understand the significance of genome organization alterations in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Most genetic variants that contribute to the risk or severity of common and rare diseases fall in regions of the human genome that control the expression of genes, rather than in the genes themselves. Although we have learned the hallmark characteristics of such “enhancer” regions, it has been exceedingly difficult to pinpoint which genetic variants within them are disease-contributory and which gene(s) they act through. Here we propose to leverage cutting-edge technologies to functionally test over one million candidate enhancers or variants therein for their role in modulating the expression of neighboring genes. If we are successful, this work will critically facilitate the leveraging of genetics to inform the prediction of individual disease risk, as well as the development or prioritization of therapeutic strategies that are well-supported by genetic evidence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To understand the Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) pathogenesis mechanism, we must understand brain region- specific and cell-type-specific dysregulations of signaling pathways in the LBD brain. To achieve this goal, we propose to uncover region-specific and cell-type-specific dysregulations of proteome and transcriptome in the LBD brain. This study will enable us to understand the cellular signaling pathways of region-specific vulnerability to pathological α-syn in LBD. Eventually, this study will lead us to understand the LBD pathogenesis mechanism.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Effective treatments for peripheral artery disease and chronic limb ischemia are limited and leave veterans with chronic pain and possible amputation, since as a group they are at higher risk for these complications. Exposure of blood and muscle to red light increases blood flow by increasing nitric oxide through the secretion of S- nitrosothiols contained in endothelial vesicles. Understanding how light facilitates this secretion will help design new classes of drug therapies to help veterans with vascular diseases by producing a stable nitric oxide source. Further characterization of this cellular mechanism of nitric oxide release is a vital step in the expansion of red light therapy as a common treatment modality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mismatch repair (MMR) defects cause inherited cancer susceptibility in humans, play a role in the development of a proportion of many types of sporadic human cancer and are predictive of a striking response to cancer immunotherapy using checkpoint inhibitors. This project will provide new insights into both the mechanisms of MMR and the function of the proteins that catalyze MMR. The results of this project will provide a better understanding of basic MMR mechanisms and will potentially impact the development of clinical tests for the MMR status of patients and tumors and improvements in cancer therapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) -- an invasive, expensive, and life-saving procedure -- are at substantial risk for delirium, with associated morbidity and mortality. This study will define the incidence, risk factors, and outcomes of delirium in children during the peri-transplant period. By identifying modifiable factors that contribute to delirium development, this project will lead to a reduction in delirium rates, and optimize long-term outcomes after pediatric HSCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE mTOR is a central controller of cancer growth and an anticancer target. This application will test the central hypothesis that aberrant mTOR signaling promotes oncogenic chromatin remodeling through degradation of the tumor suppressor ARID1A, which is important for cancer development and response to mTOR-targeted cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increased inflammation and dysfunctional mitochondria (organelles responsible for energy transduction and signaling) coincide in a range of chronic and age-related diseases, but knowledge regarding how inflammation affects mitochondrial function remains lacking. The current application aims to identify and characterize the functional consequences of how inflammatory signaling directly – and in many cases harmfully – reprograms mitochondrial function. Successful completion of this project will improve our understanding of crosstalk between metabolism and immunity, further define how mitochondria adapt to stress, and help guide approaches seeking to restore mitochondrial function to treat human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Abstract The 3 overarching goals of the USC Alzheimer Disease Research Center (ADRC) are: 1) Elucidate vascular contributions to Alzheimer disease (AD), 2) catalyze basic, clinical, and translational research in AD at USC, and 3) contribute expertise in vascular disease, biomarkers, and imaging to national collaborative initiatives. The ADRC is led by 3 principal investigators: Chui, Zlokovic, and Toga and comprised of 6 required cores, the required Research Education Component (REC), and 1 optional imaging core. The Administration Core provides administrative and scientific oversight across the ADRC, including fostering development projects and supporting ADRC-affiliated studies. The Clinical Core performs standardized evaluations and diagnoses using a standardized database, enrolls and follows participants in the Vascular Cohort Study (VCS) and Brain Research Study (BRS). The Data Management and Statistical Core provides study- and core-specific databases and curates our large imaging data sets as a local and national resource. The Neuropathology Core performs standardized neuropathological examinations, stores and distributes biological tissues to research investigators. The Outreach, Recruitment, and Engagement Core works closely with the Clinical Core to recruit and retain participants in VCS and BRS, especially those from under-represented minority groups, and the development of a participant-caregiver dyad database. The Biomarker Core uses state of the art methods to determine cell-and system-specific biomarkers related to the neurovascular unit, as well as to measure standard AD biomarkers. The Imaging Core provides high field (3T and 7T) MR imaging, as well as amyloid/tau PET scans. The Research Education Component is dedicated to mentoring post-doctoral students committed to the study of under- represented minority issues in Alzheimer disease and related disorders. The USC Health Science Campus is located near high Latinx catchment areas. Treatable vascular-metabolic risk factors are particularly prevalent among the Latinx population and dovetail with the research focus of the USC ADRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Melanoma is the deadliest form of skin cancer, and its incidence is on the rise with 106,000 new cases expected in the U.S. in 2021. Although immunotherapies are revolutionizing the treatment of melanoma, they are associated with significant toxicity, and there are no clinically useful biomarkers to predict which tumors will respond to single agent or combination immunotherapies. This project will use an integrated proteogenomics approach to improve our understanding of mechanisms of resistance to ICIs to design more effective immunotherapies and combinations, and to identify potential biomarkers to select patients appropriately for single agent vs combination immunotherapies, and to predict and monitor irAEs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This training program, directed at Ph.D. and M.D. fellows, prepares trainees for independent research to address the challenge of HIV/AIDS especially among children, adolescents, and young adults under the age of 25. Faculty in the Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, Providence/Boston Center for AIDS Research, Brown School of Public Health, and the Division of Infectious Disease provide research mentoring and didactic instruction on youth behavioral health and medical aspects of HIV research. Training involves interdisciplinary and translational elements to prepare trainees for the integration of the medical, psychiatric, and developmental issues informing biobehavioral HIV/AIDS Research.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative  The long-term goal of this multi-institutional research is to improve patient safety by establishing simulator training and evaluation of surgical skills as essential components of orthopedic residency programs. Objectively measuring skill in the OR is a critical step toward this goal because it allows skills training to be linked to performance in surgery; skill assessment in the lab guides progress to the OR, and assessment in the OR informs skills lab methods and benchmarks. This research is innovative because it demonstrates and disseminates new skill assessment techniques critically needed to hasten improvement in resident performance, ultimately reducing costs while enhancing patient safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Postnatal growth failure is a significant morbidity in very low birth weight infants and is associated with increased risk of later cardiometabolic diseases and neurodevelopmental impairment. We and others have identified in humans and animal models that early life sodium depletion contributes to impaired growth while our novel preliminary data suggests a key role for short- and long-term metabolic processes. We will address this key knowledge gap by combining novel approaches in study design, techniques and transgenic animal models to identify mechanisms by which early life Na homeostasis regulates growth and energy expenditure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Metformin has the potential to increase lifespan in several animal model systems. It is currently explored for its potential to slow human aging. Yet, the underlying mechanism by which metformin increases, or in some cases decreases lifespan are unresolved. We propose to conduct a genome wide association study with Drosophila to uncover how metformin modulates aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Harvard/MIT MD-PhD Program is to “train the next-generation of premier and diverse physician- scientist leaders” who embody the dual-calling to make a difference today by touching the life of a patient in need and make a difference tomorrow by achieving scientific breakthroughs that will change our world. By harnessing the educational, clinical, and scientific resources of Harvard Medical School, Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and its world-class hospitals and affiliated institutes, we aim to provide our students with unparalleled depth and breadth of clinical and research opportunities supported by a profoundly caring and invested community of student colleagues, faculty mentors, and program staff. Our dynamic training program is based on a series of academic and integrative objectives, girded by principles of rigor, integrity, responsibility, self-evaluation, inclusivity, diversity, and empathy, with the ultimate goal of contributing to a much-needed, multidisciplinary MD-PhD workforce to serve the critical health care and biomedical technology needs of the United States and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Serrated tumors are a subset of colon tumors with especially poor prognosis, and while these tumors are believed to initiate with mutations to the BRAF gene, the immediate consequences of these mutations within cancer-initiating cells remain unclear. Using new technologies, the proposed research will investigate changes in gene regulatory mechanisms in the moments after oncogenic mutations in BRAF. The proposed studies are significant in that they will facilitate chemoprevention, early detection, and/or tumor-suppression strategies for Serrated colon cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some patients who have unhealthy tissue (e.g., a tumor) removed from their liver using a surgical procedure called partial hepatectomy develop complications because the remaining liver tissue does not sufficiently regenerate to recover its normal function. Our studies suggest that partial hepatectomy is associated with activation of blood clotting in the liver of humans and mice, and that a specific blood clotting protein, fibrinogen, can promote liver regeneration. The primary goal of this research is to discover how fibrinogen promotes liver regeneration so that we can discover new strategies to predict, prevent and ultimately treat liver dysfunction in patients after partial hepatectomy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of the actin and myosin network can profoundly disrupt how cells respond to their environment and communicate with one another, leading to cancer and birth defects, such as neural tube defects and hereditary deafness. The proposed work will advance our understanding of how actin and myosin networks influence cell-cell communications essential for tissue assembly. Ultimately, this new knowledge will facilitate diagnosis and treatment of human birth defects and help improve the health and quality of life by restoring, maintaining, or enhancing tissue and organ function.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Southwest Health Equity Research Collaborative (SHERC) will recruit and support a new cadre of health equity-related researchers to grow basic biomedical, clinical, and behavioral research at Northern Arizona University with a focus on translational research, team science and diversity, equity, inclusion, and justice. SHERC research projects will explore multi-level factors that might lead to increased health risks and disease transmission, and variables that may affect disease morbidity and mortality in underserved populations in Arizona and the southwestern United States. In collaboration with community-based organizations, community leaders, policy experts, and researchers, SHERC will identify relevant strategies to enhance community assets and resilience to minimize the impacts of health disparities and advance health equity in our region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to inform upon the potential benefits of surgical versus medical intervention for type B aortic dissection through the development of modern geometric and mechanistically based selection criteria. Upon completion there will be a richer and more nuanced understanding of aortic stability as defined from computed tomography angiography imaging, which will allow for more optimal patient selection. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission to enhance cardiovascular health and improve mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Tissue-engineered medical products (TEMPs) have the potential to restore form, function and appearance to patients who suffer from trauma, disease or congenital defects that are otherwise untreatable by either pharmaceuticals or biopharmaceuticals. TEMPs can also be used in research and development for drug screening, for personalized medicine, and could reduce the need for animal testing. The fact that these products are not available commercially highlights a large and pressing unmet demand; the goal of this project is to develop technological solutions to transition tissue engineering from laboratory-scale to the world of commercial manufacturing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wound healing is an energetically demanding process and outcomes of identical wounds in different individuals are notably heterogeneous, ranging from regenerative (low scarring) in some to functionally debilitating and harmful scarring (high scar) in others, which often causes major healthcare, psychosocial, and economic burdens. To address this vital unmet clinical need, our aim is to discover what determines human wound healing and scar heterogeneity so that we can create therapies to reduce or even prevent fibrosis and scars in both dermal and other organ injuries. The research proposed in this application will investigate how cells from different patients uniquely change their energy metabolism in response to biomechanical tension and oxidative stress after injury to result in different degrees of scarring, which could inform the development of effective new therapies to improve tissue repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed “Biobehavioral Research Training to End the HIV/AIDS Epidemic” T32 is a competing continuation of the UCLA training program to prepare physician and social/behavioral scientists for academic research careers focused on integrated biomedical-behavioral (i.e., biobehavioral) approaches to HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment in diverse global settings. Despite remarkable advances in prevention of new HIV infections and treatment of HIV disease, significant challenges remain that highlight the need for integrating behavioral science and biomedical approaches. The renewal of our highly successful training program will help ensure that a new generation of scientific leaders is prepared to take us forward into the next era of HIV research, specifically by providing training to integrate behavioral and biomedical approaches to ending HIV/AIDS globally.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: I am reapplying for 5 years of support for mentored training and research. The proposed training and research projects address a key gap in care quality for patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) requiring cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT): the treatment of non-response to CRT and uncertainty in the feasibility of measuring cardiac function in these patients with cardiac MRI (CMR). We plan to prospectively assess the use of a novel cardiac pacing method with a lead placed in the left bundle branch area (LBBAP) in Veterans with HFrEF whom have been identified as CRT non-responders, and to measure cardiac function using CMR in addition to traditional echocardiography. We expect that LBBAP will result in significant improvement in cardiac function versus continued CRT, and that CMR will be an accurate and feasible method to assess cardiac function in these patients with cardiac devices. This award supports my long-term goal of using cardiac imaging to improve care of Veterans with heart failure whom require device therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Comprehensive profiling of DNA and RNA molecules, including nucleotide modifications, is important for a complete understanding of how genes are normally regulated or dysregulated in disease; however, this requires methods for higher resolution profiling than what is currently available by standard sequencing techniques. To this end, we will develop approaches using long-read technology to simultaneously detect in vivo genome-wide DNA modification and accessibility and correlate changes with complete RNA sequences, along with RNA modifications. We will apply our approaches to the study of well-characterized biological responses known to impact chromatin in established mammalian cell lines and probe the inter-dependence of the epigenome and epitranscriptome by suppressing expression of key protein modulators.

PROJECT_TITLE: A novel approach to improve comprehensive profiling of the epigenome and epitranscriptome

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a debilitating neurodegenerative disorder that disrupts proper movement control and motor learning. Motor control and skilled motor learning are regulated by the striatum, which integrates excitatory inputs in the form of glutamate from the cortex and thalamus. This proposal uses interdisciplinary approaches to identify the mechanisms that determine the synaptic plasticity in the striatum, and results from these studies aim to generate a better mechanistic understanding of how dopamine and loss of dopamine alter the striatal function, ultimately to provide potential new therapeutic avenues for PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: The goal of this study is to develop a new paradigm of deep learning that combines medical imaging data and clinical knowledge to augment breast cancer diagnosis, risk assessment, and lesion detection. This study will contribute major technical innovations for deep learning on small datasets, longitudinal examinations, and content-efficient images, not only to breast imaging, but also applicable/extendable to other diseases/organs. New algorithms, tools, and source code will be provided to advance research and clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Melanocyte development involves both extensive proliferation and the formation of a large number of dendrites. Both of these processes are likely to require high levels of fatty acids, however, the mechanism through which melanocytes access fatty acids during development is not known. This study aims to determine how melanocytes acquire fatty acids during differentiation and what role these fatty acids play in proper melanocyte development and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a devastating, progressive, neurodegenerative disease that affects millions of Americans, yet there is no cure, and there are very limited treatment options. As the blood brain barrier (BBB) blocks nearly all drugs from entering the central nervous system, ultrasound contrast agents activated by ultrasound are being explored to transiently open the BBB and enhance drug delivery to the brain. This proposal will determine the mechanisms by which ultrasound contrasts agents open the BBB and use this drug delivery strategy to ultimately increase the number of therapeutic candidates that can be delivered to the brain for the treatment of AD and other neurologic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Excess body weight is associated with metabolic dysfunction, including insulin resistance and chronic inflammation, and with increased risk for chronic disease including colon cancer. We propose a 12-month randomized controlled (RCT) dietary intervention to investigate our hypothesis that restoring the natural high fiber content of the western diet with natural foods, including legumes such as dry beans, will have a multi- modal effect on suppressing the elevated colon cancer risk in high risk overweight/obese post-polypectomy volunteers by inducing weight loss, suppressing systemic inflammatory responses, and by stimulating the colonic microbial production and release of antineoplastic metabolites. Should our hypotheses prove correct, our methods could be used in other high-risk populations at risk for colon cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: “Describe the relevance of this research to public health in, at most, three sentences.” The network's overall goal is to do science that is immediately applicable to everyday clinical practice, to foster movement of its findings into everyday clinical practice, and thereby improve the health of the nation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching mission of our research is to elucidate how transcription and spatial location influence fine-scale features of genome folding. We will accomplish this goal by using both established and innovative genomics and bioinformatics to track the progress of chromatin interactions during transcription and in nuclear space. This work will resolve long-standing mechanistic questions and provide new computational and wet-lab tools for investigating genome architecture at unprecedented resolution.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative The AHDC wishes to continue its cooperative agreement with the FDA Vet-LIRN and the Vet-LIRN network of veterinary diagnostic laboratories to promote the areas of food and feed surveillance, method development and standardization, quality management, and provide surge capacity for large-scale testing in the event of an emergency. The Analytical Toxicology section of the AHDC intends to continue cooperative activities with the FDA Vet-LIRN, the Vet-LIRN network, and federal, state, local and tribal organizations to promote animal health and feed and food safety and security.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV continues to be a major cause of death and suffering worldwide. Our program supports training of early career stage investigators to become independent, patient-based and translational scientists addressing the highest impact research questions in HIV that are designed to reach affected populations. Building on the successful outcomes of our prior training program, we aim to train the next generation of researchers in HIV biomedical prevention, novel treatments and cure research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The proposed research is relevant to public health because heart failure-associated morbidity and mortality represent a major economic and health burden. The study will define the role of asporin, an extracellular matrix protein, in mediating protective effects to heart. In addition, the objective of this project is to develop new asporin- based therapies to reduce cardiac injury and adverse cardiac remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative By developing and applying new, advanced tools and methods in electron diffraction, we aim to facilitate the determination of new structures from macromolecular assemblies. To achieve this, we have assembled a team of experts in cryoEM, crystallography, biochemistry and computation that will establish MicroED as an accessible tool for experts and novices alike. With a focus on method development tested on driving biological projects, community engagement through workshops, symposiums, collaborations and one on one training, we forecast that our MicroED resource would have a long and lasting impact on biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells have unique metabolic requirements that are perturbed in disease states. Findings from our studies will provide a framework for understanding how extracellular matrix dysregulation leads to increased lipid generation and reduced anti-oxidative capacity in human RPE cells. These studies will expedite the understanding of the underlying causes of RPE-related disease and facilitate treatment discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The successful development and translation of the proposed STICK nano-delivery platform will have a significant impact on the clinical management of diffuse midline glioma (DMG) as well as many other brain malignancies. This will be accomplished by minimizing drug release into normal tissues and limiting off-target toxicity, while maximizing tumor cell-specific drug delivery to DMG, thus dramatically enhancing therapeutic efficacy and minimizing off-target toxicity. The team of experts in pediatric neuro-oncology (Drs. Antony & Monje) and epigenetics in pediatric glioma (Dr. Knoepfler) will provide comprehensive expertise to facilitate the clinical development of the proposed novel targeting and transformable nano-theranostics that will ultimately benefit many patients with DMG.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study examines the influence of sociodemographic statuses and transitions among those now entering midlife on comorbid health outcomes in early midlife, as well as the role of life-course alcohol use and social and neighborhood environments for midlife health. Drawing on longitudinal data from a diverse community sample from age 10 to 47, the study investigates the long-term malleability of environmental factors and seeks to identify promising intervention targets to design and tailor prevention programs from early adolescence to midlife. The goal of the study is to provide midlife researchers and health practitioners with specific recommendations for preventive interventions addressing public health priorities for midlife adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Narrative  Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is one of the most commonly diagnosed malignancies of the breast and data are lacking with regard to optimal treatment. Consequently, the majority of DCIS are treated in the same manner: i.e. surgery +/- radiation +/- hormonal therapy that results in either over- or under-treatment of many patients. In the current work we will test the hypothesis that histologic or radiologic markers prior to surgery can guide decision support by identifying predicting up-staging and pathological risk scoring following surgical excision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  High-throughput screening of compound libraries is a fundamental starting point to drug development efforts, and natural product libraries are one of the most valuable sources of novel bioactive molecules. However, until now there have been few evidence-based rules for the rational design of natural product libraries. This work is relevant to public health because it will demonstrate the utility of bioanalytical liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry to addressing this biological need, and lead to accelerated drug development in the long term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rate of nurses who die by suicide has reached alarming proportions, with some estimates higher than the general population and other similar workforces. However, there is limited evidence about individual and environmental factors that predispose a nurse to suicidal behavior in real-world clinical settings, nor are there significant investigations of the interplay between those factors and physiologic stress responses or epigenetics. This project will leverage advancements in stress measurement (hair cortisol) and epigenetic analysis (DNA methylation) to investigate which factors increase suicidal behavior in nurses, which may help to better identify high-risk individuals and to inform suicidal behavior prevention interventions.
