IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Disorders of the musculoskeletal system with advancing age or due to injury and trauma are among the most debilitating to the human body and costly to the healthcare system with disability. Novel treatments will require convergence of molecular, cellular, and organismic research through interdisciplinary integration of biomedical science and engineering. This T32 Program is based on the unique concept of training Ph.D. candidates in the realm of scientific convergence applied to the field of regenerative engineering to enable these discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will measure individual- and environmental-level race-specific stressors and identify the biologic mechanisms linking them to late-life cognitive decline and risk of Alzheimer’s dementia in older Black adults. These data are critical to reduce disparities and the burden of dementia and cognitive decline in a rapidly growing and understudied population.

By using mouse models of aging, we aim to identify specific regulators that will provide a target for future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Chromosomal instability (CIN) is a feature of aggressive human cancers; yet how it promotes cancer progression remains poorly understood. Building on our preliminary findings, we will ask whether CIN drives cancer spread by shaping the interaction between cancer cells and immune cells to promote immune escape. We also apply a computational method that detects cell-cell interactions to probe whether the findings from our experimental models can be generalized to a variety of human cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New vessel formation is critical for proper embryonic development and pathological progression of many diseases. We identified Myct1 (Myc target 1) as a novel and crucial endothelial gene required for tumor angiogenesis and tumor growth. Unexpectedly, Myct1 deficiency in endothelial cells leads to enhanced anti- tumor immunity, suggesting that Myct1 can modulate endothelial cell remodeling of the tumor immunity. The overall goal of the proposed studies is to investigate the mechanisms by which Myct1 regulates angiogenesis and tumor immunity and develop novel therapeutic modalities against Myct1 for treating cancer or related patho-angiogenic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability of the brain to sense changing sodium levels in the blood is critical in mediating the neurohumoral responses to hypernatremia; however, the molecular mechanisms underlying sodium sensing are poorly understood. The purpose of this translational project is to identify key sodium-sensing regions of the brain and determine if the Na-K-2Cl co-transporter mediates the neurohumoral response to acute hypernatremia. Completion of this project will increase our understanding of blood pressure regulation and salt sensitive hypertension, which has public health implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Fibrosis is a common final outcome of inflammatory diseases that results in excess collagen and other extracellular matrix proteins in tissue. This proposal uses mouse models to elucidate how chronic epidermal growth factor receptor activation drives fibrosis in the skin and its relationship with interferon signaling. By understanding how this receptor tyrosine kinase drives the production of matrix proteins, we will be able to develop new therapies that target these processes to help improve patients' lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposal aims to develop new strategies to combat a common and aggressive subtype of human breast cancer (triple-negative breast cancer, or TNBC) through modulation of antitumor immune response. We recently discovered that targeting MYC+ TNBC with spliceosome-targeted therapeautics (STTs) triggers a form of viral mimicry, where mis-spliced RNAs trigger a double-stranded RNA antiviral program. Herein, we propose to elucidate the molecular and cellular mechanisms of this STT-induced antiviral signaling and harness the resulting immune response as a therapeutic approach for TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because dysfunction of glutamatergic neurotransmission is believed to underlie a number of complex brain disorders including Autism Spectrum Disorder, Schizophrenia and Alzheimer’s Disease. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NINDS given that knowledge concerning how glutamatergic synapse function is regulated will aid in the development of new therapeutic strategies for treating such disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neurodegenerative disorders such as dementia with Lewy bodies and Parkinson’s disease are characterized by the a-syn accumulation but the downstream pathophysiological mechanisms are not known. Our data indicate that a-synuclein induces changes in nuclear paraspeckles that regulate gene expression and RNA processing. We propose to use patient-derived neurons and other models to examine mechanisms that lead to changes in gene regulation, which may help to mechanistically explain proteome dysfunction in synucleinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Chronic pain disorders negative impact over 100 million Americans who suffer with the persistence of nociceptive sensory and negative affective symptoms. Presently available pain treatments fall short in providing safe and effective analgesia and often result in detrimental side effects due to their lack of specificity. This proposal aims to characterize a negative affective brain circuit in healthy and chronic pain states with the aim of informing the development of targeted treatments to alleviate the emotional unpleasantness of pain perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative We have entered a new wave of polysynthetic drug use: people are combining drugs in new ways, eg the rising popularity of methamphetamine and heroin/fentanyl, the previously rare “goofball”. We do not know why stimulant-related deaths have risen: is it because of contamination of the stimulant supply eg with fentanyls; intentional co-use, or different, novel methods of polydrug use? The Synthetics in Combination (SYNC) study will examine a) changes in synthetic drug supplies, esp. fentanyls and methamphetamine, b) the effects of these changes on how people use drugs and c) the effects of both changing supply and use patterns on drug- related morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular malformations occur when there is abnormal development of the body's blood or lymphatic vessels. They are a relatively common birth defect and can produce significant health issues in children and adults. By developing new diagnostic methods and trying to understand how these malformations form in the first place, we will expand available treatment options and improve the lives of individuals with vascular malformations.

PHR: Project Narrative  Tumor cells are often characterized by genomes with high levels of single-base mutations, deletions/duplications, translocations, and/or aneuploidy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Population- and episode-based alternative payment models (APMs) are highly relevant to surgical care and hold organizations financially accountable for the quality and costs of care; however, these APMs are not designed to protect access or outcomes for racial/ethnic minorities and individuals with low socioeconomic status, vulnerable groups that already face significant surgical disparities. To increase understanding about the potential for these APM types to worsen disparities, this study will examine and compare how participation in major Medicare fee-for-service APMs impacts surgical access and outcomes for vulnerable patients across insurance coverage type. Results will inform design, selection, and refinement of models to continue nationwide reform while safeguarding the care of vulnerable individuals.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (Overall) Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) is the most common pediatric musculoskeletal disorder in children, causing disfigurement, pain, and other physiologic impairments later in life. The name “idiopathic” conveys the fact that the pathogenesis of AIS has been poorly understood due to gaps in fundamental knowledge of the disease. Our purpose is to build upon prior discoveries of our program and further elucidate the factors that cause and exacerbate AIS to aid diagnosis and development of noninvasive biologic treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overarching goal of the Africa Hepatopancreaticobiliary Cancer Consortium is to harness resources and expertise across the African Continent and the United States to investigate the influences of lifestyle, environment, viral and host biological factors on the development of hepatopancreaticobiliary cancers to inform strategies for risk prevention, early detection, and improved survival of patients with these cancers. In this R13 grant proposal, we will organize a series of scientific workshops and training activities in the hepatobiliary and pancreatic cancers to augment our existing collaborations for multidisciplinary investigations in the cancer continuum – from risk and prevention to cancer incipience and progression to treatment and survivorship. Our collaborative research is expected to yield novel insights into the etiology and biology of hepatobiliary and pancreatic cancer for translation to practical actions to address the perennially high incidence and mortality of these cancers in individuals of African descent (African Americans and native Africans).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary focus of the SUPERS@PENN program is to enrich the undergraduate experience by educating students on the science behind cancer and radiation research with a particular emphasis on recruitment and retention of students from underrepresented populations into the program and ultimately the research career pipeline. We propose that this cornerstone experience at a world-class institution (University of Pennsylvania) which is largely unavailable to the majority of undergraduates in the United States, will encourage them to apply to graduate school programs that eventually leads to pursuit of careers in biomedical research, particularly cancer and radiation research. By completing the stated goals set forth in this proposal, we anticipate that we will increase the quantity, quality and diversity of the next generation of scientists working in cancer and particularly radiation research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Follicular lymphomas are characterized by translocations in BCL2 and somatic mutations of epigenetic modifier genes such as EZH2. In germinal centers mutant EZH2 epigenetically reprograms B-cells to form an aberrant immunological niche. Understanding how EZH2 mutant follicular lymphomas survive in their unique rich microenvironment will advance our knowledge of the underlying mechanisms by which EZH2 mutations drive lymphomagenesis and inform the design and preclinical development of new treatment strategies to prevent disease progression and transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this training grant is to prepare the next generation of scientists who will conduct high quality research leading to new discoveries in biomedicine. The research focus of students who train in our program is to understand fundamental mechanisms in signaling and cellular regulation, an area which is key to the discovery of new therapeutic treatments for human diseases such as cancer, diabetes, inflammation, heart disease, immunological and neurological disorders, and birth defects, and forms the foundation for modern research in biology and medicine.

PROJECT_TITLE: Predoctoral Training Program in Signaling and Cellular Regulation
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - A[TWD-A]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research described in this proposal challenges longstanding views that the aged brain is unable to combat the effects of aging due to a lack of inherent plasticity, which facilitates permanent age-related regenerative and cognitive impairments. By exploring how regenerative and cognitive functions can be enhanced through increased systemic Gpld1 we aim to move closer towards realizing the possibility of reversing age-related cognitive impairments in the elderly. Moreover, this study will have significant translational potential, revealing pathways that could be targeted for novel therapies to ameliorate age-related neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Acute lung injury (ALI) is a life-threatening disease characterized by plasma leakage, increased white blood cell influx and cytokine generation. Although incremental progress has been made in managing patients suffering from ALI, the search continues for treatments to reduce the unacceptably high mortality rate in these patients. The proposed studies will characterize the role of cyclic AMP response element binding protein in generating a population of reparative alveolar macrophages that promote tissue repair after lung vascular injury, thus pointing the way to development of novel therapeutic approaches for treatment of ALI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory viral infections are linked to the development of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, but the enduring changes caused by infections that might explain chronic pathology are unknown. The ectopic development of solitary chemosensory cells (SCCs, tuft cells) after influenza infection represents a likely driver of viral-induced chronic disease, given that these cells are key modulators of both inflammation and tissue remodeling. Direct implication of SCCs and their effectors in regeneration and inflammation will validate SCCs as a potential therapeutic target in chronic lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Thousands of DNA variants may contribute to common diseases by affecting how well a gene is expressed, but the identity of these variants is unknown. The proposed study will identify specific DNA variants that alter gene expression level to influence risk of disease. The study will determine whether variants act differently in males and females; in the brain, liver, muscle, lung, and heart; and in or out of an inflamed environment. The results may lead to identification of new targets for drugs to treat common diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We have formulated a model for how changes in bacterial membrane bioenergetics (likely by sensing reactive oxygen species produced by the respiration-linked sodium pump NQR) might affect virulence factor production in V. cholerae. Results of the proposed research will not only enhance our understanding of the general bioenergetic pathways in V. cholerae, but will form a solid basis for future investigations of the molecular devices maintaining membrane respiration and their relevance in virulence. A more complete understanding of these mechanisms could ultimately lead to novel intervention therapies to treat human infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescence represents a period in the life course when many individuals initiate tobacco, alcohol, marijuana, and other drug use, yet identifying youth who are at risk of experiencing problematic substance use during adulthood remains a challenging task. To improve the long-term success of school-based prevention programs, the current study seeks to expand our understanding of the factors that heighten young people’s risk of using and misusing substances in adulthood by focusing on the relational structures of adolescent peer networks. We evaluate how patterns of direct and indirect friendship ties in adolescence impact adult substance use behaviors and consider whether this relationship varies according to the stability of ties, individual-level characteristics (e.g., gender, sexuality), and school-community context; findings will inform the design of new interventions that leverage existing social ties and discourage the formation of risky relationships to promote long-term desistance from harmful substance use behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 conventional dendritic cells (cDC2s) play critical roles in type 2 inflammation and humoral immunity. We previously identified CD301b+ cDC2s as a functionally and phenotypically distinct subset of mouse cDC2s that expands during type 2 inflammation and is required for type 2 immune responses to allergens and helminth parasites, but their differentiation mechanism remains unknown. This grant application proposes to identify the cellular origin and the molecular mechanism of their differentiation, which potentially helps us to understand the etiology of allergic and autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: There is a shortage of researchers who have skills in both statistical or molecular genetics and psychiatric epidemiology. Such individuals are needed to increase our understanding of the causes and trajectories of psychiatric disorders, so that better prevention and treatments can be developed. This training grant will educate three pre-doctoral and three postdoctoral trainees in psychiatric, behavioral, statistical and molecular genetics and neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE and PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE It is well-established that cancer cells are generally very resistant to radiation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute and chronic pancreatitis affect millions of people annually and currently lack effective treatment options. The mechanisms underlying pancreatic acinar-ductal metaplasia as a response to injury remains to be elucidated. Using novel mouse models, innovative single-cell sequencing techniques, and 3D cell-culture, this project aims to uncover mechanisms that link inflammation and KRAS mutations and proposes a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of acute pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: The proposed research aims to understand patient preferences for differentiated service delivery (DSD) programs among people living with HIV and examine the impact of preference-concordant DSD programs on clinical outcomes, quality of life, and progress toward controlling the HIV epidemic in Kenya. The results of this work will inform the design of more patient-centered DSD programs and policy decision-making in Kenya and other high HIV burden settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Effective treatments to prevent and treat atopic dermatitis (AD) skin disease are lacking due in part to an incomplete understanding of the disease. Since the human pathogen Staphylococcus aureus has been linked to AD pathogenesis, this study will elucidate the importance of S. aureus Agr virulence and skin factors for triggering skin inflammation in AD. Therefore, the proposed work will define the role of S. aureus Agr virulence factors involved in AD pathogenesis, with the long-term goal of developing new therapies to treat AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed work seeks to quantify surgeon performance and build automated assessments grounded in patient-centered outcomes to inform training surgeon on how they can improve. The nerve-sparing (NS) step during robot-assisted radical prostatectomy (RARP) is an ideal test case as it is a commonly performed procedure with significant surgeon technical variation and differences in erectile function outcomes. The knowledge gained from this research will advance other surgeries by improving the methodology of assessing surgical skill in general, objectively evaluating surgeon performance through machine learning, and developing targeted training to improve specific post-surgical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T cell–mediated autoimmune diseases such as type I diabetes result from the breakdown of tolerance mechanisms in self-reactive CD8 T cells; however, we know little about how autoimmune T cell responses are initiated and sustained. Our goal is to generate a deep mechanistic understanding of the lymph node niche- dependent factors regulating CD8 T cell differentiation over the course of type I diabetes in mice and humans and to target key molecular pathways in autoimmune T cell differentiation for the prevention and treatment of type I diabetes and other autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance Mitochondrial transport and mitophagy are crucial to neuornal survival and have been implicated many neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer' disease, and Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. These diseases afflict millions of people worldwide with tremendous global economic and societal burdens. This proposal will elucidate the mechanisms underlying neurodegeneration, and is therefore relevant to public health and the mission of the NIH, as it will provide novel targets for therapuetic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic ischemic cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD) affecting predominantly white matter (WM) in the brain is a clinically important cause of vascular cognitive impairment (VCI) and dementia. Taking advantage of a novel transgenic mouse model of CSVD/VCI, we will use a combination of transcriptomic, pharmacologic and genetic approaches to explore the role of neuroimmune signaling in WM in the initiation and progression of this disorder. Our outcome parameters will include state-of-the-art neuroimaging modalities such as multiparametric MRI and 2-photon imaging to longitudinally track WM injury and positron emission tomography (PET) with a novel microglia-targeted radioligand to assess for potential as a scalable biomarker.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Specific genetic disorders that cause craniofacial birth defects have been shown to be caused by mutations in the TWIST1 and TWIST2 genes, which contain the information for DNA-binding proteins that regulate target genes. The molecular mechanisms for the dysfunction of these mutant TWIST2 proteins are not well understood. This project will contribute to the understanding of how the DNA binding properties are affected in TWIST1/2 mutant proteins and help in the identification of gene targets of these transcription factors, the cellular pathways in which they participate and their role in development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT  Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm (ATAA) is a major cardiovascular health problem characterized by a dilated aorta that may eventually dissect or rupture (fail). An accurate assessment of ATAA failure risk is a major clinical need. This project will use experimental biomechanics, computer modeling, and real and virtual patient imaging data to better assess ATAA failure risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Approximately 15 million people in the United States are at risk for developing cirrhosis, liver failure, hepatocellular carcinoma and death due to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), while there are less than 10,000 liver transplants performed annually in the United States. We are developing a novel stem cell and bioengineering-based platform where we will investigate two key factors in NASH, the effects of matrix stiffness and cell stress from unfolded proteins on induced pluripotent stem cell-hepatocytes (iPSC-hepatocytes). We will then make iPSC-hepatocytes from NASH patients listed for liver transplantation and controls to help develop platforms to study the causes of severe, progressive NASH and enable the development of biomarkers for NASH.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adult stem cells exist in a dynamic microenvironment termed the niche, which provides signals for stem cell maintenance and self-renewal. In the Drosophila testis, I have observed a novel phenotype, niche cell hypertrophy, upon knockdown of an endocytic tumor suppressor gene. A further understanding of this crosstalk between stem cells and their niches is crucial for understanding processes such as gametogenesis, cancer, development, and regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The obligate intracellular bacterial pathogen Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of human Q fever. We propose to elucidate the molecular mechanisms behind Coxiella’s ability to survive in the acidic intracellular niche, the Coxiella Containing Vacuole (CCV). Understanding how C. burnetii initiates replication under acid stress and actively regulates CCV pH to maintain viability is critical to identify new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Macrophages are increasingly used to transport nanoparticles to inflamed tissues for medical imaging and drug delivery. However, the effect of combining nanoparticles on macrophage phenotypes is poorly understood. The goal of this MIRA is to create a set of design rules that will allow researchers to select nanoparticle designs that give rise to specific cellular phenotypes and transport behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is the leading cause of death among Latinos in the US, who now represent the largest minority group. Latino cancer patients engage in advance care planning less often and receive less value-consistent care at the end-of-life more often than non-Latino cancer patients. The proposed research addresses the pressing need to reduce Latino EoL care disparities by developing an intervention for improving the therapeutic alliance between oncologists and their Latino cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The process by which stem cells differentiate into parietal cells in the stomach lining is poorly understood, yet it underlies a variety of human health conditions, including Helicobacter pylori infection, peptic ulcers, gastroesophageal reflux disease, autoimmune gastritis, chronic atrophic gastritis, pyloric metaplasia, and gastric cancers. We aim to characterize the molecular and cellular steps involved in this differentiation process, define how ERRγ and other factors are critical for healthy parietal cell function, and establish utility for those factors in therapeutic approaches that could be developed for the treatment of conditions related to abnormal parietal cell abundance and activity.

PHR: Proposed studies will identify novel genetic loci that determine stroke vulnerability in mice. PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE  Age is the most important risk factor for developing Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, but the mechanisms and development of successful treatments remain elusive. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Monoamine neurotransmitters such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin play essential roles in the nervous system by fine tuning learning and behavior, and malfunction of monoamine neurotransmission has been implicated in numerous neuropsychiatric diseases (depression, anxiety, substance use, and Parkinson’s disease). We will develop new imaging probes and methods to enable detailed readouts of neurotransmission processes on a synaptic level and advance neurobiology and neuropharmacology.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the urinary bladder fills with urine, sensory nerves send signals to the brain to indicate its level of fullness. However, the mechanisms used to detect the level of urine in the bladder are poorly understood. Our overall goal in this project is to understand how the bladder senses fullness, as this is a key issue to understanding normal bladder function and will provide new insights into bladder pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Lay Summary This project aims to use blood-based sequencing and imaging to help guide the use of immune checkpoint inhibitors for patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The proposed studies will develop new algorithms to apply blood-based tumor sequencing and novel radiomic image analyses to predict which patients are likely to respond to immune checkpoint inhibitors alone or with chemotherapy, and to help determine whether a patient is responding to therapy. The new compound blood-imaging biomarkers will address unmet clinical needs in thoracic oncology by helping guide therapeutic decision making without requiring invasive biopsies, ushering in a new era of non-invasive precision immunooncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chemokines play important roles in immune cell trafficking between and within tissues. Current immunotherapies have exposed ‘blind spots’ when it comes to understanding how effector T cells access and position themselves within inflamed tissues. The goal is to gain new knowledge of chemokine receptor requirements for CD4 T cell function in inflamed tissues that inform the design of stage-specific therapeutics for tissue entry, exploration, positioning at infection foci and eventual resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative RNA polymerase III (Pol III) transcribes transfer RNA (tRNA) genes essential for protein synthesis and cell growth and thus has increased activity in cancer. However, regulation of Pol III remains poorly understood in mammalian cells and cancers. This proposal studies how cell permeable hormones including progesterone and retinoic acid activate their cognate nuclear receptor transcription factors to directly regulate Pol III and alter the tRNA pool in breast cancer cells. This work will define an additional layer of coordinated nuclear receptor gene regulation that contributes to the frequent non-linear translation of messenger RNAs into protein that impacts cell growth, stemness, and cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Regenerative Rehabilitation is the integration of principles and approaches across the fields of rehabilitation science and regenerative medicine. The integration of these two fields will increase the efficiency of interventions designed to optimize physical functioning to the benefit of a wide range of individuals with disabilities. The Alliance for Regenerative Rehabilitation Research & Training (AR3T) 2.0 will build on the momentum gained over the first cycle of funding with the goal of continuing to illuminate and seize opportunities to expand scientific knowledge, expertise and methodologies in the domain of Regenerative Rehabilitation.

PHR: Project narrative This project uses rich multi-modal (clinical, neuroimaging, and genetic) data to develop a novel integrative modeling framework to provide statistically-principled inference, accurate personalized prediction of disease progression, and dynamic prediction update, based on new subject-specific data. This project not only facilitates the discovery and evaluation of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) variables for disease progression, but also is highly relevant for optimizing AD clinical trial design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Human gut microbiome may significantly modulate human cardiovascular health through producing and releasing lipopolysaccharide (LPS) into human circulation, although epidemiological studies of coronary heart disease (CHD) surrounding LPS exposures are limited. The proposed research aims to narrow significant knowledge gaps by evaluating prospective associations of LPS exposures with CHD incidence and how diet, lifestyle, and human microbiome may contribute to the LPS exposures in well-characterized cohort studies of free-living individuals. Data from this research will help form individualized strategies facilitating CHD prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: CHARLES R. DREW UNIVERSITY OF MED & SCI
PHR: Although is substance use disorders are a health disparity that occurs more commonly in minority and low-income populations, underrepresented minority researchers and researchers from disadvantaged backgrounds are less like to go into research in this field and apply for funding from NIDA. This R25 grant, entitled “Next Generation Substance Abuse Disorders Research Training at Charles R. Drew University (CDU) and UCLA (NGSART-CU; to be known as SART) builds on 15 years of the NIDA funded DIDARP/MIDARP programs (PI: Friedman) in which 125 mostly minority students received a meaningful research experience in substance use disorder fields along with training and mentorship. This grant proposes to provide research opportunities and courses for skill development and mentorship primarily to undergraduates, post- baccalaureate and masters students (early-stage) and post-doctoral fellows with the goal of training the next generation of substance use disorder researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The literature is characterized by a dearth of information on how to reduce risk for suicide among marginalized substance using youth experiencing homelessness (YEH). Suicide is the leading cause of death among YEH and most youth do not access services that may be available to them. Therefore, this study seeks to address this gap in the research literature with the goal to identify an effective intervention that can be readily adopted by communities that serve these youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The sense of smell contributes significantly to our quality of life, and the loss of smell (anosmia) - as evidenced by the widespread anosmia associated with Covid-19- can not only be dangerous but typically has profound effects on psychological and emotional well-being. This research seeks to understand how the sense of smell is processed in the brain, including probing poorly understood neural mechanisms that support odor discrimination, odor recognition, and odor memories. Moreover, deficits in odor recognition and odor memory are associated with neurodegenerative diseases, such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, and understanding how these processes work in the healthy brain can provide important insights into how they go wrong in the diseased brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chromosomal aberrations are essential biomarkers used to guide treatment decisions for acute myeloid leukemia patients. In this proposal we describe the use of a comprehensive method to assay chromosome aberrations at high resolution and use this information to more accurately predict the severity of disease. This information will potentially be helpful guiding decision making when making treatment decisions for patients poorly stratified by current methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: This project investigates genetic mechanisms that regulate hearing recovery after noise exposure in mice and humans. We focus on a transcription factor, FOXO3, that is crucial for outer hair cell survival and is implicated in human occupational hearing loss. Our goals are to discover how and where FOXO3 acts in the cochlea, using gain and loss of function methods, translatome sequencing, cell-specific knockouts, and by creating a novel mouse model for human hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Two-thirds of Alzheimer's disease (AD) cases are female, and females with AD present at autopsy with more plaques and tangles than males of a comparable age. The goal of this project is to identify sex-specific genetic drivers of AD neuropathology and cognitive impairment. The identification of such genetic markers will facilitate the development of personalized interventions that are tailored to the sex and neuropathology of the individual.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A top TB control priority set by the World Health Organization is to “find the missing 3 million”- those 3 million individuals developing infectious TB each year but who are never diagnosed as having TB. Active TB case finding can reduce TB incidence by finding infectious cases before they present for care on their own, but is not widely adopted. We intend to inform the implementation and scale-up of an incentive-based strategy to identify TB from among close contacts of newly diagnosed cases; we will evaluate barriers to implementation, feasibility, acceptability and preliminary measures of effectiveness (yield).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This aim of this dissertation proposal is to investigate the effect of motor learning practice schedule on the acquisition, retention, and generalization of protective balance responses in individuals with Parkinson’s Disease. Positive findings will provide support for the development of balance rehabilitation protocols based on motor learning principles to mitigate falls in individuals with PD compared to age-matched controls. Since two- thirds of individuals with PD fall yearly, results of this research will have a broad impact on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE In the U.S. two-thirds of young adults (18-24 years) pursue college, during which they adopt poor lifestyle behaviors which track into older age and contribute to cardiometabolic diseases (CMD). Sedentary behavior, particularly sitting, has been recognized by national and international agencies as a novel yet major risk factor, but one we know little about its effect on cardiometabolic diseases. Our overarching aim is to develop an evidence-based, multi-level intervention to reduce sedentary behavior and target the primary prevention of CMD in college-based young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic diseases like obesity, diabetes, and metabolic syndrome, are thought to be heavily influenced by the composition of the microbiota and the over-accumulation ceramides, which are known to cause insulin resistance and fatty liver disease. We have identified a community of bacteria that improve metabolic health and decrease the ceramide pathway. The goal of this project is to understand which bacteria contribute to metabolic protection and decipher the unknown relationship between the microbiota and ceramides, which we believe will lead to novel therapeutics for the treatment of metabolic diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative The disruption of spatial navigation and decision-making contributes to many neurological disorders, including Alzheimer’s disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perianal fistulae are a complication of Crohn’s disease with poor treatment response that affects patients of African ancestry more frequently and with greater morbidity. These studies will explore differences in protein and gene expression between African and European ancestry patients with perianal fistula at the single cell level, and establish an in vitro rectal organoid model to characterize the lipid and cytokine mediators that contribute to fistula inception. The combination of these approaches will better define gene modules that distinguish perianal fistulizing Crohn’s disease between ancestry groups and inform the discovery of novel targets for the treatment of perianal fistula.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many neurological and psychiatric disorders are caused by mutations in splicing regulators or their targets in alternative splicing. However, we are unable to treat many of these diseases due to a lack of understanding of how these regulators shape the neuronal alternative splicing network. This project will provide one of the first integrated biochemical and genome-wide studies of a multi-subunit complex of splicing regulators found in the brain and can advance our understanding of the gene regulatory circuit underlying neurological and psychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Access to comprehensive pediatric sickle cell care continues to be a national concern, and is even a more pressing issue in rural and medically underserved areas. As telemedicine has been shown to be an effective means of providing care to pediatric populations living in rural and underserved areas, we propose to directly address barriers identified in previous work to the provision of comprehensive sickle cell care by adapting, refining, and piloting two telemedicine models (i.e., hub and spoke model and direct-to-consumer model). This research will not only expand access to comprehensive care for children with sickle cell disease, but our approach will help identify which telemedicine model is most appropriate for various environments, and we can easily adapt this approach for other subspecialty populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the human population shifts to a higher proportion of aged and geriatric individuals, it is critical that we develop interventional methods to maintain human health and to systemically treat age-related disease. Modifications of diversity in the human intestinal microbiome have been associated with chronic diseases including obesity, frailty, and cardiac dysfunction. Marmosets offer a unique model in which to evaluate the relationship between microbial diversity and age-related health changes, as well as to evaluate the efficacy of fecal microbiota transplant as an interventional treatment for aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a highly fatal cancer accounting for over 780,000 deaths annually, and while men have consistently higher HCC risk and worse survival compared to women, we do not have an adequate understanding of why this disparity exists. We will apply a conceptual framework to three large multi- center patient cohorts to identify specific sex- (i.e. biologic) and gender-related (i.e. social, behavioral) factors that influence disparities in HCC incidence and prognosis. This proposal will yield critical data to inform future interventions to reduce disparities and improve survival for both men and women with HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to develop sensors that will provide mechanistic insight into how non-neuronal cells, astrocytes, communicate in the brain in a region- and circuit-specific manner. This layer of information about functional astrocyte heterogeneity will contribute to the field by providing quantitative metrics to assess diversity. The new knowledge of how astrocytes communicate in the brain generated by our sensors can potentially lead to paradigm-shifting therapeutic approaches to neurological and developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Corneal transplantation is the most commonly performed type of solid organ transplantation in the world and T cell-mediated alloimmune rejection is the most common cause of corneal transplant failure. We have recently demonstrated fibrosis in rejected corneal transplants, and in the proposed research we will investigate the interactions between T cell alloimmunity and fibrosis in corneal transplantation. These studies will provide fundamental insights in a previously unexplored area and have the potential to help identify novel therapeutic strategies for i) preventing transplant fibrosis and failure and ii) regulating T cell-mediated immune rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative CD4+ T cell help is required for optimal effector CD8+ T cell function; however, therapies that enlist CD4+ T cells for cancer immunotherapy are lacking. I discovered that intratumor activation of childhood vaccine CD4+ T cell recall responses inflame the tumor microenvironment and mediate antitumor efficacy. This work will define inflammatory reprogramming, CD8+ T cell potentiating, and `helper' functions induced by CD4+ T cell recall within tumors to leverage CD4+ T cells for cancer immunotherapy.

PHR: NARRATIVE Climate change is expected to have important negative consequences for the health and living standards of vulnerable populations in low and middle-income countries, but to date there are few population-based strategies that have been documented to help protect against these exposures. We will use data from randomized controlled trials of cash transfers to poor households in Zambia and Kenya to test whether these additional resources can protect food security, child health and youth lifecourse transitions during periods of adverse climate conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE While historically infections have been attributed to individual pathogens, polymicrobial communities are now known to be common in human disease and can be composed of multiples species of bacterial, viral, and fungal origin. Interactions between differing microbial species can profoundly alter the course of human disease; however, how bacteria sense signals from other bacterial species, the nature of these signals, and how signaling contributes to community behaviors necessary for human infection are unknown. This proposal seeks to answer these questions by integrating genetic approaches with state-of-the-art live-imaging of bacterial behaviors during mixed species cultivations and 3D imaging of bacterial communities in the lungs and respiratory secretions of patients with polymicrobial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although NMD is the only RNA regulatory pathway that has been linked to numerous mental illnesses, a comprehensive model of how cell-specific NMD influences synaptic and cognitive function remains elusive. Astrocyte dysfunction has been implicated in the pathophysiology of numerous neurological disorders, with a strong impact on synaptic plasticity and behavior. This research proposal is designed to elucidate the astrocytic mechanisms that regulate synaptic plasticity through mRNA degradation, and will illuminate an important molecular mechanism with likely relevance to a broad range of neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TRPV6 and TRPV5 are Ca2+ selective epithelial ion channels. Loss of function mutations in these channels are associated with chronic pancreatitis and kidney stones. This project studies the regulation of these channel by endogenous calmodulin and phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate, and take advantage of our molecular level understanding of their regulation to identify small molecules that increase channel activity, which could be potentially used to treat pancreatitis and kidney stones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Poor neurodevelopmental outcomes remain stubbornly prevalent after pediatric critical illness despite medical and surgical advances that have produced improved survival for conditions such as stroke, congenital heart disease, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, and extreme prematurity. To develop effective interventions, a bedside neuroimaging system capable of timely detection of injury during longitudinal monitoring is needed, and optical neuroimaging of the brain’s resting-state holds potential to fill this role. In this application, I propose to develop statistical methods and biomarkers of neurologic injury applicable to bedside translation using mouse models of acute and chronic hypoxemia and optical intrinsic signal imaging of resting-state hemodynamics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The transcription factor ZFP24, which is regulated by phosphorylation, binds to the genome in proximity to genes that are crucial for oligodendrocyte differentiation and CNS myelination and this binding activates gene expression. We propose here to identify the kinases and phosphatases that control ZFP24 phosphorylation, to characterize ZFP24 phosphorylation intermediates in oligodendrocyte lineage cells, and to determine the role of ZFP24 in adulthood. These studies have the potential to identify therapeutic strategies to enhance myelination and remyelination through the modulation of ZFP24 kinase activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome-wide association studies of human disease provide a powerful opportunity to uncover novel etiologies and inform rational drug targets which would otherwise be overlooked. The goal of this project is to elucidate the mechanism whereby a genetic variant in CD33 protects individuals from Alzheimer’s Disease, which may provide a breakthrough in this devastating disease with no effective treatment options and improve the quality of life for millions of patients. This project will provide exceptional training to an underrepresented and highly motivated doctoral candidate, facilitating his transition to postdoctoral studies and launching his promising career as an independent neuroscience researcher.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 37% of conceptions fail to advance beyond 20 weeks of gestation because the embryo fails to implant into the uterus. This project tests a new idea that alternative mRNA splicing mediated by sex-steroid hormones is critical for normal function of the uterus. This project will identify novel transcript variants that are associated with uterine function and may lead, in the long term, to new strategies to diagnose or prevent early pregnancy loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Sleep disorders are associated with cognitive dysfunction, mood disorders and mental illness. Some sleep problems may be caused by abnormalities in `sleep homeostasis; a process that increases the need for sleep. The cellular mechanisms governing sleep homeostasis are unknown, but may involve glial astrocytes. Identifying the role of these cells in sleep will provide new insights into the cellular basis of sleepiness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The environmental health problems faced by the nation are multi-factorial in nature, and therefore require multi-disciplinary approaches for effective intervention. Our training program emphasizes the importance of multidisciplinary training and translation of basic science findings to obtain rigorous, reproducible and transparent results that benefit the patient and/or community. This multi-disciplinary translational program interfaces with the NIH Roadmap and the NIEHS strategic plan.
PROJECT_TERMS: Environmental Health;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: UOFL ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES TRAINING PROGRAM

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Genomics is a major driving force for modern biomedical research. Given the recent advances in genomic technologies and electronic health records, analysis and interpretation are the biggest bottlenecks to understanding the basis of human variation and disease. This training program will produce a diverse generation of computational genomicists with the statistics, computer science, bioinformatics, molecular biology, and genetics skills necessary to turn this flood of data into biomedical knowledge that can advance the understanding, diagnosis, and treatment of disease.
PROJECT_TERMS: Genomics;Grant;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Grant in Genomic Analysis and Interpretation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuroblastoma is a fast-growing cancer that affects infants and children. Our work is designed to exploit an important new Achilles’ heel of this disease. Because drugs that exploit a specific weakness of cancer are less toxic than standard chemotherapy, our research may help deliver therapies that are more effective and less toxic than current approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple-negative breast cancers (TNBCs) are highly aggressive, metastatic and recurrent. The standard chemotherapies and radiotherapies have marginal curative benefits but there is no efficacious targeted therapy. This project will develop and fully evaluate a new strategy, i.e. the combined dual-targeted mitochondrial luminoptogenetic gene therapy and synthetic lethality of poly (ADP-Ribose) polymerase inhibitor, to eliminate the metastatic and heterogeneous TNBCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Our proposal for training in biomedical informatics and data science at Stanford harnesses the opportunity to produce the next generation of researchers who will enable precision medicine through innovations in translational bioinformatics, health care informatics and clinical research informatics. We have a 39-year track record of producing bioinformatics leaders who pursue research-driven careers in academia and industry. We remain well-positioned to advance human health through future training in biomedical informatics and data science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer research is dependent on the availability of high quality biospecimens linked to patient information from clinical trials. The SWOG Biospecimen Bank collects, processes, banks and distributes biospecimens from adult cancer patients enrolled on NCI-sponsored clinical trials. These biospecimens are eventually used by researchers to study different types of cancer. The results of this research benefits patients through discovery of targeted therapy and/or improved outcomes and survival with the ultimate goal of cancer prevention and cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to combine an innovative machine learning algorithm with synthetic biology approaches to design new proteins that can read and write information from and into cells in vivo and consequently, to improve communication with synthetic biological circuits that precisely control diagnostic and therapeutic agents. Such technology is likely to move the needle towards the next generation of treatment strategies for devastating diseases which currently have a profound negative impact on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The area of developmental neuroscience and psychopathology has already demonstrated great potential to inform the understanding of the causal pathways and mechanisms of mental illness. This training grant renewal seeks to continue to develop new research scientists in this area, building on the track record of success over the last two cycles. The division of Child Psychiatry at Washington University School of Medicine is well poised to continue and expand this unique post-doctoral training program based on established expertise in a range of child neuroimaging modalities, genetics, gut microbiome, and sleep/circadian rhythms offered by the multidisciplinary mentoring group. The program is directed by two researchers with complimentary expertise in developmental psychopathology (Dr. Joan Luby) and clinical neuroscience and neuroimaging (Dr. Deanna Barch) who have successfully collaborated on the first two cycles of funding, launching numerous young scientists in this domain.
PROJECT_TERMS: Child;Development;Neurosciences;Psychopathology
PROJECT_TITLE: Developmental Neuroscience and Child Psychopathology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several G-protein-coupled receptors use the common diffusible second messenger, cAMP, in the same cell, and yet elicit vastly different functional responses. The prerequisite for achieving such divergent functions is believed to be due to segregation of cAMP into separate compartments such that the cAMP can only access a select subset of target proteins that are involved in mediating the responses specific to the stimulated receptor. The main objective of this proposal is to unravel the role of confined spaces associated with mitochondria in mediating compartmentation of cAMP, with the ultimate goal of providing a therapeutic strategy for managing cardiovascular diseases linked to dysregulation of cAMP compartmentalization, including cardiac arrhythmias, hypertrophy, and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young adults in the U.S. (ages 18-24) have the highest and fastest growing rates of suicidal thoughts and behaviors, but the lowest rates of mental health care. This project aims to design and pilot an automated interactive safety planning service delivered via SMS that yields highly personalized safety plans and supports use over time. By accomplishing the proposed training goals and research project, this project will generate data to support an efficacy trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL Sanford Burnham Prebys Medical Discovery Institute (SBP) is an independent nonprofit research and graduate degree-granting institution located in La Jolla, CA, that conducts laboratory-based biomedical research. The SBP Cancer Center's vision is to make paradigm-shifting discoveries that will underlie novel therapeutic modalities by creating, translating, and disseminating exceptional cancer basic science. This will be achieved by conducting cutting-edge, multidisciplinary basic research, advancing our discoveries into early pre-clinical development, and educating and training the next generation of cancer scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The efficient assessment of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) is a significant impending public health challenge. The proposed project aims to study digital biomarkers from large language models as a novel methodology and to apply them to quantify MDD and GAD symptoms. The project aims to increase our understanding of depression and anxiety by examining and preliminarily validating computational linguistic features, and will result in an improved empirical framework and associated digital tools to move psychiatric assessment of MDD and GAD from subjective ratings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the nature of stimulus representation in visual cortex has been heavily studied, relatively little attention has been given to the impact of active task engagement on stimulus-driven visual responses. Using a multidisciplinary approach combining cutting-edge methodological development, extensive high-field (7T) fMRI measurements, theory-driven experimental design, and computational modeling, this project aims to develop formal models characterizing how engagement in different perceptual and cognitive tasks modulates visually- driven responses. Completion of this work will yield reusable methods, data resources, and models of visual information processing. Progress in identifying the computational mechanisms underlying visual perception in healthy individuals is a critical step for understanding the nature of sensory disorders such as prosopagnosia and dyslexia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A new platform is envisioned that combines two existing technologies to produce a low cost, simple to use, handheld device that can screen patients for high-risk oral cancer, image the location of the cancer, and treat it using this same device at point of care. It includes testing therapeutic efficacy both pre-clinically and clinically in patients, along with identification of an easy-to-use topical application of the therapeutic agent well suited for low-income settings. The impact of these studies could be substantial in the low-income settings such as rural areas and can avoid deaths in the regions where oral cancer is highly prevalent in India as well as other countries including regions of the U.S.A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease outcomes are aggravated in patients presenting with concurrent atherosclerosis and diabetes, although the mechanisms responsible are not fully understood. Here we will study how an axis involving the TFEB gene and its target, GPNMB, can restore the function of the endothelium, the internal layer of the blood vessels, in models of atherosclerosis associated with diabetes. We will use a novel pharmacologic strategy that allows the production, by the body itself, of a potent anti-inflammatory molecule, NO2-CLA (pronounced, nitro-CLA) starting from dietary supplements to activate TFEB and increase GPNMB and reduce atherosclerosis associated with diabetes, which could change current clinical paradigms for the treatment of cardiometabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Many metastases of breast cancer may further disseminate to seed more metastases, but the pre-clinical models, the underlying mechanisms, and the potential therapeutic targets are all lacking. Herein, based on several lines of preliminary evidence, we propose to test the hypothesis that the bone microenvironment invigorates metastatic seeds for further dissemination. Specifically, we will focus on delineation of temporal course of metastatic seeding from bone to other organs, and identification of druggable pathways driving this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Breast cancer brain metastasis is observed in up to 50% of HER2-positive breast cancer patients and patients survive less than 2 years following CNS involvement. CAR T cells are a promising new treatment but typically results in poor responses against solid tumors. This proposal seeks to apply thermal targeting by Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound to increase anti-HER2 CAR T cell delivery and potentiate therapy against breast cancer brain metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Dysregulation of feeding results in obesity or in malnutrition and the various morbidities associated with these conditions. Therefore, to better tackle the challenges of obesity and malnutrition, we must better understand the neural mechanisms that modulate feeding. Further, because insect-born diseases are a major human health challenge and insect agricultural pests are key contributors to human malnutrition, the studies presented here will contribute to better understanding of the control of insect feeding and may therefore have a major impact on global human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative IgE antibodies are significant contributors to the pathogenesis of allergic diseases. Repetitive exposure to particular antigens induces the production of specific IgE antibodies in susceptible individuals, yet the underlying mechanisms are unclear. In this project, we will study the mechanisms that regulate the generation and fate of IgE-producing cells upon repetitive antigen exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Oxidative stress can be an overwhelming force in the microbial world. Sensitivity to oxygen restricts the environments in which many microbes can live, and reactive oxygen species serve as weapons by which hosts, competitors, and redox-active drugs attack them. By revealing the molecular details of this stress, we will be able to understand the variability in oxidant tolerance among species, and we will become cognizant of the important situations in which oxidative stress plays a decisive role in microbial fate.

PHR: NARRATIVE This project will identify clinical, psychosocial, and genetic elements of epilepsy in Mali, with the goal of utilizing the data to improve care and quality of life for people with epilepsy in Mali, sub-Saharan Africa, and even more broadly. It will also build scientific expertise and infrastructures to further the study of epilepsy and other diseases by African scientists in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) experience seizures, although these events are commonly non-convulsive in nature and thus potentially missed. Despite this, little is known regarding the direct long-term impact of untreated seizures on disease progression in patients with AD. This study will directly define whether chronic seizures age-dependently aggravate neuropsychiatric comorbidities of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In individuals with HIV infection, chronic inflammation is present even with undetectable viral loads, and such persons often present with co-morbidities associated with older age, including bone loss, cancers, stroke, cardiovascular disease, and dementia. In this application, we propose to test the hypothesis that gamma delta T cells, a unique ‘innate-like’ T cell subset, exhibit hyper-inflammatory activity in the gastrointestinal tract of aviremic HIV+ individuals and uninfected older subjects, and this aberrant activation directly causes increased permeability of intestinal epithelium, leading to movement of GI microbial products and inflammatory gamma delta T cells into the circulation, which spurs and propagates systemic inflammation. Identification of the mechanisms driving increased intestinal permeability with aviremic HIV infection and normal aging is critical to develop novel therapeutic strategies to abrogate and/or prevent age-associated co-morbidities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This work will test the novel hypothesis that epigenetic changes regulating pluripotency and differentiation of male germ cells occur in association with the inner nuclear membrane (INM) and are facilitated by cell cycle arrest and by the RNA binding protein (RBP) Dead End 1 (DND1). We have shown that DND1 binds multiple epigenetic regulators, and we hypothesize that it controls their transcript levels and gates their translation during cell cycle arrest. Integrating RBP-mediated epigenetic reprogramming and cell cycle regulation into a unifying theoretical concept would establish a new paradigm and provide insights into the process of male gametogenesis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: Project Narrative The Center for Smart use of Technologies for Assessment of Real-world Outcomes (C-STAR) addresses a pressing need within the rehabilitation research community for appropriate, accurate, and clinically meaningful use of available technologies—including sensors, mobile phones, smart-watches, and robots—to assess disease progression, treatment response or compliance, and patient-centered outcomes in real-world settings, e.g., the home, work/school, and community. We will support studies, mentored collaborations, and didactic interactions that promote use of technologies for assessment in the laboratory, clinic, and community. Our four Cores—Engineering, Clinical, Outcomes, and Implementation Science/Community Engagement—will provide expertise to (i) standardize use of such technologies, (ii) customize, validate, and calibrate technologies, and (iii) interpret collected data in the context of the needs and abilities of specific patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung squamous cell carcinoma (LUSC) is a major form of lung cancer with poor prognosis and limited treatment options. This project will: 1) assess the efficacy of novel drug combination strategies that target three cancer-causing genetic drivers of LUSC; and 2) characterize tumor initiation and progression in a new pre- clinical mouse model of LUSC. These studies will facilitate development of new therapies to improve treatment of LUSC and identify biomarkers to predict LUSC progression and response to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of type 2 diabetes and its severe complications have been rising in the U.S. and globally. The goal of this research is to determine the effects of exposure to the widely used per- and poly-fluoroalkyl substances and other environmental chemicals on developing type 2 diabetes in multi-ethnic adult populations, using novel metabolomic and genomic approaches. Findings will inform precision medicine approaches for the prevention and treatment of type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Homeostasis relies on precise and dynamic action by nuclear pathways including RNA transcription, DNA repair, and genome organization. While cooperative interactions between proteins and cofactors helps ensure selectivity, the events mediating the rapid action are less well understood. We believe molecular chaperones, especially the Hsp90 system, foster a highly dynamic nuclear environment that is critical for timely and effective DNA-associated pathways.

PROJECT_TITLE: Regulation of the Native Protein Landscape in the Nucleus by Molecular Chaperones

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When inhaled at high concentrations, carbon monoxide causes cardiac and neurocognitive deficits and death; however, when produced at low concentrations in tissue, carbon monoxide acts as an intracellular signal and has even been tested as a therapeutic agent. In this proposal, we aim to develop a microbial carbon monoxide sensor, RcoM, into (1) a fast-acting carbon monoxide scavenger that can serve as an antidote for carbon monoxide poisoning and (2) a sensitive detector of carbon monoxide in living cells. Development of these molecular therapeutics and tools will dramatically improve the current standard of care for carbon monoxide poisoning and advance our understanding of intracellular carbon monoxide signaling and toxicology, with the potential to substantially decrease death and disability caused by this common poisoning.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To optimally support child health and development, research needs to be designed to account for the scale of disease burden and child mortality and shifts that occurs worldwide. The Pediatric Subspecialty Global Health Research T32 training program will capitalize on the significant resources that currently exist across the campus of Stanford University to provide dual fellowship training in a pediatric subspecialty combined with research focused on global child health, as well as completion of a Masters in Epidemiology and Clinical Research. This comprehensive program will train a new generation of pediatric subspecialty global health scientists equipped to advance the research agenda outlined in the NICHD Scientific Vision, including studies of the developmental origins of health and disease, pregnancy outcomes, behavior and cognition, and population dynamics at the global level.
PROJECT_TERMS: Childhood;Fellowship;global health
PROJECT_TITLE: Pediatric Global Health Subspecialty Fellowship

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Immunotherapy for the treatment of cancer relies on the activity of specialized white blood cells called cytotoxic (or “killer”) T cells which are capable of eliminating tumors, provided they recognize specific targets on the tumor cell surface. Identifying these tumor-specific targets in cancer patients will allow for the design and administration of personalized immunotherapies with the potential to benefit or even cure these patients. The major goal of this grant proposal is to use specialize methodologies to identify novel and unconventional immunotherapeutic targets for melanoma, thus enabling the development of effective immunotherapeutic treatments for patients with these and other cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE STING is a cellular signaling protein crucial to generating innate and adaptive immune responses against microbe-infected cells that can elicit beneficial vaccine outcomes when activated by adjuvants. We propose to use animal and in vitro models to characterize the molecular and immunological effects of a novel vaccine platform that incorporates virus-like particles containing internalized STING-inducing molecules. Results we generate will have a transformative impact on vaccine technology and our understanding of the biological role of STING and its immunotherapeutic potential as a pharmacologic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is an invasive and rapidly progressive malignancy that remains highly lethal despite recent therapeutic advances. There is an urgent and unmet clinical need for more reliable and accurate imaging tools to optimize delineation of the tumor and non-invasive evaluation of response to neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy. The purpose of this study is to develop an image-guided paradigm using a novel collagen specific PET imaging probe to address these needs with the ultimate goal of improved management and clinical care of PDAC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative When the concentration of -aminobutyric acid (GABA) diminishes in the brain, convulsions can occur and neuropathic pains can prevail. Inhibition of GABA aminotransferase raises GABA levels and can terminate convulsions and ease neuropathic pain. We propose to design, synthesize, study inactivation mechanisms, and evaluate in vitro and in vivo new compounds to inactivate GABA aminotransferase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A fundamental challenge in physical medicine and rehabilitation has long been measuring muscle force and stiffness, yet there are no rigorous methods for doing so noninvasively. Ultrasound elastography is a promising tool but it remains unclear precisely what this tool measures when applied to muscle. The objectives of this proposal are to determine how elastography is sensitive to changes in muscle force and stiffness during conditions encountered in everyday activities, and to test a novel approach for uniquely determining these two important quantities from ultrasound measurements.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will compare the efficacy of a parent-only treatment for children with both autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and overweight or obesity (OW/OB) compared to a health education active comparator. Information from this study could advance the standard of practice for children with ASD, and will provide a tailored intervention for children with ASD and OW/OB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Advances in computational and experimental protein engineering have ushered in a new era of biomolecule development with both fundamental and applied aims, but current approaches lack the ability to develop and study synthetic receptors and inhibitory molecules in high throughput. We propose to develop protein engineering platforms for robust inhibitor development, for studying synthetic receptors, and for a combined computational and experimental pipeline to engineer and study natural molecules. Once developed, these platforms will be applied to study fundamental questions in cell signaling, in development of disease pathologies, and in biomolecular sequence-function and structure-function relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE The diagnosis and treatment of cancer begins with discovering the ways cancer cells differ from normal cells, and how those differences allow cancer cells to grow and spread around the body. Glycoproteins called mucins vary widely in abundance and composition between cancer and normal cells. In this project we will develop tools to characterize the molecular structures of cancer mucins and study why they change in cancer, with an eye toward developing new diagnostic and therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Microscopic colitis is an inflammatory disorder of the gastrointestinal tract and a common cause of chronic diarrhea and fecal incontinence in older adults. The goals of this proposal are to identify pharmacologic determinants of microscopic colitis, to characterize the composition and function of the gut microbiota with disease activity, and to examine the interplay between pharmacologic risk factors and the gut microbiota in relation to risk of microscopic colitis. The public health benefits of the study findings include informing clinical guidelines for management of microscopic colitis and providing in-depth examination of how commonly prescribed medications in interaction with the gut microbiota may predispose older adults to gut inflammation.
