IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Genomics Core of the MSK SPORE in Leukemia brings together unique expertise in computational biology and modeling of genomic data to support generation, analyses, and interpretation of data generated in the research projects of the Leukemia SPORE. Our major aims are to deliver mechanistic insights into the biology, disease progression, and treatment response of AML. Our vision is to deliver data-driven and evidence-based research that will guide development of diagnostic biomarkers, disease surveillance tools, and, importantly, biologically-informed therapeutic interventions to include target identification, target validation, and preclinical model development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The identification of IDH1/IDH2 mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) led to the development and approval of the first small molecule IDH1 (ivosidenib) and IDH2 (enasidenib) inhibitors for IDH1/2 mutant AML; however not all patients respond to IDH1/2 inhibition. We will use preclinical studies and analysis of primary samples from patients treated with IDH1/2 inhibitors to delineate molecular predictors of sensitivity and resistance to IDH inhibitors, and test novel combination therapeutic approaches to increase therapeutic efficacy in IDH1/2-mutant AML. The goal is to use this insight to test new therapeutic approaches in mechanism-based clinical trials aimed to improve outcomes in this molecularly defined AML subset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Approximately 10% of cases of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) have a complex karyotype (CK), meaning that the cancer displays 3 or more chromosomal abnormalities. These CK-AML patients face a dismal prognosis, as there are no effective treatment options. In this project, innovative genetic and modeling approaches will be used to better characterize human AML and to discover and validate targets for much-needed, novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We recently found that inhibiting enzymes called protein arginine methyltranserases (PRMTs) may be an effective treatment for leukemia. We propose to examine how patients treated with PRMT inhibitors respond at the molecular level, and to identify predictors of response such as genetic mutations in cancer cells, which could help improve the efficacy of this therapy. PRMT inhibitors are now entering early phase clinical trials for other cancers and we expect this project to facilitate testing of these drugs in leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a critical need to develop therapies to eliminate leukemia-stem cells (LSCs) as a treatment for acute myeloid leukemia (AML). To this end, we have developed a novel chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell platform targeting CD371, a cell surface marker present on the vast majority of AML cells and LSCs but absent from normal hematopoietic stem cells. We will determine the safety and efficacy of CD371-targeted, IL18- secreting CAR T cells in patient-derived xenografts models and by conducting a phase I clinical trial in relapsed/refractory AML patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Lyme disease spirochete, Borrelia burgdorferi, produces a unique DNA-binding protein named Gac. Our biochemical and genetic analyses indicate that Gac regulates expression of several genes that encode proteins that are essential for mammalian infection, including the alternative sigma factors RpoN and RpoS. Our studies will define the role of Gac during B. burgdorferi infection processes, and assess the mechanism by which Gac controls transcription of RpoN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative  Precision medicine in oncology requires accurate prediction of drug response to guide personalized treatment decisions. We developed a pharmacoproteomics platform that links kinome activity in liver cancer cell lines to kinase inhibitor drug response; we will optimize our KI-Predictor in liver cancer and test its ability to select useful kinase inhibitor drugs in cell lines and organotypic slice culture models as a validation platform for predicting drug response in cancer. The combination of prediction and drug testing in a validation platform enhances the accuracy and translatability of the predictions, facilitating the advancement of precision medicine in oncology by aiding clinicians in selecting optimal treatment strategies tailored to individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exercise-based prevention and treatment strategies for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) have historically focused on the promotion of aerobic exercise. However, given the coinciding epidemics of physical inactivity and obesity in the U.S., and the compromised aerobic capacity and exercise intolerance in patients with HFpEF, long-term adherence to aerobic exercise is generally poor and thus, the prevention and treatment of HFpEF remains a major public health challenge. To help alleviate this public health burden, the proposed project will be the first to examine the isolated role of resistance exercise—a more movement-varied, non-weight-bearing exercise modality that may be better tolerated by obesity-burdened, aerobically- compromised populations—in the prevention and treatment of HFpEF, with examination of potential biological intermediates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Our rapidly increasing understanding of the power of immune effectors, combined with development of advanced genomic tools, has generated the new field of immunoengineering, with a promise to revolutionize treatments for infectious disease, autoimmune disorders, and cancer. However, application of these breakthroughs has been stymied by remaining knowledge gaps, inefficiencies, and operational barriers between immunologists, engineers, and other partners who could collaborate and innovate. Our goal in this renewal is to continue interfacing with bioengineers, immunologists, material scientists, and biomedical researchers to develop tools, techniques, and protocols that are broadly relevant to immune and inflammatory diseases; engage in new collaborations; provide training for graduate and post-graduate investigators; and maximize the potential of immunoengineering and immune-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. Our ReVAMMP Center (Flavivirus and Alphavirus ReVAMPP, FLARE) addresses the hypothesis that innovative approaches to antigen and vaccine design and monoclonal antibody screening will promote the development of platform technologies that can rapidly generate countermeasures against current and future flavivirus and alphavirus threats. With our allied industry partners, we will develop and optimize protein nanoparticle, virion- based, and mRNA vaccines, and mAb-based treatments to respond to emerging flaviviruses and alphaviruses with pandemic potential using a pathogen prototype, modular approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric hydrocephalus is a life-threatening condition that is primarily caused by in-utero and perinatal infections and intraventricular hemorrhage. The underlying molecular pathology of how neuroinflammation from infection or hemorrhage during critical developmental periods leads to hydrocephalus is poorly understood. This proposal implements single-cell transcriptomics combined with core methods for studying the choroid plexus (ChP) to uncover the role that the ChP has in mediating neuroinflammation that can be leveraged for diagnostics and therapeutics to prevent the progression of inflammatory-driven hydrocephalus.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Effective healthcare-associated infection (HAI) prevention requires multiple complex interventions across the work system. The COVID-19 pandemic also broadly impacted HAI prevention, and increases in some HAI rates have been observed during the pandemic. There is now an urgent need to assess how the implementation of HAI prevention practices was impacted in order to 1) develop strategies to support the resumption of effective practices and 2) identify practices needing future analysis to develop implementation strategies that will maximize effectiveness while minimizing provider burden. In this pilot project, we will analyze the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on HAI prevention through all work system elements (people, tasks, tools, environment, and organization). This analysis will identify practices interrupted during the pandemic with barriers and facilitators to resuming these practices. We will also use these findings to create a model for future, larger-scale implementation studies into HAI prevention during resource-constrained settings.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Lung cancer is responsible for more death in the United States than breast, prostate and colon cancer combined and is the number one cancer killer in veterans. This is because lung cancer is usually diagnosed when the disease has spread and cure is less likely. Screening for lung cancer with a scan finds cancer at an earlier stage when it is curable. Screening for lung cancer is recommended for people that are at high risk based on age and smoking history every year. Unfortunately, many people eligible for screening have not been screened and one reason is the distance needed to travel to a place offering it. The proposed study will evaluate the implementation of mobile lung cancer screening to understand facilitators and barriers and determine the impact of mobile lung cancer screening on offering, uptake and return for annual lung cancer screening.

PHR: Narrative The development of resistance to mutant KRAS inhibitors is currently a major obstacle for the treatment of KRAS mutant cancers and the underlying mechanisms are not well-understood. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will reveal a newly-identified mechanism that contributes to the efficacy of KRAS- targeted therapy, and success of this proposal will not only expand our knowledge of KRAS signaling and biology but also shed light on novel therapeutic strategies against KRAS mutated cancer to achieve durable therapeutic response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite significant clinical and research advances in the field of food allergy, many remaining questions must be addressed before global implementation of impactful therapeutic and prevention options for patients affected by food allergy can be realized. The Arkansas Center for Food Allergy Research (ArCOFAR) builds on a >30 year foundation of expertise, and leadership in food allergy and is ideally positioned to function as a Clinical Research Center within the Consortium for Food Allergy Research. We will contribute our extensive research experience and capitalize on our population’s distinct geographic and patient demographic characteristics to immediately address the overarching program goal of the Consortium for Food Allergy Research to improve the health of children and adults living with food allergy and related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will investigate how choroid plexus epithelial cells might sense and respond to changes in intracranial pressure (ICP). The results of this project will deepen our understanding of how the brain is able to dynamically balance blood, brain, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volumes to regulate ICP, which can be pathologically elevated after traumatic brain injury, stroke, hemorrhage, tumor, hydrocephalus, and during seizures. The data collected in the proposed experiments could help inform therapeutic strategies for stabilizing ICP across several neurological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The experience of both elderly Mexican immigrants in the United States and that of older Mexico-based adults -connected to the US via their own past migration or that of their children - is greatly influenced by the accumulation of social and economic experiences over the life course, including contextual factors that shape immigrant inclusion. Using nationally representative panel data for 2006-2018 in the United States and 2001- 2018 in Mexico, we examine 1) how contemporary changes in factors affecting immigrant social inclusion are associated with the mental and physical health of Mexican immigrants and Mexico-based elderly with children in the United States; and 2) the way in which disadvantages experienced by these individuals across the life course are associated with chronic physical and cognitive health and mortality.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly half of all teen suicide deaths are caused by firearms. Lethal means safety involves limiting firearm access for teens at elevated suicide risk. It is an essential component of suicide prevention, yet is not done consistently or comprehensively in the Emergency Department (ED). This study will employ human-centered design to obtain teen and caregiver perspectives of lethal means safety planning, adapt an existing tool, and pilot the tool to improve patient-centered care of teens with elevated suicide risk presenting to the ED.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common serious arrhythmia in human populations, but current treatment strategies only function to reduce symptoms, instead of treating underlying causes. The studies outlined by this proposal will expand our understanding of the genes required by atrial muscle cells to maintain heart rhythm, and how the expression of these genes is maintained at the appropriate level. We will examine a set of genes implicated in human AF and in two mouse models for their requirement to maintain heart rhythm and for their effectiveness as gene therapies to prevent AF and reverse established disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The overall goal of this project is to enable Veterans with partial paralysis due to incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI) to improve their daily walking capabilities and become functional ambulators in the home or community environments. Approximately 15% of all Americans with SCI are Veterans, and the number of new cases with iSCI has been outpacing all others. We will achieve the goal of enhancing the functional walking ability and overall activity level of Veterans with iSCI by developing practical methods to control the activation of paralyzed or partially paralyzed muscles and seamlessly coordinate them with voluntary contractions to propel and stabilize the body based on feedback from wearable sensors that can estimate movement of the user's center of mass. This study progresses from initial computer simulations, through preliminary laboratory experiments, to clinical implementation with 10 volunteers with iSCI needing various degrees of stimulated assistance to walk naturally, intuitively vary walking speed, and recover from potentially destabilizing disturbances.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Over 50% of the Veterans enrolled for VA health care are over the age of 65. Dementia prevalence increases with age, and with the increase in the population of people ages 65 and older, the total number of people with dementia is also increasing. Older Veterans often have comorbid PTSD, major depression and traumatic brain injury so that they are at 2 to 5 times the risk for cognitive impairment and dementia compared to the general population. There is evidence that exercise interventions in sedentary older adults could improve both physical and cognitive function. However, there have been very few studies on the effects of exercise on cognition in older Veterans and do not reflect the broader ethnic and health-status diversity of Veterans. Thus, improved knowledge of the role of exercise on cognition as well as the predictive power of biomarkers could have a major beneficial impact on Veterans’ functional independence and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug resistance evolution is always a major threat to disease control and malaria drug resistance arises to each new frontline antimalarial drug. This Program Project renewal grant (P01) will use targeted genetic crosses to dissect the genetic complexity of artemisinin resistance in the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum emerging in Africa. This novel approach can extend well beyond artemisinin resistance and the malaria community by providing unprecedented insights into how genes control key drug resistance traits, with the goal of understanding evolutionary paths to resistance and ways to block the spread of drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium falciparum experimental genetic crosses in chimpanzees were used to pinpoint genes involved in drug resistance to antimalarials. We have developed a human-liver chimeric mouse model (the FRG NOD huHep mouse) to replace the chimpanzee for the recovery of recombinant progeny from crosses. The ease of use of this model will allow us to understand P. falciparum Mendelian inheritance, which, in turn, will help explain the evolution and spread of parasite drug resistance.

PHR: NARRATIVE Core B will conduct molecular and bioinformatic analyses of cross progeny to determine the location of QTLs. As each QTL may contain multiple genes, we will use a suite of methods to fine map QTLs, followed by CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing to determine the causative genes and SNPs within each QTL region. This Core will work closely with RP01, RP02 and RP03.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium falciparum experimental genetic crosses and downstream analysis of recombinant progeny can help determine genotypes associated with phenotypes. We will carry out genetic crosses to determine genotypes associated with phenotypes of mosquito and pre-erythrocytic life cycle stage development. Specifically, we will study the propensity for outcrossing in genetic crosses, the infectivity rate of sporozoites for the liver and the growth and development of the liver stage parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic linkage studies can be powerfully applied to discovering genes that control important phenotypes of malaria parasites such as drug resistance. We will apply our new technology to routinely generate genetic crosses of malaria parasites using ‘humanized’ mice that express human liver cells to generate 10 new genetic crosses strategically designed to map genes involved in resistance to the drug, artemisinin. This form of drug resistance is emerging in Africa and beginning to spread, with likely devastating consequences if unchecked.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novel therapies for food allergies and thorough understanding of the mechanisms associated with food allergy and tolerance are pressing needs of utmost priority. We will evaluate the safety and efficacy of microbiota transplantation therapy in teens with peanut allergy and investigate the role of novel biomarkers in predicting the outcome of peanut oral food challenge or peanut oral immunotherapy. We also will contribute extensively to the Consortium of Food Allergy Research as a Clinical Research Center through successful implementation, scientific expertise, and training of the next generation of NIH funded investigators skilled in food allergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC) is one of the most lethal forms of this disease, in part, due to the lack of effective therapies. This proposal will investigate whether blocking a factor that is highly active in TNBC known as NEK2 can increase the effectiveness of drugs that typically have limited impact on this disease. This may provide a new collection of drugs to improve the outcomes of patients with TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most human breast carcinogens are genotoxic and/or endocrine-active, and the combination of genotoxicity with endocrine activity is predicted to increase breast cancer risk more than either effect alone. Understanding these effects is vital, because exposure to chemicals with these activities is common from diet, pharmaceuticals, consumer products, and the environment. To investigate the joint risk of genotoxic and endocrine-active exposures, this project will use novel multiplexed spatial biology to measure how chemicals interact early in tumor development, expanding knowledge of fundamental mechanisms of breast carcinogenesis and providing a framework for rapid prediction and identification of human health hazards.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Consortium of Food Allergy Research Clinical Research Center: Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center (CoFAR-CRC:CCHMC) aims to bring the experience, expertise, and scientific productivity and the diverse patient populations of CCHMC to CoFAR. The CoFAR-CRC:CCHMC approach to research is multipronged and self-sustaining by attracting patients with excellent care and creating and maintaining databases and registries supported by biospecimen collection and biobanking. Those are utilized in conducting mechanistic research that forms the basis of discoveries and clinical trials and advances knowledge that improves patient care and attracts more patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Contingency management is one of the most effective behavioral health tools available for substance use disorder treatment, yet it is one of the least available to patients due to implementation barriers. This proposed research seeks to adapt a contingency management program to fit a new context within a low-threshold buprenorphine program providing services to patients with opioid use disorder via mobile van. Given the worsening opioid overdose crisis in the United States, this project has the potential for a significant public health impact by contributing to knowledge on how to adapt and implement contingency management to make it more accessible to patients with opioid use disorder, particularly those at highest risk of overdose death.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Assisted transfers are known to be one of the most strenuous activities of daily living leading to back and shoulder pain and injury to the caregiver and potential harm to the Veteran if not performed correctly. The Caregiver Assisted Transfer Technique Instrument (CATT) is a tool that was designed to identify deficits in technique that if corrected could reduce the risk of injuries to both the caregiver and their care recipients. Current work involves establishing the reliability and validity of the CATT so that it can be widely disseminated for clinical use in the future. Home-based fitness products involving access to live or on demand content and virtual reality cycling have become widely popular and beneficial for increasing fitness and motivation among able-bodied individuals however they are not accessible or tailored to the needs of wheelchair users. We aim to develop ParaCycle, a upper arm exercise bike that will be compatible with commercial fitness apps that offer virtual reality, social and motivational features to help support increased physical activity among Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Many mutations (about 6%) in cancer lead to serines. Despite the prevalence of serine-acquiring mutations in cancer, methods to target them are scarce. This project will develop a new chemical strategy to target serines in cancer through a covalent mechanism and discover inhibitors for EGFR(C797S) and BTK(C481S), two commonly occurring oncogenic mutants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite growing evidence of nutrition’s role in modulating the risk of COPD and COPD-related manifestations, we lack a mechanistic understanding of how dietary chemicals may synergistically exert their influence. Here, we develop a new set of machine learning and network science-based methods specifically designed to explore the impact of small molecules directly derived from food digestion, absorption, and related metabolism (dietary xenobiotics) on COPD exacerbation frequency and severity. These methods will help identify tailored interventions, combining pharmacological and dietary approaches, to mitigate lung disease through the use of Precision Nutrition.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: While long-term opioid therapy for chronic pain is common, harms of continuing it may outweigh benefits for many patients and tapering may be recommended; however, recent evidence also highlights potential harms associated with tapering or discontinuing opioids. Limited data exists on strategies for patient-centered opioid tapering and managing chronic pain among patients prescribed long-term opioid therapy. To address these unanswered questions and help inform VHA’s decisions about pain care resource deployment, our overarching aim is to emulate a three-arm, randomized controlled trial where we will compare two active interventions to a matched usual care group on the primary outcome of pain-related interference and secondary outcomes of opioid dose reduction, uptake of nondrug pain treatment, and health-related quality of life. We will also examine outcomes for pre-specified high-risk subgroups and, among patients who tapered opioid doses, will compare rates of patient-reported harms (namely, worsening pain and quality of life).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative - Overall  Vaccines are a demonstrably effective tool for blunting the global health consequences of emerging infectious diseases like COVID; however, they must be delivered quickly to limit outbreak spread and reduce human mortality. Here, two different programmable vaccine platforms primed for quick deployment will be compared and characterized. The knowledge and technology gained from this project will enable a rapid and effective response to the next pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Signaling through neuronal primary cilia plays a crucial role during early development, but primary cilia persist into adulthood and their role in mature neurons is largely undefined. Recent research has unveiled that ciliary signaling via the neuropeptide somatostatin (SST) can modulate neocortical circuits to potentially stabilize activity by providing network-wide homeostatic feedback to modulate excitatory synaptic strengths. Here I will test this hypothesis by manipulating SST signaling and determining the impact on neocortical function and further provide valuable insights into the underlying cause of cognitive impairment in disorders arising from cilia dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this K24 application, candidate Abby R. Rosenberg, MD, MS, MA proposes to expand her research and mentoring skills to optimize the impact and delivery of promising psychosocial interventions among youth with non-malignant blood disorders. Her research aims are to (1) test the feasibility and acceptability of a community- based, collaborative care model to deliver a positive psychology intervention among teens and young adults with Sickle Cell Disease; (2) leverage the electronic health record to evaluate relationships between social determinants of health and outcomes among children with non-malignant blood disorders; and (3) explore the impact of social determinants of health on psychosocial intervention efficacy using existing data from her R01- funded clinical trials. Her career development goals are to: (1) enhance her skills in collecting and investigating social determinants of health; (2) develop knowledge in dissemination and implementation science, with a focus on community-based adaptation and engagement; and (3) develop skills in using the electronic health record to assess patient-centered outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) continues to be a leading cause of irreversible blindness in veterans. This project addresses remaining gaps in AMD prevention and treatment by investigating blood flow to the eye with specialized imaging specifically to identify those veterans at higher risk of vision loss with low blood flow in the eye. This project will determine whether using laser speckle flowgraphy (LSFG) a type of non-invasive imaging that measures blood flow supplying the retina, can detect lower blood flow among patients with age-related macular degeneration. We will also determine how variable these measurements are so that we know what to expect when following veterans’ blood flow over time in the future. This will allow us to identify and monitor veterans who could be candidates for new treatments to increase blood flow to prevent vision loss from advanced AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lumbar puncture with cytology is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis of leptomeningeal disease (LMD); however, it is an invasive test and often requires multiple samples to capture circulating tumor cells (CTCs) within the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Point-of-care diagnostic devices that could be quickly and simply used by the hospital staff to quantify CTCs would significantly aid in the diagnosis of LMD. Such devices could also be easily integrated with treatment procedures to assess treatment efficacy, which is beneficial as there have been studies that suggest that the concentration of CTCs in CSF can be used as potential outcome measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The typhoidal Salmonellas (TS), primarily Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi A, remain a major cause of global morbidity and mortality. Revitalizing Informal Settlements and their Environments (RISE) is a cluster-randomized controlled trial of community-level upgrades of water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) infrastructure currently underway in 24 informal urban settlements in Indonesia and Fiji, two countries at high risk for TS. To inform improved future interventions under different scenarios, the data from this controlled trial, including serosurveys and human and environmental microbiome data, will be used to establish compartmental modeling approaches to predict and assess the impact of WASH interventions on TS transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with stroke frequently suffer from aphasia, a disorder of expressive and/or receptive language, that can lead to serious health consequences, including social isolation, depression, reduced quality of life, and increased caregiver burden. Aphasia recovery varies greatly between individuals, and likely relies upon the capacity for neuroplasticity, both at a systems level of reorganized brain networks and a molecular level of neuronal repair and plasticity. The proposed work will evaluate genetic and neural network biological markers of neuroplasticity associated with variability in aphasia, with a future goal to improve prognostics and identify therapeutic targets to reduce the long-term burdens of aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (3 sentences maximum) This project will develop technology to drive cancers that are defined by lineage-specific transcription factor overexpression to produce their own anti-tumor therapy. The project will result in the development of a specific therapeutic strategy for non-small cell lung adenocarcinoma, and a platform for the development of further therapies to target other cancer types with different transcription factor dependencies. Localized production of the anti-tumor drug will circumvent the toxicities and short half-life limitations associated with systemic administration of some therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is severe respiratory failure due to inflammatory lung injury, and immune regulatory pathways may dictate whether patients will develop progressive disease or recover. Our preliminary data in ARDS patients and using a mouse model of acute lung injury (ALI) revealed a role for one such pathway, IL-33-induction of type 2 immunity, in ALI recovery, with increased levels of an endogenous inhibitor (soluble ST2) of this pathway associated with worse ARDS clinical outcomes. The proposed work uses a mouse model of ALI and genetic tools to define the role of IL-33 signaling, and its regulation by soluble ST2, in lung injury and repair and leverages serial plasma and airway samples from ARDS patients to determine how markers of type 2 immunity predict disease trajectory and may reveal opportunities for early therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal cord injury (SCI) disrupts the nerves controlling movement, along with those that regulate functions like heart rate and blood pressure (known as the autonomic nervous system, or ANS). Testosterone (T) plays a significant role in brain health and ANS reflex function in non-neurologically impaired men. However, little is known about the relationships between T, nerve function, and ANS dysfunction after SCI. Interestingly, up to 60% of men with SCI exhibit persistently low T concentrations, which may worsen nerve and ANS dysfunction. In uninjured eugonadal people, a single pharmacologic dose of intranasal T has been shown to quickly improve nerve function, but no study has evaluated if T administration alters nerve and ANS function in men with SCI. Herein, we will conduct the first study to assess the relationships between circulating T and motor and ANS function in male Veterans with SCI. We will also conduct a pilot study in a subset of men with SCI and low T, to test how a single dose of intranasal T impacts motor and ANS function in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skin melanoma readily develop resistance to therapies, and targeted therapy is available only to a subset of patients with skin melanoma. We set out to develop and improve targeted therapy for the majority of patients by generating foundational and comprehensive knowledge of therapy resistance mechanisms. We will co-target these resistance mechanisms to develop combination therapies to improve patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The role of stress as the underlying cause for human adaptation is well-appreciated. Inherent in this response is the logical progression to human disease and disability, as there is little debate regarding the link between many different types of stress and the natural history of disease initiation and progression. The proposed program will focus on predoctoral scientist training in common themes of stress adaptation, and emphasize new core competencies that will develop new research skill sets, preparing scientists to innovate and discover novel therapeutic interventions.
PI_NAMEs: CANTORNA, MARGHERITA T;HARVATINE, KEVIN JOHN;KORZICK, DONNA HOPE (contact)

PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training in Physiological Adaptations to Stress

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The Spironolactone Initiation Registry Randomized Interventional Trial in Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction Extension Study (SPIRRIT-EX) is an extension of the SPIRRIT-HFpEF clinical trial that proposes to evaluate the effectiveness of spironolactone versus usual care. The primary hypothesis is that use of spironolactone will have an 18% lower incidence rate of total heart failure hospitalizations or cardiovascular death compared to usual care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-healing diabetic foot ulcers affect millions of Americans annually and existing therapeutic interventions are not efficient. This application will investigate how lipid nanoparticles loaded with pro-healing gene encoding mRNAs, and surface-functionalized to target specific cell types, can be delivered with novel biomaterials to accelerate diabetic wound healing. Additionally, using multi-omics approaches, the spatial cellular transcriptomic and proteomic landscape of the wounds will be mapped to determine the exact mechanisms of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the third leading cause of death worldwide and a highly variable disease with limited therapies, in part given prior studies do not account for disease heterogeneity with differential therapeutic responses. An understudied and highly prevalent potential phenotype is the heterozygous state of the SERPINA1 gene (encodes for alpha-1 antitrypsin protein) with one wild-type allele (M) and one Z variant allele (rs28929474), known as PI*MZ. We propose studying airway inflammatory and genotypic contributions to disease development among PI*MZ individuals to identify biologic correlates of disease severity and potential treatment targets for a highly prevalent disease phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative/ Relevance Huntington’s Disease (HD) is a devasting terminal disease with no disease modifying treatments. DNA damage accumulates in HD patients, contributing to neuronal death. The goal of this project is to identify key protein interactions and post translational modifications of DNA damage repair proteins which can be modulated to improve HD phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The heart and skeletal muscle contract when myosin protein pulls on actin filaments and mutations in these and associated proteins can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy through different mechanisms. This study will use methods from single atoms to whole hearts to explore a unique mutation in an actin protein that normally causes skeletal muscle disease but, in this case, causes cardiomyopathy. The findings from this study will establish a new way to study actin proteins in cardiomyopathy and lay the foundation for new heart failure therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The BP4 consortium brings together experts in virology, immunology, vaccine sciences, and antibody discovery to perform advanced research on prototype pathogens for Picornaviruses and Bunyaviruses. The group will develop both protective antiviral human antibodies (passive immunity) and vaccines (active immunity) for each of the viral pathogens studied. The highly interactive consortium will leverage lessons learned in the antibody studies of sites of vulnerability on the viruses to develop and test new vaccine concepts that can be extended from one prototype pathogen to all members of that class of viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The discovery of new antibiotics for Neisseria gonorrhoeae is relevant to public health due to the increasing prevalence of strains that have developed resistance to ceftriaxone, which is the last remaining highly effective antibiotic treatment and the standard first-line treatment globally. This project will apply a new approach to antibiotic discovery in N. gonorrhoeae by using machine learning to virtually screen hundreds of millions of chemicals for antibacterial activity. This approach promises to address the pressing need for new antibiotics and stave off the threat of untreatable gonorrhea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Estimating effects of infectious disease interventions is challenging when study samples do not reflect the target populations where intervention policies will be applied or when the outcomes of individuals are dependent on the treatments of other individuals. The proposed study will bring together the fields of generalizability and interference to estimate intervention effects using data from cluster randomized trials and observational studies. This work will allow for more accurate estimation of intervention effects in a variety of practical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Alcohol Use Disorders are currently positioned as the third leading cause of preventable death in the United States, several within 6 stimulation (TMS), a constituting a humanitarian crisis with substantial financial burden on society and medical facilities. While pharmacological interventions exist, 60% of individuals who seek these treatments relapse to alcohol months. The current proposal seeks to improve upon the clinical efficacy of transcranial magnetic form of non-invasive brain stimulation, by developing personalized, fMRI-guided TMS as a strategy to reduce brain reactivity to alcohol cues and reduce relapse rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Globally, tuberculosis is one of the leading causes of death by an infectious disease, and there is a critical need to develop new tools to enable early diagnosis and improve treatment and prevention. The proposed K24 award would support Dr. Andrews to mentor early career investigators in patient-oriented translational research. The focus of the proposed research is to test novel approaches to early diagnosis and pharmacogenomic approaches to optimize treatment and preventive therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The R2P2 ReVAMPP Center aims to develop vaccines and antibody-based treatments for viruses in the Paramyxoviridae, Peribunyaviridae, and Phleboviridae families. The center focuses on four primary research projects, working alongside key scientific cores to investigate prototype viruses and use principles of reverse vaccinology to understand immunity and antigenicity. The projects compare three vaccine platforms (protein subunit, mRNA, and chimeric VSV) to gather information about their performance in translating to related pathogens.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Social isolation is a negative social determinant of health (SDoH) that affects 1-in-5 adults in the U.S. and 43% of Veterans. Social isolation is estimated to cost the nation $6.7 billion annually in federal healthcare spending. Yet, social isolation has rarely been the direct focus of healthcare interventions. The proposed project is a randomized controlled trial that seeks to test the effectiveness of the Increasing Veterans’ Social Engagement and Connectedness (CONNECTED) intervention on social isolation among diverse Veteran groups in primary care clinics. CONNECTED involves three key services delivered by peers via telehealth through individual and group sessions over 8 weeks: 1) peer support, which includes person-centered assessment for social isolation, 2) psychosocial interventions to address social isolation, and 3) navigation (i.e., connecting Veterans to social resources). Findings from this study will contribute to the VA’s efforts to address SDoH among Veterans and to provide high quality, person-centered, and equitable care to all Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory bowel disease is a disease notable for intestinal energetic stress, such as down regulation of the machinery required to use creatine. We will evaluate the impact of creatine transporter loss on the mucous producing cells of the intestines and the impact that loss has on the bacteria and energetic factors in the intestine. This is significant because disruption of energy, bacteria and barrier function all contribute to inflammatory bowel disease activity and understanding their interactions could provide more targeted therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Aging and obesity are strong risk factors for breast cancer in women because as ovarian estrogen declines, women have less protection from the harmful effects of obesity, which causes inflammation and increases insulin levels. These harmful effects can be reversed by weight loss but this is often not sustainable. We have shown that a novel dietary intervention using time-restricted feeding of a western-style, high-fat diet prevents the effect of obesity to drive breast cancer in mice; the proposed studies will investigate whether this intervention has a beneficial effect during hormonal or chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Prostate cancer is diagnosed in approximately 12,000 American Veterans annually accounting for one third of all cancer diagnoses in American male Veterans. It is the second leading cause of cancer death in American male Veterans, and the number one cause of cancer-specific death amongst non-smoker Veterans. In addition to death, the treatments for prostate cancer have frequent and predictable detrimental impacts on Veterans’ quality of life. This burden is most intensely experienced by Veterans living with metastatic prostate cancer where the backbone of treatment is indefinite medical castration therapy. By leveraging advances in non-hormonal active therapy, our proposal promises to improve treatment efficacy and quality of life for Veterans with lethal prostate cancer. Specifically, comprehensive non-hormonal therapy in the form of targeted radiopharmaceutical therapy combined with metastasis directed precision radiotherapy, followed by physiologic restoration of testosterone will improve efficacy of therapy while simultaneously improving quality of life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of girls are married annually before the age of 18, and despite the lifelong negative consequences for health and the social determinants of health, little is known about how to reduce the prevalence of child marriage. Our study leverages a prior randomized control trial of the uniquely effective Pathways program, which reduced child marriage by 60 percentage point in treatment communities in northern Nigeria. We will conduct a six-year follow up survey with study participants to evaluate the medium-run effects of a successful program to combat child marriage, aiming to contribute important evidence on the health benefits of delaying marriage and inform future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Falls represent an enormous burden for people with PD, leading to injury, isolation, and death. Physical therapy is incompletely effective at reducing falls, due in part to a lack of knowledge regarding which aspects of balance clinicians should target during therapy to reduce falls and the brain regions that underlie these deficits. This project will fill these knowledge gaps by identifying the specific aspects of reactive balance and standing sway that are related to prospective falls and their neural signatures, thus improving clinicians’ ability to treat people with PD at risk for falls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Interdisciplinary graduate training in Occupational Safety (OS) and Occupational Health Psychology (OHP) are critical to meet NIOSH goals to advance Total Worker Health® research and practice. Researchers and practitioners with broad content knowledge, state-of-the-art research skills, and interdisciplinary teamwork experience are needed to protect the health and safety of workers while advancing their wellbeing. The proposed expansions to the existing successful OS training program will produce researchers and practitioners to meet these goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE J. DZUGAN This project has critical relevance to one of the nation’s highest risk occupations the nation: Alaska commercial fishing. This project will continue to support Coast Guard required safety training in the prevention and effective response to both commercial fishing vessel disasters and falls overboard, as well as develop a distance education methodology to reduce musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) to upper extremities due to repetitive motion, the most common cause of injuries in this occupation. This work will be accomplished by maintaining and supporting an Alaska port based marine safety instructor network to deliver training statewide and develop a web based ergonomics training platform specific to commercial fishing MSDs.

PROJECT_TITLE: Commercial Fishing Safety Training

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are an extremely valuable therapeutic cell type due to their capacity to reconstitute the entire blood system upon transplantation or injury. Recent research has identified transcription factor combinations that reprogram endothelial cells to HSCs, but the mechanisms underlying this process remain unknown. Here, we propose to elucidate the molecular and cellular mechanisms by which reprogramming factors promote cell fate changes, laying the groundwork for more selective and efficient generation of clinically relevant HSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Enzymes using metal centers and/or organic radicals play many crucial roles in the fundamental biochemistry of human health, with deficiencies in their bioassembly or enzymatic functions associated with various diseases. The R. David Britt laboratory is using advanced spectroscopic techniques to understand the assembly and catalytic mechanism of a number of such metal and radical centers. The ultimate goal is to bring this enhanced knowledge of fundamental metallobiochemistry to the treatment of diseases and the enhancement of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative  Neurotropic flaviviruses, including Zika virus, are a growing threat to global health. Despite the increasing burden of neurologic injury and cognitive impairment associated with flavivirus encephalitis, no disease-specific therapies for these infections exist. Here, we aim to identify new molecular mechanisms that promote protective neuroimmune function during Zika virus infection of the brain. These findings would uncover much-needed new molecular targets for the development of therapeutic and intervention strategies.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Immunology is the study of the body’s immune system and how it responds in states of health and disease. Many human conditions involve alterations of the normal function of the immune system including cancer, autoimmune diseases, infectious diseases, and transplantation. The purpose of this training grant is to instruct the next generation of scientists in the critical thinking and technical skills necessary to provide mechanistic insights into how the immune system functions, and how to manipulate the host immune response to the benefit of human health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading causal of morbidity and mortality in the United States. Veterans are at higher risk than the general population and CVD is the number one cause of hospitalizations in the VA. Atherosclerosis, narrowing of arteries due to plaque, causes CVD. It affects the coronary arteries of the heart causing heart attack, the peripheral arteries of the leg causing debilitating leg pain and gangrene, and the carotid arteries leading to the brain causing stroke. Current approaches to prevent and treat CVD treat all forms of atherosclerosis the same. Genetic studies of coronary and peripheral artery disease have identified important differences, suggesting a tailored approach will work better. Similar studies for carotid artery disease are lacking, which prevents the full implementation of precision medicine approaches. The proposed study will use data from the VA Million Veteran Program to identify genes associated with carotid stenosis and quantify the impact of known and novel risk factors. It will help establish tailored therapy to treat carotid stenosis and prevent stroke.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE South Carolina Biomedical Data Science and Informatics for Health Equity Research (SC BIDS4HEALTH) training program combines rigorous curriculum in biomedical informatics, data science, population, health systems and policy, and domain biology based on existing joint PhD degree in Biomedical Data Science and Informatics with coursework and practical experiences in understanding diversity and career readiness skills. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – New treatments for anxiety disorders are critically needed and a more complete understanding of pathological anxiety at the molecular, cellular and circuit levels will provide a foundation for new treatment development. Using our non-human primate model of extreme anxiety, the proposed studies will use neuroimaging, molecular sequencing techniques and chemogenetics to understand the extent to which neurons in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex are involved in the expression of early-life pathological anxiety and could serve as treatment targets for anxiety disorders. Additionally, these studies will serve as a proof-of-concept to understand the feasibility of developing chemogenetic approaches for the modulation of prefrontal cortical function in the treatment of severe and refractory psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative To meet the needs of cancer researchers investigating the role of extracellular vesicles in cancer we will develop and validate assay kits that enable the high-resolution measurement of EV number, size, and surface cargo. These assays will enable researchers to study the roles of EVs in the pathology and response to cancer. Such studies may lead to the development of new biomarkers to assess cancer type and target and monitor treatment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 200,000 veterans have moderate to severe chronic kidney disease (CKD). People CKD will die prematurely from cardiovascular disease (CVD) or progress to end stage renal disease (ESRD). The two most common causes of CKD are hypertension and diabetes. However, great variability exists in both the severity of risk factors and the response to therapies, limiting the full potential benefit of therapy on individual and population levels. In this proposal we apply what we have learned from the genetics of CKD, hypertension and resistant hypertension in the MVP and apply it to inform risk stratification equations and stratification base on clinical response to treatments. Finally we study the genetic determinants of phosphorus and vitamin D important risk factors for progression of disease, something that our patients struggle with. We hope to be able to improve the health and care provided to our patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death amongst U.S. Veterans. Despite recent advances in cancer immunotherapy, many patients with NSCLC do not respond to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI). Therefore, there is a critical need for the development of novel strategies that enhance the efficacy of immunotherapy. One approach is to utilize in situ vaccination (ISV) with rationally engineered cytokine-secreting dendritic cells (DCs) to generate broad tumor-specific T cell responses. In preclinical studies, we have shown that ISV with FLT3L-secreting conventional type 1 DCs (FLT3L-cDC1) synergize with ICI to eradicate highly aggressive immune-resistant NSCLC. This proposal seeks to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of ISV and DC immunobiology in murine NSCLC models to facilitate the development of novel vaccine therapies for Veterans with lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Eating disorders affect 14.4 million women and 6.6 million men in the US, costing the US economy $64.7 billion annually. The long-term objectives of this project are to evaluate whether we are making progress in reducing the public health burden associated with eating disorders, determine the course of eating pathology over adult development, and identify predictors of course that can be translated into targets for intervention, including what to modify, in whom, and when. Findings will establish a benchmark against which to measure progress and advance efforts to eliminate these serious mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This program will provide innovative and comprehensive predoctoral research training at the intersection of clinical translational science and the Research Domain Criteria using a dual mentorship model. Six NIH and two institutionally-funded psychological and brain science trainees per year will receive structured applied experiences, didactics, seminars, and workshops from both core and “stretch” faculty with a specific focus on the development of a clinical translational program of research, grant writing, and professional development.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Clinical Translational Science: Maximizing the Public Health Impact

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: While the rapid increase of our elderly population has led to a burden of disease and disability that threatens our society, new research is identifying universal mechanisms that determine and even regulate the aging of all organisms and impact all organ systems. Our aim is to train the next generation of scientists to engage in interdisciplinary research aimed at discovering and implementing therapies that alleviate the suffering caused by age-associated degenerative processes. The collaboration of scientists from diverse backgrounds enhances creativity and innovation by bringing together a wide range of perspectives, and our goal is to provide rigorous training to our students and postdocs to become leaders in the broad area of aging biology, and to increase the diversity and quality of the national work force in this area.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biology of Aging;Molecular Biology;Training Programs;Universities
PROJECT_TITLE: Brown University Training Program in the Molecular Biology of Aging

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The process of sex determination has significant consequences on animal development and results in distinct differences in organ systems, behavior, and even responses to diseases. Animals like humans and flies use conserved mechanisms, such as the Doublesex/Mab3 Related Transcription Factors (DMRTs) and steroid hormone signaling, to regulate sexual development in the gonad. Elucidating these mechanisms is critical for understanding how sexual development occurs and can further treatment of human syndromes leading to Differences of Sexual Development and infertility.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: While previous research primarily focused on the properties of the cancer cell, in recent years, there has been an increasing interest in understanding the role of the tumor stroma in supporting cancer growth. It has become clear that to develop effective strategies against pancreatic cancer, tumor stroma needs to be addressed. In this regard, our preliminary data suggest that NFκB signaling in pancreatic cancer stroma is pro-tumorigenic and promotes tumor growth by creating an immunosuppressive environment. In the current grant application, we will decipher how stromal NFκB modulates pancreatic cancer growth. Successful completion of these studies will lead to discovery of novel strategies to modulate tumor microenvironment for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Protein-coding genes must generate functional RNAs at the appropriate levels, and this process is controlled by many different molecular machines, including the Integrator complex and the spliceosome. The proposed studies will characterize in detail how Integrator controls the amount of RNA that is produced as well as why abundant circular RNAs are generated from many protein-coding genes by the spliceosome. This will allow us to better understand how gene outputs are controlled, thereby providing important new insights into how gene misregulation can lead to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The discovery and clinical use of polygenic risk scores (PRS) for complex traits promises to dramatically change the practice of medicine. Our eMERGE IV grant will leverage a large Biobank and a rich electronic medical record to define the clinical impact of PRS derived from diverse populations and the clinical impact of returning these results along with family history and clinical risk information to participants and their healthcare providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular diseases are the major causes of morbidity and mortality in the United States. This Cardiovascular Surgery Research Training Program aims to prepare next-generation scientists and clinician- scientists in state-of-the-art cardiovascular research by training surgery residents and postdoctoral fellows through outstanding mentored research experiences. This Program will help advance basic and translational research to develop novel therapeutic modalities by a group of well-trained cardiovascular academic researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Babies experience dramatic changes in their metabolism after heart surgery that may lead to heart failure, organ damage, or even death. Currently little is known about the specific metabolism changes that are most dangerous or how to fix them. In our project we will use blood tests from our patients to better understand these metabolism changes and then test metabolism in important organs in an animal model of heart surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelination is essential for the transmission of electrical signals along axons in the central nervous system (CNS) and the mechanisms underlying its formation and plasticity are still not fully understood. This study aims to test the hypothesis that subunits of voltage-gated calcium channels positively control CNS myelin development and remyelination after trauma or disease. If successful, this study will further our understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms controlling myelination and provide molecular targets that can be manipulated for therapeutic gain to promote remyelination after CNS injury and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) represents advanced diabetic eye disease and can result in permanent vision loss. The electronic health record (EHR) can be a powerful tool for studying real-world outcomes of conditions like PDR to help prevent disease occurrence and improve outcomes. We will develop and validate EHR-based methods and tools to improve outcomes in PDR, which can also be applied to other eye conditions to facilitate future EHR-based clinical studies in ophthalmology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The Boston University Rheumatology Research Training (BURRT) T32 Program will provide a comprehensive two-year multidisciplinary training program in rheumatic and musculoskeletal diseases for postdoctoral MD and PhD scholars to pursue academic and scientific clinical research careers. The program will train 3 postdoctoral scholars every 2 years in a core curriculum and several specialized tracks under the guidance of experienced and funded mentors, and supported by a broad curriculum with coursework, seminars, roundtables, team research meetings, and hands-on experiences. Ultimately, the program aims to have T32 scholars successfully transition to independent clinical research careers as the next general of leaders in rheumatic and musculoskeletal disease research.
PROJECT_TERMS: Boston;programs;Research Training;Rheumatology;Universities
PROJECT_TITLE: Boston University Rheumatology Research Training (BURRT) T32 Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Public Health Statement Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia and imposes tremendous burdens on families, communities, and the health care system. Tragically, the population of Americans suffering from AD is expected to grow to 16 million by 2050. There is no cure, but insights into the pathophysiology of AD promises more effective treatments to ease symptoms, slow progression, and prevent disease. This is an application for the training of pre-doctoral and post-doctoral fellows in the area of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) related to neurodegenerative disorders pathophysiology.

PROJECT_TITLE: Predoctoral and Postdoctoral Training in Alzheimer's Pathophysiology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Fundamental features of the nervous system development and function are regulated by the extra cellular matrix (ECM), a complex three-dimensional milieu surrounding the cells. This proposal will study a newly described cellular pathway that has a critical role in brain development, motor function and regulating the composition of the brain ECM. This pathway is regulated by the protein THAP1, whose loss of function leads to the neurodevelopmental movement disorder, dystonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In this renewal application, we will investigate a novel tool of benefit-risk analysis for the presurgical evaluation of pediatric drug-resistant focal epilepsy which utilizes the state-of-the-art deep convolutional neural network (DCNN)-based tract classification to provide an optimal resection boundary of the epileptogenic area resulting in the maximized benefit (seizure freedom) and minimized risk (functional deficit including motor, language, hearing, and vision). We will also study if the integration of DCNN and DWI connectome helps decide timely surgery by providing preoperative imaging markers underlying a high likelihood of postoperative neurocognitive improvements and mechanistic insight in structural brain reorganization associated with postoperative verbal IQ improvement. The results of this project will translate deep learning-based diffusion MRI techniques to optimize the surgical margin, predict the postoperative neurocognitive outcome, and determine the specific mechanism of postoperative brain reorganization, which will be validated for optimizing clinical benefit-risk analysis before surgical intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Clinicians trained in the discipline of pediatric clinical pharmacology remain instrumental to the acquisition, adoption, and implementation of knowledge that guides the safe and effective use of medicines in children. Formal training in clinical pharmacology arms individuals with the skills necessary to 1) integrate the basic and clinical sciences, 2) design and analyze clinical trials, 3) characterize therapeutic outcomes and/or relevant surrogate biomarkers, and 4) define dose-exposure-response relationships. The program at Children’s Mercy, which accepted their first fellow in 1998, provides an exemplary environment in which to train the next generation of pediatric clinical pharmacologists and remedy the shortage of clinician scientists who have formal training in this discipline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Impaired mitochondrial calcium homeostasis has been linked to both common and rare neurological disorders. Recent evidence indicates that genetic loss of the gatekeepers of mitochondrial calcium uptake, MICU1/2, causes progressive neurological disease in both human and mouse but the underlying mechanism remains elusive. The proposed work will help to understand the dynamic and complex physiological involvements of the MICU proteins, and the neurological pathogenesis caused by their inherited as well as acquired acute loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma is a leading cause of death worldwide. A large proportion of trauma-related deaths that occur in the days to weeks following injury are caused by multi-organ failure that is driven by loss of microvascular barrier function. The proposed studies will support innovative programmatic areas of research to advance our understanding of the pathophysiologic mechanisms of trauma-induced endothelial damage that will guide the identification of novel therapeutic targets after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall aim of Dr. Jae Sevelius' K24 application is to develop and implement intersectional approaches to mentoring and patient-oriented research focused on HIV prevention and treatment interventions with transgender and gender diverse people who use substances. The specific aims of the research strategy are as follows: (1) to characterize the relationships between experiences of transgender-related discrimination, substance use, and engagement in HIV care among transgender women living with HIV, (2) to assess how implementation of an existing intervention for transgender women living with HIV is impacted by substance use among participants, and (3) to develop a contextually grounded understanding of multi-level intersectional stigma, including substance use stigma, among transgender women in Brazil to inform measurement refinement and future intervention strategies. Dr. Sevelius' specific focus on developing an intersectional approach to mentoring in patient-oriented research on substance use and HIV has the potential to directly contribute to increasing the pipeline of diverse researchers entering the field who have the capacity to develop and advance innovative approaches to major challenges in HIV prevention and substance use research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address the widely recognized decline in the physician-scientist workforce, we propose to establish the University of Southern California Stimulating Access to Research in Residency (USC-StARR) Program to foster the development of surgeon-scientists in the field of cardiovascular and pulmonary disease. We have designed an intensive, 24-month, contiguous StARR program for select clinical residents in the General Surgery, Integrated Vascular Surgery, and Integrated Cardiothoracic Surgery Residency Programs. Through the development of an Independent Career Development Plan (ICDP), composed of research, education, and mentorship components, we will establish a program that will lead to both clinical and research competency and increase the ability of these surgeon-scientists to transition to other forms of research and career development support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The primary goals of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Direct Phase II project are to test, refine, and bring to market a novel algorithm that uses electronic health data (including electronic health records [EHR] and insurance claims) to improve detection and diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD). More than half of the 6.5 million Americans currently living with ADRD are undiagnosed. Lack of a diagnosis can result in delayed access to treatment, poor care management, unnecessary hospitalizations and emergency department (ED) visits, difficulty managing other chronic conditions, inability to participate in planning for future care, risky behaviors such as driving, and delayed access to caregiver support. Studies also have shown that healthcare costs for people with ADRD are three times higher than those without ADRD. For this reason, health plans are reimbursed by Medicare at a higher rate for patients diagnosed with ADRD. Multiple principal investigator (PI) Dr. Deborah Barnes and colleagues have developed and validated a novel algorithm called eRADAR (electronic health record [EHR] Risk of Alzheimer’s and Dementia Assessment Rule) that uses EHR data to identify patients at risk of having undiagnosed dementia with high accuracy. They have externally validated eRADAR in two healthcare systems, including confirming that the algorithm works well over time and in different race and ethnic groups. A limitation of eRADAR, however, is that it was designed as a static tool, and it does not learn from or adapt to new data streams. Many organizations that are interested in improving dementia detection, such as Medicare Advantage plans, have access to insurance claims data rather than EHR data. As part of Phase I proof-of-concept work for this grant, we created RADAR (Risk of Alzheimer’s and Dementia AlgoRithm), which uses Medicare claims data rather than EHR data to calculate a risk score for undiagnosed dementia that is similar to eRADAR. The primary goals of this SBIR Direct Phase II are to: 1) Retrospectively assess the accuracy of RADAR to detect undiagnosed dementia using historical Medicare claims data; 2) Develop an adaptive process using machine learning techniques to identify optimal RADAR predictor sets based on data inputs; and 3) Determine the optimal strategy for sharing RADAR’s output with clients interested in improving dementia detection and diagnosis. Together Senior Health’s mission is to serve people living with memory loss, cognitive decline and ADRD by providing evidence-based, online programming. Our current products include Moving TogetherTM–a mind-body group movement program for people with mild ADRD and care partners—and Brain Health Together, which combines Moving Together with brain health coaching to address modifiable risk factors. Our current clients include Medicare Advantage plans, home health agencies, and ADRD care centers. Adding RADAR to our product line will enable us to better support our business clients while also expanding access to our services and improving quality of life for people living with ADRD and those who care for them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Temperatures are rising due to climate change and, in parallel, psychopathology among U.S. adolescents has risen in the past decade; these concerns require a robust and innovative public health response. The role of the natural and built environments in affecting psychopathology remains largely unstudied, and this project aims to create high-resolution estimates of annual neighborhood surface temperatures, tree canopy cover, and other built environment sources of shade and green space to evaluate how these features impact psychopathology across time among adolescents. We will estimate typologies of neighborhood risk that can be utilized by public health and policy stakeholders to identify high-risk neighborhoods for which place-based interventions may be of the greatest public health relevance.

PHR: The future of biomedical research in the U.S. will depend on the rigorous training of PhD scientists who can think critically and independently, and who use cutting edge Molecular Biophysical approaches to solve important biomedical problems. The Molecular Biophysics Training Program at the University of California, San Diego fosters the development of dedicated Molecular Biophysics researchers who can apply rigorous research approaches across disciplinary boundaries, choose research problems with important human health implications, and communicate their results effectively. The Program serves as the campus “home” for Molecular Biophysics, and provides rigorous training, high-quality individual mentorship, and career guidance for graduate students from different graduate programs pursuing research projects in the area of Molecular Biophysics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We know that rural residents in the Appalachian region of the Southeastern United States have the nation’s highest rates of insufficient sleep (habitual sleep duration ≤6 hours), but the reasons for this are unclear. This issue is particularly concerning, as these same rural residents also face substantially higher than average rates of negative health outcomes including heart disease, cancer, diabetes, obesity, depression, and substance use disorders. We will follow a group of Appalachian adults over the course of two years to track their sleep, physical and mental well-being, and health behavior (e.g., substance use, smoking, diet, exercise), in order to better understand the culturally relevant factors that predict difficulties with both sleep and health in this unique and underserved, rural population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Rectal cancer patients have significantly improved quality of life when surgery can be avoided. Carbon monoxide, which has been shown to have beneficial properties at low concentrations with roles in modulation of diverse physiological and pathological processes such as inflammation and cancer, may improve anti-tumor response to chemoradiotherapy and paradoxically protect surrounding normal rectum. To improve neoadjuvant therapy and reduce the likelihood of requiring surgery, I propose the evaluation of novel CO biofoams as an adjunctive strategy to chemoradiotherapy and will evaluate the mechanism of protection in tumors and normal tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Periodic paralysis is a rare inherited disorder of skeletal muscle in which recurrent episodes of severe weakness, and the risk of progressive weakness with loss of ambulation, are caused by mutations of ion channel genes. The defects in channel function resulting from these mutations are now known, but the mechanism by which transient attacks of paralysis are triggered by diet, stress, or exercise are poorly understood. We will use our genetically-engineered mouse models of periodic paralysis to explore the hypothesis that these transient episodes of weakness occur as a result of changes in the abundance of intracellular ions (sodium and chloride), and also determine whether channel defects lead to chronically altered intracellular ion content.
