IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Exogenous surfactant has previously been shown to offer a clinical benefit in full-term infants, children and adolescents experiencing acute lung injury (ALI) or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), but has not been successfully applied in adults, most likely due to poor alveolar lung delivery efficiency of the current liquid bolus instillation procedure, which is often employed with invasive mechanical ventilation late in the development of ALI/ARDS. In this project, a new high efficiency synthetic lung surfactant powder aerosol product is developed (including delivery strategies, formulations and devices) that can be rapidly administered early and often in ALI/ARDS development during less invasive forms of ventilation support, such as high-flow nasal cannula therapy. The proposed synthetic lung surfactant inhalation product will reduce the required administered dose by an order of magnitude, reduce aerosol treatment times in adults from >10 hours to minutes, and substantially reduce the projected cost per treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Reinhard, Bjoern Plasmonic Inactivation of Virus and Mycoplasma Contaminants Relevance to Public Health Microbial contamination is a significant problem in the safe production of biologics as pharmaceuticals, and our goal is to develop nanoplasmonic materials that inactivate viruses and mycoplasma without harming the precious biologics. Biologics, in particular monoclonal antibodies, are among the fastest growing class of pharmaceuticals, and disruption of their production due to viral or mycoplasma contamination has the potential for profound impact on public health. Our approach combines new breakthroughs in the fields of plasmonic metamaterials and nanotechnology to address a vexing and persistent contamination problem in the safe production of monoclonal antibodies and other biologics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Conventional intracellular electrical signaling tools are not designed for sensing cellular activities either at different positions of a single cell or among different cells in a cellular network, which is essential for deciphering the propagative and communicative behaviors of electrogenic cells' (e.g., neurons) signals and determining the mechanism and treatment of progressive neurological disorders, such as Parkinson's disease. To overcome these challenges, we propose a 3D array of intracellular sensors featuring a field effect transistor configuration that is highly sensitive, accurate, and scalable to record both intra- and inter-cellular electrophysiological events in a cellular network. !

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Training a new generation of scientific leaders in health services research (HSR) is crucial for improving the quality, efficiency, and equity of health care delivery in the United States. The UC Berkeley-UCSF Health Services Research T32 uses an interdisciplinary social and behavioral science approach to health services research training at both pre- and postdoctoral levels. The faculty group’s application of interdisciplinary advances -- including in data science, behavioral economics, and implementation science methods – to issues of direct relevance to policymakers and health care organization leaders, and close mentorship, equips trainees to conduct partnered health services research that can generate evidence to improve access to care, affordability, quality, patient outcomes, and to advance equity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is estimated that 1 billion people have hypertension worldwide, causing an estimated 9.4 million deaths annually. We will evaluate the effect of home blood pressure monitoring on clinical outcomes, clinic blood pressure, blood pressure medication intensification, and medication adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal will use a multidisciplinary approach to elucidate neuron-specific mechanisms that underlie increased risk for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia –motor neuron disease (FTD-MND) in patients with Ataxin-2 intermediate-length polyglutamine expansions. Results from these analyses will provide new insights into (1) the molecular basis of Ataxin-2 / TDP-43 interactions, (2) how Ataxin-2 polyQ expansions interact with TDP-43 at the cellular level to impact post-transcriptional RNA regulation, and (3) potential molecular targets for mechanism-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults with cancer experience multiple distressing symptoms during treatment, yet few age-appropriate resources have been developed to help these individuals self-manage their symptoms. This project will test an intervention designed to improve symptom self-management by helping adolescents and young adults understand their unique symptom experience and discuss it with their health care providers. Enabling patients to have a more active role in self-management during cancer treatment should lessen their symptom severity and distress during cancer treatment.

PHR: Narrative CHCHD10, a gene coding for a mitochondrial protein, is the second most frequently mutated gene in Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration (FTLD)-Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) spectrum disorders. However, as only 1 patient with CHCHD10 mutation (ALS-linked CHCHD10R15L) and no FTD patient with CHCHD10 mutation has come to autopsy, we do not know the pathological signatures of CHCHD10-driven pathogenesis and to what extent such signatures are present in sporadic Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRDs). This proposal will allow us to identify and validate the changes in insoluble proteome driven by CHCHD10 function and dysfunction and test the hypothesis that such pathological signatures results from disruption of mitochondrial proteostasis and autophagic clearance of proteotoxically challenged mitochondria, and that restoration of wild type CHCHD10 represents a viable strategy to mitigate proteotoxic burden and disease outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative Psychiatric epidemiology, a core science of public mental health, is critical to development of prevention, intervention, and translation efforts to improve population mental health. For 50 years, the Psychiatric Epidemiology Training (PET) program at Columbia University has advanced scholarship, science, and training in psychiatric epidemiology. Through balanced growth of historical legacies and new intellectual resources, we will continue to grow this highly successful program, one of only a few of its kind in the US, to prepare the next generation of scholars and change-makers to address critical challenges among those with mental illness across the globe.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed study will test the efficacy of a family-focused preventive intervention in improving healthy lifestyles among first-time parents in military families and reducing obesity risk among their infants. We propose to test this innovative approach in the context of the Military Health System (MHS), within a research network of military family medicine physicians, for several reasons. Recruitment will be conducted by embedded clinical staff from the network in the primary care clinics, and follow-up will be facilitated by the tracking providing by the MHS.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative This training program is designed to develop early career scholars who identify timely research problems, conceptualize creative responses, apply cutting-edge research techniques, and effectively guide the translation of findings into policy and practice. Our trainees are prepared to tackle the complex ways in which contemporary health and health care problems transcend disciplinary boundaries. Their published work, both during and after completing the program, has had a demonstrable impact on health care, healthcare equity, as well as the policies and practices that affect both.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: 8. Project Narrative This application proposes a longitudinal study of the long-term impact of COVID-19 pandemic-related school closures on the growth of emotional and behavioral problems in a diverse sample of 613 children, ages 4–15 years, with and without developmental disabilities and their families. The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the risk of increased emotional and behavioral problems, parenting stress, and poor school outcomes for high-risk children and families, including those with disabilities. This study will significantly contribute to our understanding of long-term effects of pandemic-related school closures and elucidate policy and intervention recommendations for supporting children with disabilities and their families in a post-pandemic world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Further progress in the malaria eradication agenda requires novel vector control strategies to complement advances in prophylactic and therapeutic drug discovery and an effective vaccine. Long-term, sustainable impacts on the vector mosquitoes requires the deployment of strategies designed to be resilient to the immigration of susceptible mosquitoes and parasite-infected people. Approaches that couple genes that confer resistance to parasite transmission with mechanisms for spreading those genes through target mosquito populations hold great promise for contributing to the control of this major disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative In normal hearing the understanding of speech depends upon the ability of the organ of Corti to properly process the information content of sound. In the context of this proposal, the processing requires the correct system components (e.g., fluid hydrodynamics) as well as the biochemical components the control the elusive mechanical/physiological character of the tectorial membrane. Among the components, two are chosen for study in this proposal. The effect of perilymph viscosity and tectorial membrane calcium buffering. These have not yet been investigated and the resulting new information can lead to insights into hearing loss treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: There are currently few to no effective therapies to treat pulmonary fibrosis, which is a devastating progressive illness. The multifunctional cytokine transforming growth factor-b (TGF-b) is at the apex of a series of pathologic inflammatory and fibrotic events that culminate in fibroinflammatory pathology. The far-reaching goals of this project are to improve mechanistic understanding so that TGF-b can be effectively and selectively targeted to treat fibrosing and chronic inflammatory lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The world's aging societies require solutions for debilitating and costly chronic diseases that rob people of the joy of their `golden years,' and threaten to overwhelm both the capacity of the medical establishment and the treasuries of national governments. Ultimately, the solutions to these problems will lie in preventative measures or actual cures for diseases such as Alzheimer disease, Parkinson disease, coronary artery disease, diabetes, late onset cancers, rheumatoid and arthritic diseases, stroke, respiratory diseases, and susceptibility to infectious bacteria and viruses (e.g. COVID-19). This Geroscience program in the Biology of Aging prepares researchers to discover the mechanistic complexities and causes of aging and of age-related diseases, and to design rational preventative measures or cures for clinical testing.

PROJECT_TITLE: USC-Buck Geroscience Training in the Biology of Aging

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Influenza virus is a significant pathogen in pediatric solid organ transplant (SOT) recipients, but these individuals respond poorly to standard-dose (SD) inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV). Studies suggest that two doses of SD-IIV or one dose of high-dose (HD-IIV) is superior to one dose of SD-IIV; however, this has not been tested in the highest risk early post-transplantation period, and pediatric-specific studies of these regimens and their impact are critically lacking. This study aims to compare two doses of HD-IIV to two doses of SD-IIV administered in the same influenza season in pediatric kidney, heart, and/or liver SOT recipients in the early post-transplant period.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: We have recently shown that several aspects of the structures of bacterial chromosomes play important roles in gene regulation, especially of genes involved in nutrient acquisition and virulence. We will utilize a recently developed suite of tools to determine the contributions of chromosomal structure to the regulation of these processes across a broad range of bacterial species and physiological conditions. Our findings will assist in the design of targeted therapeutics inhibiting bacterial virulence, and enhance our capabilities in designing regulatory circuits for synthetic biology.

PHR: Project Narrative We seek to understand the basis for increased susceptibility of the elderly heart to surgical stress insult via investigating signaling mechanisms underlying altered adaptive responses to cardiovascular stress with aging. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Prescription and illicit opioid use have been recognized as a public health crisis, and heroin is being rapidly replaced with illicitly-manufactured fentanyl. Xylazine, a veterinary anesthetic, is being used as an adulterant in fentanyl use, and this pattern of polysubstance use renders naloxone ineffective at precipitating withdrawal and thus reversing overdose. The proposed research has the potential to not only uncover novel neurobehavioral mechanisms by which xylazine and fentanyl polysubstance use uniquely alter the reward pathway, behavior, and render naloxone unable to precipitate withdrawal, but will also identify and target mechanisms to reverse these effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Misuse of prescription opioids is a significant public health and economic burden; in 2020 in the United States, more than 9.9 million people reported prescription opioid misuse, and prescription opioids contributed to over 17,000 overdose deaths. A defining symptom of opioid use disorder is the inability to abstain from drug consumption in the face of aversive life consequences, which afflicts only a subset of individuals who take prescription opioids. Understanding the neural circuits that distinguish this subset of individuals who cannot inhibit drug consumption is necessary to predict which patients are at risk for developing opioid use disorder, and to prevent or reverse these neural circuit changes as a potential therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project uses the Drosophila genetic model to investigate mechanistic relationships between the innate immune system, lipid homeostasis, and the unfolded protein response that underlie sleep during sickness. Specifically, we test the hypothesis that through a negative feedback mechanism, an over production of antimicrobial peptides dampens the ability of cells to mount an appropriate recovery response, leading to sustained excess sleep characteristic of sickness behavior. Findings from this project will have implications for mechanisms underlying illness-associated unrefreshing sleep and fatigue in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Recently a number of electronic cigarettes (EC) companies have marketed products with vaping liquids that are advertised as “tobacco-free”, meaning they contain “synthetic” nicotine and therefore are not subject to existing FDA tobacco regulations. Nicotine can exist as two optical isomers (enantiomers) – (S)- and (R)-nicotine, which have different pharmacologic properties – and most synthetic nicotine products are comprised of a combination (racemic mixture) of the two. We propose to conduct a human clinical pharmacology study using stable isotope methodology to compare pharmacokinetics, metabolism, subjective, cardiovascular effects and self-administration of vaped (S)- and (R)- nicotine and racemic nicotine, which will provide important information for appropriate FDA regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed training in critical thinking, communication, rigor and reproducibility, professional and career development as well as disciplinary knowledge is supported by literature findings of critical skills needed by biomedical Ph.D. graduates who will work in multiple settings. This includes training in mentorship, time management, working with and leading teams, career planning including key competencies in teaching and mentoring, communication, leadership self-awareness and professionalism. PSTP trainees will receive this training both from our program and from professionals in the School of Medicine and Graduate School who can complement the instruction provided by the highly experienced Ph.D. mentors associated with the program. Training provided by these entities is open to all Ph.D. candidates, and so allows us to synergize with other T32 (and other training programs) present at Duke University.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Genome-wide sequencing technologies have allowed an unprecedented discovery of somatic mutations in chromatin and epigenetic regulators in human cancers, including gain-of-function or loss-of-function mutations in Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2). The proposed research will determine mechanisms of how PRC2 dysregulation disrupts the chromatin landscape and leads to cancer formation. These findings are expected to illuminate new strategies for development of cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: Genome rewiring events, through translocations, deletions, and even massive chromosomal rearrangements, contribute to genome instability associated with many human diseases, including a significant portion of cancers and inherited or spontaneous diseases. Furthermore, many classes of noncoding RNAs participate in genome remodeling pathways or the maintenance of genome integrity, and their loss or dysfunction can increase the frequency of genome rearrangements, resulting in either deletion of tumor-suppressing genes, formation of chimeric genes, or over-expression of genes that promote tumor stability. The extreme degree of natural genome editing events in Oxytricha make it unparalleled as a model system to study genome stability, and similar mechanisms that may contribute to genome instability and cancer in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality worldwide and is also a major cause of death in obesity-induced type 2 diabetes, owing to the development and progress of dangerous atherosclerosis plaques that will ultimately lead to blood clot formation and death in the form of heart attacks. The long-term objective of this project is to expand the targeting possibilities of RNA interference (RNAi) therapy, which can specifically silence individual genes including those that are considered “undruggable”, beyond the liver for treatment of chronic diseases like atherosclerosis. We will develop a novel and robust RNAi strategy with long duration of action for silencing a unique kinase that is activated in both advanced atherosclerosis and obesity- induced type 2 diabetes, which we expect could lead to development of potent therapeutics for atherosclerosis and cardiometabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding mechanisms underlying sex-related vulnerabilities relevant to Alzheimer's disease (AD) from cells to networks is critical to interrogate disease processes and develop effective sex stratified, precision medicine derived therapies. We present an innovative, multidisciplinary strategy to study proteome-wide protein-protein interactions in disease to investigate interactome network and connectome dysfunction in the context of sex- specific vulnerabilities in brain cells and regions across the AD spectrum. Outcomes are highly relevant insights underlying sex difference driven molecular mechanisms and the influence of differential risk factors negatively impacting brain function at the cell, network, and connectome levels as they relate to the transition from healthy aging to pathologic neurodegeneration, topics of high interest under RFA-AG-21-029.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Narrative  Ocular exposure to mustard agents has harmfully affected thousands of soldiers and civilians, yet an effective medical countermeasure against the ocular injury of mustard agents still does not exist. The proposed study will investigate whether extracellular vesicles (EVs) derived from mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) can be developed as a topical drug for the treatment of mustard-induced ocular injury. Successful completion of the proposed study will provide valuable preclinical data of MSC-derived EVs in vesicant-induced corneal injury, which could facilitate the development of new and improved medical countermeasures against mustard agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The fundamental objective of our Trauma Research Center Training Program is to inspire the next generation of surgical trainees to pursue a career that includes basic science and translational investigations. Our secondary objective is to recruit capable surgeons as surgical investigators to the field of academic trauma surgery, in which lack of research has become a national crisis. As trauma continues to be the leading cause of death for individuals younger than 45 years of age, and the most common cause of preventable death is uncontrolled bleeding, training the next generation of clinician investigators in this field is our fundamental goal.

PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanisms of Trauma-Induced Coagulopathy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid overdose is a leading cause of death in the United States with approximately 49,000 deaths and 1.5 million Emergency Department (ED) encounters related to opioid misuse annually. ED-based interventions for opioid misuse are effective but limited in scale by barriers to the accurate detection of all patients who could benefit from these interventions. This proposal seeks to use machine learning approaches to better identify and characterize ED patients with opioid misuse so that timely treatments can be targeted to decrease opioid-related mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opioid syndemic is a public health crisis that consists of the overlapping epidemics of opioid misuse, fatal and non-fatal overdose, human immunodeﬁciency virus and hepatitis C. Accurate and local surveillance of community levels of opioid misuse is critical to inform public health policies but is extremely challenging. This project devel- ops new surveillance science methodology for opioid misuse that is built on imperfect surveillance data already collected by the existing public health infrastructure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Latinx men who have sex with men (LMSM) account for the majority of new HIV infections in South Florida and are one of the only populations in the US where HIV incidence is increasing. Expanded efforts are needed to optimize the benefits of PrEP in stimulant-using LMSM, especially approaches that address the role of key cultural factors (e.g., acculturation) and social networks in relation to stimulant use/HIV risk. The proposed formative clinical research aims to develop and pilot test a culturally tailored intervention targeting the intersection of substance use and HIV in Latinx men who have sex with men (LMSM).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Clinical trial populations are a subset of the overall population and may be biased through several factors. To better understand disease, reduce healthcare disparities for underrepresented groups, assess drug approvals, and ensure safety as the indications for a drug expand it is critical to quantify how representative clinical trials are of the real-world population. Identifying enriched and underrepresented groups offers the opportunity to identify subpopulations who may have heterogeneous treatment effects and/or underlying physiologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Synthetic analogs of nucleobase and nucleoside (NNA) are one of the most widely used classes of therapeutic agents with broad activities as anti-cancer and/or anti-viral agents. NNA drugs are frequently associated with dose-limiting toxicities and their pharmacologic effects vary significantly across patients, and there is a pressing need to understand the biological basis of inter-patient variability in NNA drug response and to develop genetics- based treatment individualization for safe and more effective therapy. Building upon our NIGMS-funded work in the past 5 years focusing on pharmacogenetics of thiopurines, we now propose to expand this program to characterize pharmacogenetic factors related to efficacy and side effects of NNA drugs broadly, e.g., to identify genetic variants linked to antiviral effects of ganciclovir and to characterize the role of human NUDIX enzymes in NNA drug metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Sleep disruption is now recognized not only as an early symptom of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), but also a contributor to its ongoing development, and thus sleep enhancement is a promising approach to slow the disease. This proposal intends to provide new technology to facilitate preclinical studies in AD model mice, including long term monitoring of behaviors associated with disease progression, and a new method to manipulate and enhance sleep in mice to assess effects on disease and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Metalloredox reactions lie at the heart of many key biological processes, from the one electron Fe2+/Fe3+ redox cycle in ferroptosis-associated neurodegenerative diseases and bacterial infection to the multi-electron enzymatic transformations that power biological respiration and the global nitrogen and sulfur cycles, but the structure-function relationships underpinning these phenomena are key gaps in our knowledge that hamper our ability to address significant health challenges. To fill these gaps, we propose to engineer i) novel metal ion sensors for the spatiotemporal imaging of metal ion redox states in biological systems, ii) protein-based structural and functional mimics of complex metalloenzymes responsible for multi-electron reactions, and iii) DNA-cleaving DNAzymes for smaller and more robust alternatives to restriction enzymes and CRISPR/Cas. Achieving these goals will not only advance our knowledge of redox processes in metalloproteins and biological systems, but also expand the toolbox for designing metalloenzymes, real-time diagnostic imaging of mobile metal ions, and customizable recombinant DNA cloning and high-fidelity genome editing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Interactions within bacterial communities are highly regulated by microbial, host, and environmental factors, and these interactions have a significant role in microbial competition and the host response. Reactive nitrogen species (RNS) derived from microbes plays a significant role in the behavior and function of mixed species communities. Using molecular genetics, systems biology tools, and a Drosophila melanogaster model our mechanistic studies will increase our understanding about how RNS production within polymicrobial communities drives bacterial competition and the host response to microbes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Many people with schizophrenia experience reductions in motivation, which impair occupational functioning, reduce quality of life, and increase public health demands. Recent work has provided strong evidence that abnormal effort-cost decision-making, calculations performed to weigh the “cost vs. benefits” of actions, may be a key contributor to motivational deficits in SZ. This proposal aims to determine the psychological and neural mechanisms of effort-cost decision-making impairment in people with schizophrenia, using computational modeling techniques, to better identify treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sjögren disease is a complex, chronic autoimmune disease that leads to severe dry mouth with complications due to poor oral health and severe dry eye disease with potential for vision- threatening complications. Despite being one of the most common autoimmune rheumatologic diseases, affecting up to 4 million Americans, the cause of Sjögren disease is unknown. The goal of this research is to define the mechanisms by which the immune system is driven to attack saliva producing glands–the hallmark of Sjögren disease–which will lead to better early diagnostic tests and new treatments for this and other autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Medication treatments for opioid use disorder (MOUD) are the most effective tools for improving outcomes and preventing overdose among persons with OUD. However, there is a significant discrepancy between MOUD effectiveness achieved in clinical trials and in real world settings-what NIDA has termed the research-to- practice gap-which may be partially attributable to differences between clinical trial populations and those in the real world. In this work, we will unite design and analytic strategies to bridge MOUD trial evidence to target populations by: 1) empirically identifying those individuals not represented or under-represented in MOUD trials, and 2) accurately and reliably generalizing expected MOUD effects on treatment retention to the adult Medicaid population, with the broad goal of optimizing the generalizability and policy-relevance of future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE β-cells derived from human stem cells represent a transformative, unlimited source of insulin-producing cells for the treatment of type 1 diabetes, but translation of these cells is hindered by the lack long-term engraftment and function without chronic immunosuppression and use of encapsulation devices that limit engraftment. The objective of this project is to engineer advanced biomaterial delivery technologies to (i) enhance vascularization, survival, and engraftment of SC-β cells and (ii) protect them from rejection by the immune system without the need for encapsulation or chronic immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiomyopathy patients are at risk for sudden cardiac death and progressive heart failure, but improving treatments depends on our learning more about how heart function is perturbed by specific mutations in ‘titin,’ a key protein controlling the contraction of heart muscle. Our research will reveal how a series of titin mutations cause heart failure by determining how they change contraction of engineered heart tissues (which are models of human heart muscle) and how they change the levels of titin protein and other proteins important to the heart. This research has the potential to reveal patient-specific insights into cardiomyopathy disease development and lead to new treatments that prevent heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Over 7 million adults older adults are hospitalized in the US annually and older adults are often discharged with changes to medications for chronic conditions which are not directly related to their reason for hospitalization. In current practice, neither prior chronic disease control nor key geriatric issues such as multimorbidity, polypharmacy, or cognition appear to influence discharge prescribing decisions, thus, there is an urgent need to reorient the current approach to hospital management of older adults’ chronic conditions from a number- driven to a patient-centered decision-making process. With this proposed project, we will develop and pilot test an innovative clinical decision framework which will incorporate geriatric principles to individualize chronic medication discharge prescribing decisions for hospitalized older adults, thereby improving the health and wellbeing of older adults in the peri-hospitalization period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative T cells coordinate systemic immunity and are essential for defense against pathogens. Systematic molecular analysis of T cells and of T cell interactions with other cell types across tissues is fundamentally important for better understanding of mechanisms of the adaptive immune system and critical for developing better T cell modulation therapies for infectious diseases and autoimmunity. The goal of our research program is to employ innovative experimental genomics to build multi-dimensional data resources and develop new computational algo- rithms that we will use to obtain a comprehensive molecular understanding of T cell activation and differentiation in response to various stimuli across biological contexts in mouse and human.

PHR: The arenavirus family of the Bunyavirales order includes old world arenaviruses (such as Lassa fever virus and lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus) and new world viruses (such as Wachupo virus, Pichinde virus and Junin virus). The proposed structural and functional studies of lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus facilitates development of vaccines and antiviral agents against arenaviruses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life stress greatly increases the risk for developing psychiatric illness later in life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The mission of the Center for Advancing Sociodemographic and Economic Study of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (CeASES‐ADRD) is to advance innovative social science ADRD research, to increase knowledge and technical capability of social science researchers, to broaden and diversify the set of researchers working in the field and, to disseminate resources and communicate findings for impact. CeASES‐ADRD targeted research themes are social and economic burden of ADRD over the life course, and national and international trends and projections of ADRD and were chosen to fill research gaps of some of the most pressing and immediate challenges of ADRD and to align with multiple NIA Strategic Directions. CeASES‐ADRD strengths include: (1) a multidisciplinary research team from University of Southern California, University of Texas, Austin, and Stanford; (2) the development of a unique set of interrelated programs hosted over 2.5 days each year including the Science of ADRD for Social Scientists program, ADRD research network meetings, and methodological and technical workshops; and (3) the uniting of key resources including USC Schaeffer Center’s external affairs staff for dissemination of findings, a research programming staff and data librarian for technical support and expertise, and multiple NIA‐funded Centers including a Resource Center for Minority Aging Research, an Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center and a Roybal Center in Health Policy Simulation for network building and driving innovative science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The burden of hypertension and related cardiovascular disease, stroke, and end-stage kidney disease is disproportionally high in Black populations, especially in the South. This cluster randomized trial will test the effectiveness, implementation, and sustainability of a church wellness coordinator-led multifaceted intervention compared to enhanced usual care on hypertension control in Black communities. This study will generate evidence on an effective, scalable, and sustainable strategy for eliminating hypertension disparities in Black communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Many of the diseases of old age like cancer and Alzheimer’s disease, as well as the process of aging itself, have been linked to changes in the composition of microbes in our gut. In addition, the ability of our gut to keep toxic microbial fragments out of our bloodstream declines with advanced age and results in inflammation. We have discovered a normal gut bacterium called Parabacteroides distasonis (Pd) that strengthens the gut barrier and blocks inflammation in mice and extends lifespan in fruit flies – we now seek to understand whether Pd can extend lifespan and healthspan in mice and gain a comprehensive understanding of how it works.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Centromeric satellites and their binding protein partners are engaged in an evolutionary arms race such that each side is continuously evolving. As a result, centromeres are one of the most divergent genomic elements in geographically isolated populations, which ultimately lose the ability to exchange genetic material and become two species. Our evolutionary-guided approach investigates the role of centromere divergence in forging the reproductive barriers (male hybrid infertility) between populations using genomics, cell biology and genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The CURS program addresses the lack of diversity in biomedical research, which is rooted in the limited number of under-represented students entering the field of science, ultimately affecting the goals and direction of research. Underserved communities suffer from a lack of representation at the decision-making level in science, in terms of policy issues and the determination of priorities for conducting research. Therefore, the CURS program addresses the critical need to increase the pipeline of highly qualified trainees into cardiovascular science.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Combining a modified dietary approaches to stop hypertension (modDASH) eating plan with a home-based exercise program may be a new method that people with peripheral artery disease can do to optimally improve walking ability, quality of life, vascular function, and vascular inflammation. These improvements could also improve the long-term risks of having major cardiovascular events, as well as improve other health conditions such as obesity, diabetes, high cholesterol, and high blood pressure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our skin acts as a barrier to protect us from water loss and pathogen invasion, which is a process critically dependent on epithelial stem cells that constantly regenerate the epidermis and promote hair growth. Immune protection of stem cell niches in the skin is necessary to maintain barrier integrity; however, the mechanisms of immunoprotection that prevent autoimmune attack of cutaneous epithelial stem cells is unknown. Our research is focused on understanding these protective mechanisms in order to develop novel therapeutic strategies to treat skin conditions that are the result of immune-mediated destruction of epithelial stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The MSTP at Cornell’s College of Veterinary Medicine (CVM) aims to develop a diverse pool of well-trained veterinary clinician-scientists with the disciplinary knowledge and skills that will uniquely prepare them for leadership roles in biomedical research to advance human health at the individual and population levels. By virtue of their broad knowledge of comparative disease and strong intellectual and lateral thinking abilities, veterinary clinician-scientists are uniquely suited to play key roles in advancing NIH goals in biomedical science and public health. Funding from the proposed MSTP will allow us to provide comprehensive programming and opportunities for Combined DVM-PhD Degree trainees, foster a spirit of diversity and inclusion, and nurture the research and professional skills necessary for our future leaders to tackle some of the most important biomedical problems we face in the 21st century.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: Coronary artery disease is a major health problem in the world, leading to significant morbidity and mortality. In studies proposed here, Drs. Muzumdar and Dutta will evaluate the potential of a new peptide called Humanin to protect the heart following ischemia-reperfusion and prevent progression to heart failure in a clinically relevant mouse model of aging, and examine the mechanisms that mediate the cardioprotection. Humanin could be a potential new treatment option for treatment of acute myocardial infarction and prevention of progression to heart failure in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The progressive nature of pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) progression represents a major hurdle in designing effective therapies. Our recent studies have shown that in IPF lungs, a unique type of protein oxidation occurs which involves attachment of glutathione to proteins (termed glutathionylation). We also showed that treatment of fibrotic mouse lung with the protein oxidation repair enzyme, glutaredoxin, reversed existing pulmonary fibrosis. Most recently we discovered that collagen, which makes up scar tissue, can be glutathionylated and this not only makes it resistant to normal degradation processes but also activates myofibroblasts, which are collagen- producing cells, thereby creating a potentially fibrosis-progressive scenario. In this project we examine how collagen glutathionylation occurs and how it activates myofibroblasts. We will study whether this process is disturbed in aged lung and if this is reversible by glutaredoxin. Given that we have developed pure glutaredoxin preparations, completion of the studies may have potential impact for the treatment of persistent fibrosis in aged lungs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury (AKI) is characterized by a sudden decrease in the ability of the kidneys to adequately maintain electrolyte, acid-base, and fluid balance. Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) has recently emerged as the preferred dialysis modality for critically ill children and is becoming increasingly common for newborns and small children (under 10 kg) with AKI and congenital kidney failure. While frequent monitoring of anticoagulant therapy, kidney function, and electrolyte composition is necessary during the course of CRRT, existing laboratory tests require large blood volumes, contributing to iatrogenic anemia and subsequent blood transfusions. To meet the critical unmet need for rapid, low volume blood tests for CRRT monitoring in newborns and children, we will develop a panel of four assays on our near-patient digital microfluidic platform to provide comprehensive profiling of anticoagulation dosing, kidney function, and phosphorus balance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Invasive cervical cancer disproportionately burdens women living with HIV (WLWH) and can be prevented with appropriate screening coupled with effective treatment of cervical precancerous lesions. We propose to establish a CASCADE Network UG1 Research Base at the University of North Carolina to develop, implement, and analyze hybrid effectiveness-implementation trials of innovative, yet pragmatic, strategies to reduce cervical cancer among WLWH. If strategies are found to be clinically effective, acceptable, and cost-effective, CASCADE Trial findings have potential to inform clinical practice guidelines to ultimately reduce cancer disparities among WLWH in the United States and low-and-middle income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fermentation of non-digestible, complex dietary polysaccharides by distal gut microbes can enhance and maintain beneficial microbes in the distal gut and generate immune regulatory metabolites. Therefore, identification and functional characterization of microbial metabolites from complex dietary polysaccharide degradation could lead to the development of precision -nutrition and -medicine approaches to prevent and treat immune-mediated disorders. Our proposed studies are expected to identify novel microbial metabolites of candidate complex dietary polysaccharide degradation and functionally characterize them for the ability to enhance gut and systemic immune regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adult neural stem cells (NSCs) are a population of cells in the adult brain that can self-renew and give rise to a variety of cell types, including neurons. NSCs are of tremendous interest for both their potential role in neural development and disease and because they may be harnessed in various ways to treat neurodegenerative disease (e.g., Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and Lou Gehrig’s Diseases). The goal of this proposal is to understand mechanisms through which biomechanical inputs from the cellular microenvironment influence NSC neurogenesis, which we expect will significantly add to our understanding of NSC biology and help inform the design of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine strategies to treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: An HIV cure has proven elusive given the persistence of HIV in tissue sanctuaries in people with HIV on suppressive anti-HIV drugs. A better understanding of the source of HIV rebound when anti-HIV drugs are halted is needed in order to guide effective HIV cure strategies. Our long-term goals are 1) understanding HIV and SIV reservoirs in both CD4 T cells and myeloid cells across the central nervous system (CNS) and lymphoid tissues, 2) developing a cellular immunotherapy using virus-specific chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells that target tissue reservoirs of HIV in the CNS and lymphoid tissues that durably suppress HIV replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Heterotopic ossification (HO) is the pathologic formation of extra-skeletal bone that forms almost exclusively at sites of mechanical stress. We purport that discoidin domain receptor 2 (DDR2) and injury site immobilization modify extra-cellular matrix alignment and thus changes cell fate through downstream mechanotransductive signaling. Determination of the underlying mechanisms responsible for HO will enable us to validate clinically relevant mobilization protocols and mechanotransductive therapies to combat this currently untreatable disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lineage-specific cell differentiation is controlled by gene transcription in chromatin that is fundamental to human biology and diseases. While key transcriptional and chromatin regulators have been identified, it remains elusive as to how they work in concert to direct ordered gene expression in chromatin in response to physiological and environmental cues. In this study, we will investigate the fundamental transcriptional mechanisms required for specification of disease-causing cell types, and establish a new therapeutic strategy for future development of more effective and safer treatment of allergic inflammation such as asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical activity has extensive and well-documented neuroprotective effects, benefitting cognitive function during healthy aging and reducing the risk of Alzheimer Disease (AD). However, the mechanisms responsible for these benefits remain largely unknown, making identification of the circulating signals that underlie the CNS-targeting benefits of exercise a major advance for developing CNS rejuvenating therapeutics against AD. The following studies address muscle proteostasis, a pathway highly activated during exercise, as a potential new regulator of the neurocognitive benefits of exercise, as well as new therapeutic intervention for preservation of CNS function in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Early onset Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (EOD) is a devastating but under-studied condition. We propose here to pool and rigorously harmonize data to create a cohort with a sizable number of EOD events to estimate EOD incidence in the general population, identify predisposing and/or protective physiologic and behavioral risk factors, and study whether a favorable midlife risk profile in the presence of genetic predisposition delays the occurrence of EOD. Findings will provide actionable insights regarding targets for delaying the onset of EOD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver metastasis are a common cause of cancer-related deaths and are associated with a poor response to immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) immunotherapy. Although liver-directed radiation improves the ability of ICB to control liver metastasis, response rates are often short-lived. Novel immunotherapeutic approaches that can stimulate antitumor immunity in the liver have the potential to boost liver-directed radiation plus ICB mediated control of liver metastasis. Towards this end, our research will advance our liver trophic immunotherapy drug called entolimod as a way to improve liver-directed radiotherapy and ICB response rates. The fact that entolimod, liver-directed radiotherapy, and ICB are in the cancer clinic ensures the feasibility of combining these therapies into a single novel and effective therapy to improve the dire survival outcomes in patients with liver metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The ability of bacteria to actively export antibiotics out of their cells through efflux pumps is a prominent mechanism contributing to the escalating global antibiotic resistance health crisis. My research will investigate how specific efflux systems belonging to a family of pumps found in many pathogenic bacteria accomplish the essential processes of antibiotic uptake and recognition for export out of the cell. In addition to providing me the interdisciplinary training necessary to become an independent researcher, my results will enhance our understanding of efflux pump activity/ function and could support development of new pump inhibitors or guide redesign of current therapeutics to reduce their export while retaining antibiotic efficacy.

PHR: Discovery of Drugs that Modulate Neuroinflammation for the Treatment of Alzheimer's Disease Narrative We identified a drug that reduces inflammation and increases the synthesis of a protective neurosteroid in the brains of animal models of neurodegeneration, and believe an improved analog may have utility to treat Alzheimer’s Disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Lipidomic studies have identified multiple dysregulated lipid metabolic pathways in aging brain and neruodegeneration, however, synthesis of these data sets, which are often incomplete, has not yet yielded a clear understanding of mechanisms of lipid dyshomeostasis in aging. Imaging Mass Spectrometry is an emerging technology that has not yet been applied exhaustively to aging and mouse models of neurodegeneration and has potential to furnish valuable spatial information in mouse brain. We will test the hypothesis that genetic manipulation of dysregulated lipid metabolic pathways in the brain can rescue cognitive, functional and pathological deficits associated with Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease affects millions of people in the United States and worldwide, yet no effective treatments exist for this devastating neurodegenerative disease of aging. This research project aims to better understand the protein changes that occur in the brain during Alzheimer’s disease so that we can develop therapies to treat the disease. It also aims to use this improved understanding to develop better diagnostic tests for Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake plays an essential role in regulating ATP production, buffering cytosolic Ca2+, maintaining redox homeostasis and triggering cell death; dysregulation of these Ca2+ uptake mechanisms has been implicated in several neuromuscular, cardiac and metabolic diseases. The proposed work utilizes application of direct electrophysiological methods on the native mitochondrial membranes to study the gating of mitochondrial Ca2+ uniporter (MCU), the principal pathway for mitochondrial Ca2+ entry. This work will potentially identify novel molecular mechanisms that can be therapeutically targeted to modulate MCU activity in disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Acylcarnitines are a lipid in the blood that are known to be elevated during obesity and are known to cause insulin resistance. In this proposal we describe the discovery and functional characterization of a novel transporter that shuttles acylcarnitines from the blood into cells. We will investigate the impact of the loss of this transporter on metabolic health allowing us to identify new physiological and molecular mechanisms that can be targeted for the treatment of type 2 diabetes and obesity related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proper assembly and maintenance of neural circuits in the retina is essential to visual function and becomes deranged in the setting of inherited retinal disorders. The primary objective of this proposal is to investigate fundamental mechanisms of synapse formation, maintenance, and specificity between photoreceptors and bipolar cells in the human retina by using stem cell-derived human retinal organoids. The proposed studies will together determine the logic underlying human retinal synapse formation and identify potential therapeutic targets to preserve or regenerate synaptic connectivity in the disease state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 10% of babies worldwide are born premature, and at risk for poor vision and neurologic impairments later in life. There remains an unmet need to understand how postnatal exposures change eye development in premature infants and whether the eye can provide a window to elucidate changes that are happening in the brain. Our study will utilize non-invasive eye imaging with optical coherence tomography and angiography in neonates requiring intensive care to: (1) help us understand how the retina and its blood supply are affected by oxygen use and retinopathy of prematurity treatment in the immediate postnatal period, and (2) inform about whether measurements taken from these postnatal non-invasive eye pictures can predict later retinopathy of prematurity, vision, and neurodevelopmental outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in therapy, people with HIV (PWH) continue to experience adverse health consequences, which appear to be due in part to inflammation that persists even after viral replication is suppressed. Cannabis can reduce inflammation and PWH use it more frequently than people without HIV but little is known about its beneficial and detrimental effects in this population. The proposed translational, multimodal research project seeks to address key scientific gaps to identify the biological mechanisms underlying the effects of cannabis use on persistent inflammation in PWH and its corresponding impact on the medical, neuropsychiatric, and neurocognitive consequences of HIV disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research seeks knowledge that will inform effective strategies for a vaccine that protects against HIV-1 by inducing broadly active neutralizing antibodies, and for using such antibodies optimally to treat infection. The research is therefore relevant to public health because, according to UNAIDS, as of 2021 38 million people were living with HIV, of whom 10 million lacked access to antiretroviral therapy, while 1.5 million people became newly infected with the virus and 650,000 died from AIDS and related illnesses that year. The application focuses on the molecular basis of the binding by neutralizing antibodies in relation to their breadth and efficacy of action, aiming to inform not only vaccine development but also the use of neutralizing antibodies to treat or prevent infection.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals suffering from metabolic dysfunction are at an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and depression, all of which correlate with increased mortality and years lived with disability and, importantly, are influenced by factors such as chronic stress. This proposal will determine whether activation of a specific frontal cortex to brainstem circuit mitigates the effects of chronic stress on glucose homeostasis and Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal axis activation. Determining the neurocircuitry that regulates blood glucose during prolonged stress is vital to advance our understanding and, potentially, address the increasingly prevalent stress-related metabolic disorders that burden our society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The chronic abuse of alcohol causes alcoholic cardiomyopathy, which is characterized by cardiac fibrosis and heart failure. Treatment and prevention strategies are limited, as the damaging cardiac effects of chronic alcohol abuse are poorly understood. Our studies will identify key mechanisms of alcohol-induced fibrosis and cardiac dysfunction, which can then be targeted for therapeutic benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Neurotropic RNA viruses continue to emerge at an increasing rate, causing severe acute neuroinvasive syndromes with majority of survivors exhibiting significant neurocognitive deficits that persist for years after clearance of virus. Most of these are vector-borne infections, however, the most recently emerged RNA viruses, Zika virus and severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV)-2, can be transmitted person-to-person. In addition, evidence that viruses trigger the development of neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease and other dementias, is mounting. There are limited studies of the mechanisms of post-infectious, progressive pathological forgetting, which are poorly understood. There are also currently no diagnostic or treatment modalities for cognitive sequelae in patients that recover from viral infections of the central nervous system,.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance The proposed research will elucidate mechanisms by which atherosclerosis can be regulated by small nucleolar RNAs that affect cellular levels of reactive oxygen species. Understanding the function of small nucleolar RNAs in vascular smooth muscle cells and in macrophages may lead to new therapeutic interventions to treat atherosclerosis, which is the leading cause of heart attack and stroke. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CAR T cell therapy has revolutionized the treatment of relapsed/refractory B cell malignancies, but most people treated with CAR T cells don’t have durable responses, indicating that to improve CAR T cell therapy, we need better tools to measure how patients are responding. Existing tools to monitor a patient's cellular and molecular immune response to CAR T cell therapy are limited, so we developed antigen-multimer technology, which outperforms most available reagents in CAR T-cell labeling, and is useful in CAR T-cell detection, isolation, and downstream phenotypic and functional analyses. In this application, we propose to demonstrate the flexibility and broad applicability of antigen-multimer technology in labeling four different CARs, and by applying these reagents to analyze patient biospecimens using single-cell multicolor flow cytometry and multi-omics analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis is a leading infectious killer worldwide. TB preventive therapy (TPT) is highly efficacious but poorly implemented. New shorter regimens that have better adherence and safety are now available and can contribute to epidemic control. We plan to conduct a randomized trial of one-month of daily rifapentine and isoniazid compared with three months of the same drugs given weekly in people without HIV infection to determine adherence to and safety of these regimens. We will also assess the cost-effectiveness of these two regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Rhinovirus-induced exacerbations of asthma represent a significant health burden to children and adults, and pose a significant challenge in controlling and preventing asthma-related deaths. The molecular mechanisms by which rhinovirus decreases efficacy of current therapeutics used to treat asthma and exacerbations of the disease are unclear. Current asthma therapies dampen inflammation, and/or promote opening and reduce bronchoconstriction of airway smooth muscle that modulates tone of the airway. Our preliminary data suggests that rhinovirus exposure of epithelial cells that line the airways results in decreased bronchodilator responses in airway smooth muscle. Our proposal aims to identify novel therapeutic targets to reverse rhinovirus-induced hyposensitivity to bronchodilators, that when given with current bronchodilators would thereby allow these therapeutics to work more effectively in treatment of virus-induced asthma exacerbations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer remains the second leading cause of mortality in the United States. While immunotherapies, including checkpoint inhibitors hold great promise, most patients do not respond to immunotherapy and resistance mechanisms are incompletely defined. This proposal will use genetic murine tumor models to determine the mechanistic role of tumor cell-intrinsic hypoxia inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α activation in impairing the anti-tumor T cell response within the tumor microenvironment and promoting immunotherapy resistance.

PHR: Project Narrative Age-related cognitive deficits are a growing public health problem for our aging society, especially in the Information Age when higher cognitive functions are required to manage finances and medical care and allow people to live independently. The goal of the proposal is to develop brain-penetrant glutamate carboxypeptidase II (GCPII) inhibitors for the treatment of age-related cognitive disorders through novel actions in the association cortex. The successful execution of this project will lead to a novel therapeutic strategy with greater feasibility for clinical translation to address the main healthcare needs of the growing elderly population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Role of XPD in DNA Damage Response Pathway Choice We have discovered that the nucleotide excision repair factor (NER), XPD occupies a pivotal role in mediating survival/death decisions following DNA damage. We will elucidate the mechanism by which XPD influences cellular fate outcomes and determine the role of XPD-mediated pathway choice in maintaining genomic integrity. We expect that this work will provide insight into the regulatory mechanisms that facilitate crosstalk within the DNA damage response network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Black and low-income populations are disproportionately affected by obesity and its comorbidities, including cardiovascular disease. Although primary care health care providers could play an important role in providing tangible and practical lifestyle advice to prevent childhood obesity, they lack efficient and effective tools to engage parents and evoke change. This study will develop, assess, and evaluate the acceptability, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy of two visual communication tools that incorporate culturally relevant brief behavior change counseling grounded in motivational interviewing, to facilitate engagement in behavioral lifestyle counseling between primary care health care providers and Black parents from low-income households who are affected by obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Taste and appetite are inherently intertwined, yet very little in known about the cortical circuits that integrate gustatory perception and expectation with interoception related to hunger/satiety. The gustatory cortex has been extensively studied for its involvement in taste perception and expectation, and for its role in mediating taste- related behaviors, decisions and learning. Recent data show that cortical responses to taste, anticipatory cues and spontaneous activity are affected by hunger and thirst. Yet, the nature and the function of these interoceptive homeostatic signals in the cortex is poorly understood. Here we propose to address this gap, focusing on a population of gustatory cortical neurons expressing gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP), a feeding-suppressing peptide. Neurons containing GRP are ideal candidates to integrate gustatory perception, expectation and interoception, and drive behavior through release of GRP.  We will combine anatomical and electrophysiological analyses, cellular imaging and manipulations of neural activity to unveil the organization and function of GRP in the circuit involving the gustatory cortex and the basolateral amygdala. The results of this research will advance our understanding of the neural basis of taste- based consumption and help us revise existing models of the function of the gustatory cortex. In addition to furthering our knowledge, this work will test the validity of GRP as a target for modulating feeding behaviors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The need for rigorously trained infectious diseases epidemiologists has never been more evident than during the CoVID-19 pandemic of the past two years. The Training in Infectious Diseases Epidemiology (TIDE) T32 training program fills a unique and critical training niche in preparing academic and clinical researchers in interdisciplinary infectious diseases epidemiology. Funded for 15 years, we seeks to continue for another 5 years our work to train first-class academic and clinical infectious diseases epidemiology researchers to combat the infectious diseases of today and prepare for those of tomorrow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral demyelinating disease is a prevalent disorder of the PNS that affects myelin, and the prognosis of these diseases is poor with no available cure. Therefore, understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate Schwann cell myelination and myelin repair is important for developing therapeutic strategies to improve the prognosis of the patients. Upon conclusion of the proposed study, we will 1) understand how choline, which is an important precursor to myelin membrane, is imported into Schwann cell, 2) understand how choline metabolism regulates Schwann cell myelination and 3) gain important insights into understanding the implication of choline metabolism in developing therapeutic strategies to treat peripheral demyelinating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: In the 21st century the biomedical sciences will have ever increasing roles in improving health as well as acting as an engine of economic growth, so it is central to America's future to train the next generation of biomedical scientists. At the center of the biological revolution has been the understanding of basic cell mechanics using cell and molecular biology techniques. For 35 years the Cell and Molecular Biology graduate training program at the University of Virginia has turned out leaders in biological research that populate laboratories in companies, thinktanks and universities throughout the country. This has always been an inclusive program that has had over 20% of its trainees from under represented populations and produced outstanding graduation rates. This proposal outlines a bold restructuring of this program with the introduction of a number of student- centered activities to modernize our Ph.D. training program and to continue this proud training tradition.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Cell and Molecular Biology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Every day, humans and rodents alike are faced with opportunities to learn, store, and remember events. It is challenging to remember distinct events that are very similar, particularly under conditions of chronic stress. Neuroscience and clinical practice for memory dysfunction would both greatly benefit from understanding the brain circuitry that underlies this multi-stage discrimination of very similar events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy is a critically important technique in biomedical research with a unique ability to detect naturally occurring or engineered unpaired electrons in complex biological environments. I focus on the development of three technical and method developments that significantly improve X-band EPR sensitivity for three classes of samples: small to medium-sized (0.1–3 nl) protein single crystals, volume-limited frozen samples (85 nl), and microfluidic (500 nl) with microfluidic sample handling. The combination of these prototypes will be easy to use and widely available to the scientific community, enabling a wide range of new applications in biomedical EPR spectroscopy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Cochlear implants cause scarring in the ears of humans and rodents who subsequently can experience implantation induced hearing loss, but the processes causing this hearing loss are not fully understood. We will measure sound evoked vibrations inside implanted guinea pig ears, to understand how inner ear scarring impacts hearing, and also compare this data to 3D scans of the scarring in each inner ear. Understanding how scarring impacts remaining hearing mechanics following implantation will help to improve implants or develop treatments to prevent implant induced hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Although we now have the power to routinely sequence human genomes, most genetic variants discovered in patients are of uncertain consequence. Predictive models of complex traits, which are caused by large ensembles of genetic changes acting together, are therefore key to realizing the goals of personalized medicine. We propose to use a powerful genetic model system to build a mechanistic understanding of which variants impact complex traits and how they do so, with far-reaching implications for interpreting the functional consequences of genetic variation and for the diagnosis and treatment of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Alterations in the growth and differentiation of epidermal stem and progenitor cells can lead to a variety of disorders including non-melanoma skin cancers as well as chronic wounds. Thus a comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms that regulate epidermal growth and differentiation is necessary to understand the progression to disease. This proposal seeks to characterize the mechanisms of epidermal self-renewal and differentiation through the regulation of mRNA export.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Influenza virus infects millions globally each year and in some cases is complicated with bacterial super-infection, which can result in severe illness and/or death. This study addresses the mechanisms by which influenza makes the lung more susceptible to later bacterial infection. This proposal defines the molecular pathways by which influenza leads to suppressed Staphylococcus aureus host defense and attempts to identify novel therapeutic targets to improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Approximately one-third of adults in the United States has hypertension, which can have severe consequences on the retina in the eye. This disease is called hypertensive retinopathy, which occurs in 25% of those with mild hypertension, and in 85% of those with severe hypertension. The disease involves changes in the blood vessels of the retina, which will be studied in the proposed work. We plan to identify the specific structural changes in the blood vessel wall that can be targeted in future treatments to protect vision.

PHR: Project Narrative How health systems recover and respond in the face of major events, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, speaks to the structure of health systems and the policies that support them. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis B virus is a major human pathogen that replicates by reverse transcription of its pregenomic RNA within the viral capsid. Ten-eleven translocation (Tet) methylcytosine dioxygenases mediate the demethylation of HBV genomic DNA during liver development and therefore are essential for viral transcription, and hence replication, in vivo. A detailed understanding of the mechanism by which Tet-deficiency prevents viral biosynthesis without significantly altering liver physiology may permit the more effective design of antiviral therapies targeting this essential step in the viral life cycle. https://uic365-my.sharepoint.com/personal/mclach_uic_edu/Documents/Documents/MSword files/UIC/Grants/R01 Methylation 2/ProjectNarrative_Methylation_AMcL01.docx

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the role of selection, gene flow, and mutations in the formation and divergence of species is a principal goal of evolutionary biology. This research investigates how selection and hybridization affect the genome during the process of speciation and adaptation, which is relevant to the NIH’s mission as hybridization with ancient hominins contributed to variation (some adaptive) in modern humans. Studying genomic variation in an organism for which manipulative field experiments and laboratory studies can verify the cause and effect of mutations is critical for a broader understanding of how evolutionary forces cause divergence and speciation in all organisms, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative By asking people to report their behaviors, feelings, and social context in nearly real time, ecological momentary assessment (EMA) helps researchers better understand the causes of drug use so that just-in-time intervention strategies could be developed. However, EMA data are often partially missing, increasing the risks of drawing invalid research conclusions and developing ineffective interventions. Using simulated and existing data in a cost-effective way, the current study develops novel statistical methods to deal with missing data in EMA, which inform the development of better drug use interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromosomally abnormal pregnancies are the leading cause of miscarriage and birth defects. Most errors leading to chromosomally abnormal conceptions occur during egg development and their incidence is strongly influenced by maternal age. This project will make use of data amassed during ten-plus years of collaborative studies of human fetal ovaries to enhance our understanding of the earliest stages of oogenesis and test the hypothesis that disturbances that predispose to chromosomally abnormal eggs are increased by fetal exposure to manmade endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE State and federal policymakers have expanded access to residential treatment for substance use disorder (SUD) in the Medicaid program, broadening access to the full continuum of care, increasing the capacity in the greater SUD treatment system, and potentially spurring patients to seek care for an SUD. This project will examine the relationship between increasing coverage for residential treatment services among Medicaid beneficiaries with opioid use disorder and explore the implications of co-morbid SUDs. Through the proposed research and training in this Mentored Research Scientist Career Development Award, I will gain the additional skills and knowledge to pursue innovative, independent research to improve access to care and health outcomes for people with SUD in the U.S.
