IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer causes nearly as many deaths as the number of deaths resulting from breast, cervical, colorectal, and prostate cancers combined and rural areas are disproportionately impacted, but knowledge to inform effective interventions is limited. In this project, we will examine the uptake of bundled evidence-based interventions for prevention and early detection, examine the occurrence of modifiable gaps in the care received, and then conduct interviews with patients and healthcare professional to further understand why death rates may be higher in rural than urban areas. The innovative approaches we propose in socioeconomically diverse populations will allow us to inform interventions that can substantially improve outcomes in many communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Allergen-induced inflammation and increases in the amount of airway smooth muscle, fibroblasts, and extracellular matrix in the lung occur in asthma and contribute to disease progression and severity. We have identified a novel compound that selectively inhibits signaling molecules critical in the pathogenesis of asthma. Studies proposed in this application will use structure-guided computer-aided drug design to optimize the pharmacological properties of this compound and its ability to inhibit pathological features of asthma providing a framework for developing a new class of anti-asthma drugs and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  It is estimated that between 2.5 and 4 million Americans are living with aphasia today – a primary disorder of spoken and written language. This project addresses common problems experienced by people with aphasia, including difficulty retrieving known words for production, and problems retrieving the meanings of words. The proposed studies aim to elucidate how powerful learning principles derived from basic psychological research can be leveraged to confer maximal, sustained improvements in the naming or comprehension of treated words in people with aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adult mammalian heart is one of least regenerative organs. In this study, we will test whether manipulation of histone deacetylase 7 may promote adult cardiomyocyte proliferation and understand the potential underlying mechanisms. Our new findings will shed new light on how to promote heart regeneration, ultimately find a new treatment for heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Drugs of abuse usurp and modify communication between different types of neurons within defined circuits in the brain, resulting in stable changes in the expression and activities of proteins (the “neuroproteome”) required for normal neuronal function. Improving our understanding of how drugs of abuse alter the distinct neuroproteomes of the specific neuronal sub-types that define the circuits that underlie the actions and addictive properties of drugs of abuse will provide deeper insight into the molecular basis of drug addiction and thus help in the design of new and more effective therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The SARS-CoV-2 virus is a pandemic causing widespread COVID-19 respiratory disease and death globally. We have discovered that cow antibody CDR H3 “knob” domains can be made as independent small peptides, and have identified several such peptides that potently bind and neutralize the SARS-CoV-2 virus and its variants, including delta and omicron. We aim to discover a larger panel of these knob peptides and evaluate their efficacy as single agents, cocktails, and bispecific molecules on SARS-CoV-2 neutralization; this work could impact the current SARS-CoV-2 outbreak, as well as future novel coronavirus outbreaks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: We aim to elucidate the immunological basis of why otherwise healthy individuals develop severe COVID19 by studying the role of DPP9. Human genetics have highlighted the importance of DPP9 in response to SARS-CoV-2 infection, and our preliminary studies indicate this role is conserved in mice. We are therefore uniquely situated to determine how this susceptibility locus determines disease outcome to one of the biggest global health challenges in the last century.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Safe and effective strategies toward an HIV cure remain a clinically unmet challenge. This is due to HIV DNA integration in the host cell chromosome, where it remains in a latent state and persists in viral reservoirs. Upon cessation of ART, the virus reactivates and silent virus rebounds causing viremia and eventually progression toward AIDS. A highly effective, genetic strategy involving gene editing to excise viral DNA from the host together in concert with immune cell activation/improvement offers a promising curative strategy for the eradication of the virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The long-acting lipoglycopeptide dalbavancin can select for cross-resistance to vancomycin and daptomycin, which play critical roles in the management of invasive methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections. This cross-resistance is highly correlated with the emergence of mutations in the walKR pathway but it remains unclear how WalKR dysfunction leads to resistance to each agent or whether this resistance can be mitigated. Our interdisciplinary team proposes to use integrated and complementary techniques to determine the mechanisms through which walKR mutations lead to dalbavancin, vancomycin, and daptomycin cross- resistance, and to use beta-lactams and other metabolic modulators to re-sensitize mutants and prevent resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This grant will provide support for high quality, specialized training in the mechanistic bases of vision and related diseases with modern approaches to the development of technologies and therapies for eye disease. In addition, this training program will broaden the research perspective, communication skills and knowledge base of future vision scientists. The program is designed to have significant impact on the health and science agendas of the National Eye Institute and to prepare the next generation of PhD scientists to enter the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Giant Axonal Neuropathy is an autosomal recessive disease that results in early onset neurodegeneration. We have discovered that gigaxonin—the protein mutated in this disease—regulates the disassembly and degradation of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments. In this proposal we seek to elucidate the role of gigaxonin in neurons, in particular its part in modulating the levels of neuronal intermediate filaments along with identification of its other substrates, in order to understand the pathological basis of this disease and identify therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: The brain controls the kidney's excretion of salt, its release of the blood pressure controlling protein, renin and its ability to remove blood poisons through filtration, and it is likely that disorders in brain control lead to hypertension and sudden failure of kidney function. Until we can identify the specific nerve cells in the brain which control the kidney, we will not be able make progress in understanding how the brain controls kidney function. The studies proposed in this grant will identify which nerve cells in two parts of the brain (hypothalamus and medulla) actually control kidney function and in doing so will open the way for investigators to map out the brain circuits that control kidney function in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This grant proposes to develop the capability for accurate, reliable seizure forecasting and adaptive brain stimulation using advances in machine learning. Focal canine epilepsy is an excellent model for investigation of seizure forecasting and adaptive brain stimulation because of the clinical and electrophysiological similarity to focal human epilepsy. This is an initial step in establishing a new treatment paradigm for focal epilepsy, whereby the probability of seizure occurrence is continuously tracked for patient warning and intelligent responsive adaptive brain stimulation or pharmacological therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (limited to 2-3 sentences) Given the limited effectiveness of single food group-targeted interventions to enhance child nutrition, a key component of current and future health, innovative approaches are needed. Healthy dietary patterns are emerging as an important intervention target, and the Mediterranean Dietary pattern has been particularly effective at reducing cardiovascular disease risk factors, a leading cause of death in the US. Since parents are the gatekeepers of the home food environment and influence child intake through their food-related parenting practices, children enjoy cooking with their parents, and home food preparation is associated with more healthful dietary intake, we propose to develop and assess the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of an online cooking intervention for parent-child dyads living in low-income households that promotes the Mediterranean dietary pattern and healthful food-related parenting practices.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common neurologic disease caused by inflammation and damage to myelin, the fatty substance that insulates nerve fibers. Myelin repair may be an effective strategy to improve mobility and prevent disability in people with MS and, in animal models of MS, aerobic exercise has been shown to repair myelin independently or synergistically with medications. This project will investigate how damage to myelin impacts mobility in people with MS and will help design a future, full-scale trial using aerobic exercise with myelin repair medications to overcome and prevent MS disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Polysubstance use is a very common phenomenon that is generally thought to lead to worse outcomes than use of single substances. However, very little preclinical research has investigated polysubstance use, leading to a gap in our fundamental knowledge of how combinations of drugs may produce differential outcomes relative to single drug exposure. Thus, this project will use an established model of co-use of nicotine and THC, two of the most commonly co-used substances, to investigate neural mechanisms by which the two drugs interact to produce changes in dopamine neuron function and enhanced THC reinforcement.

PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed project has significant relevance to public health as it studies the role of a novel molecule with potential role in atherosclerosis. Atherosclerosis is the clogging of arteries which may lead to chest pain, heart attacks, heart failure or stroke, with atherosclerotic heart disease causing ≈1 of every 6 deaths in the United States according to the 2018 American Heart Association statistics. Findings from our proposed project will provide new insight into the mechanism of the disease, and could lead to therapies preventing or treating atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Epitranscriptomic marks on viral RNAs are emerging as important regulators of viral gene expression. In this project we will combine next generation sequencing technologies together with molecular assays to identify the nucleotide position of pseudouridine on Zika virus RNA and determine the function of this epitranscriptomic mark during virus infection in human and mosquito host cells. This research will broaden our knowledge of viral epitranscriptomics and possibly identify novel targets for antiviral therapeutics targeting Zika virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Predicting the impact of disease variants on molecular and cellular function is essential to uncovering disease mechanisms and discovering therapeutics. In this proposal, we aim to understand genomic regulatory function by integrating ever-evolving functional genomics data. The tools that we will develop to predict the functional impact of disease risk variants, predict the genes impacted by disease variants, and defining the pathways impacted by disease variants, will enable mechanistic understanding of a broad spectrum of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal aims to study the role of microglia in neuromyelitis optica, with particular focus on astrocyte-microglia interaction in the evolving spinal cord lesion. We anticipate the results will advance understanding of neuroimmune interaction in neuromyelitis optica and potentially justify therapeutic targeting of microglia in future management of patients with neuromyelitis optica. New principles and therapeutic strategies discovered may be applicable to other IgG-mediated disorders affecting the central nervous system and neurodegenerative neurological diseases with an inflammatory, complement-mediated component.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) affects ~70% of cancer patients in the first month and may persist indefinitely. Pain hypersensitivity and affective disorders impair patient quality of life, underscoring the need for new treatments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Retinal pigment epithelium cells, a population of cells that lies underneath and supports the neural retina, degenerates with aging and are believed to be the primary site for the initiation of age-related macular degeneration. Age-related modifications of genes and epigenetic changes disrupt youthful DNA patterns, resulting in cellular dysfunction and senescence; yet, it has been shown recently that these age-related modifications can be reversed through a process called “partial epigenetic reprogramming”. This application proposes to test the hypothesis that partial epigenetic reprogramming can reverse retinal pigment epithelial cell aging in vivo, their injury profile in vitro, and inhibit the formation of AMD-like pathologies in a mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ancestry contributes to differences in disease development and wound healing. This work will address critical gaps in our understanding of the relationship between ancestry and the cell responses in wound healing through biomaterial microenvironments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Myocardial infarction occurs in many types of congenital heart diseases and surgical treatments. Recent case reports indicate that newborn patients may be able to regenerate myocardium and recover from severe myocardial infarction that occurred shortly after birth. In this project, we will exploit the high regenerative capacity of neonatal pig heart model to decipher the mechanisms of heart regeneration in large mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emergence of Plasmodium falciparum strains with resistance to first-line artemisinin-combination therapies threatens malaria control and elimination efforts across the Horn of Africa. Improved understanding of the epidemiology and determinants of drug-resistant falciparum malaria, including infections by drug- and diagnostic-resistant strains with hrp2/3 deletions, is needed to inform clinical management and policy decisions in the region. We will conduct population surveys across Ethiopia and characterize resistant parasites, integrating our findings into a point-of-care clinical tool for identifying individuals with drug-resistant falciparum malaria and into a model to predict the future spread of resistance mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Protective immunity against viruses depends on memory cytotoxic CD8+ T cells – therefore, understanding how memory CD8+ T cell survive long-term will positively impact antiviral therapies and immunizations. We recently identified that sensing of the “danger signal” extracellular ATP (via its receptor P2RX7) induces antiviral memory CD8+ T cells, but it is still unclear (a) if P2RX7 imprints memory CD8+ T cell longevity in a subset of memory precursors or in all cells seeding the memory pool, and (b) how this receptor promotes long-lived memory in response to tissue-localized infections, especially the medically relevant influenza virus. These questions will be addressed in this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Buprenorphine is an evidence-based treatment for opioid use disorder that also has strong potential to reduce HIV transmission in people who use drugs. Rural health care professionals are eligible and critically needed to provide these medications, but stigma currently limits provider willingness to prescribe buprenorphine, especially in regions where mortality and HIV transmission secondary to opioid use are high. In this developmental trial, we will adapt, refine, and test the feasibility of a prototype brief stigma-reduction training intervention aimed at increasing buprenorphine prescribing in the rural primary care setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project narrative Despite promising new therapeutics, lung cancer remains a devastating disease and is the top cause of cancer mortality. We recently showed that a particular cellular metabolic process called oxidative phosphorylation is essential for growth of a subtype of lung cancer and discovered a potent chemical inhibitor of this process. In this proposal, we aim to perform in depth biological studies to better understand the mechanism of the metabolic rewiring in this lung cancer subtype and explore the therapeutic potential of inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation in such tumors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the phenomenon of subliminal priming has been known for decades, whether and how sensory information is encoded in the brain in the absence of awareness remains a mystery. We will perform multiple- electrode recording simultaneously in two visual cortical areas of non-human primate to examine the neural dynamics and coding of subliminal stimuli across neuronal circuits, and their impact on perceptual performance. Our research has the potential to advance our understanding of the neural underpinnings of vision while providing effective non-invasive therapies to treat the brain-based aspects of low vision conditions which can lead to life- altering benefits for many millions of people worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative By investigating opioid-related benefits and risk factors for harms in individuals with metastatic cancer, the proposed study will provide evidence that patients, family caregivers, and clinicians need when engaged in opioid-related decision-making. This has the potential to transform pain and opioid care for patients with metastatic cancer, and as such, is directly responsive to National Institute of Nursing Research priorities to improve the health of individuals with serious illness and the National Cancer Institute’s mission of helping people with cancer lead longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Depression doubles the risk of death in patients with coronary heart disease (CHD), but so far, there is insufficient evidence that we can reduce the risk of death by treating depression. This study will investigate the cardiac risk markers that are associated with depression symptoms that remain despite treatment, and identify potential targets for their treatment. The results of the study will inform the development of more effective interventions to improve both depression and survival in patients with CHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This study will contribute to the fundamental knowledge of how to remediate visual and cognitive deficits resulting from a mTBI to enhance the health, lengthen the life and reduce the disabilities that result from a mTBI. The goal of this study is to determine the feasibility of a timing intervention (PATH neurotraining) to significantly improve working memory, processing speed (primary outcomes) and auditory working memory, selective attention, cognitive flexibility, sustained attention, reading speed, and reading proficiency (secondary outcomes) in mTBI patients more than after either Sham or conventional working memory training The present work is a critical step towards establishing feasibility of PATH training and determining early stage data demonstrating efficacy and understanding individual differences regarding which participants with mTBI may be the best targets for these types of timing interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on optimizing outcomes for patients with severe aortic stenosis undergoing transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). Results from this study have the potential to change antithrombotic therapy guidelines for patients with valvular heart disease. The proposed work is relevant to the NHLBI's strategic goals to not only more effectively treat aortic stenosis but also, by advancing understanding of the thromboinflammatory response, improve thromboembolic and bleeding outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Viruses that are able to establish persistent or chronic infections have developed strategies to suppress immune mechanisms that would normally eradicate the virus. Regulating inflammation in the face of persistent infection is also critical as many of the long-term problems of chronic infection are due to persistent inflammation, including increased risk of developing cancer. Our new data have uncovered an unexpected role for IL-17 in helping to limit T cell activation and inflammation as persistent infection becomes established, and here we propose to explore the sources and functions of IL-17 in immunoregulation of antiviral response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance The ductus arteriosus (DA) is a fetal blood vessel whose patency is critical for survival in the womb, and whose closure is essential for adaption to newborn life. Persistent patency of the DA after birth (PDA) occurs frequently in preterm infants, increasing their risks for chronic lung disease and other complications. Because preterm infants are exposed to multiple drug combinations, this proposal will determine whether drugs used in the NICU may inadvertently impair DA closure and contribute to high rates of PDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intracranial aneurysms are extremely dangerous when they rupture. When one is detected, it may be treated or monitored through imaging, with aneurysm growth a strong indication of increased risk of rupture. This project will study how remodeling in the arteries of the Circle of Willis associates with aneurysm growth, and how blood flow may determine locations of remodeling, in order to identify new biomarkers to improve tracking and assessment of aneurysm progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on determining the pathways that lead to water accumulation during cytotoxic edema, a pathological state observed in multiple neurological injuries of the newborn, resulting in cell death and difficult to treat seizures. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein kinase signaling dynamics is highly heterogeneous in diseases such as cancer, but the biological origin and implications of such heterogeneity remain elusive. We plan to develop novel imaging probes and analytical methods for studying protein kinase signaling dynamics at single-cell resolution. Our results will help to understand the regulatory mechanisms that shape the kinetic patterns of protein kinase signaling activities and inform about therapeutic outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Activation of pattern recognition receptors initiates inflammatory signaling that is regulated by endocytosis. We have recently discovered that a protein that is mutated in patients of human ARC syndrome controls inflammatory responses induced by pattern recognition receptors by regulating endocytosis and phagocytosis. In this proposal we aim to study the molecular mechanisms by which this protein functions in cells of the innate immune system and the impact of its function on adaptive immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The goals of this proposal are to combine evolutionary and biochemical analysis to discover the genetic and structural mechanisms that caused the evolution of protein functions that play major roles in health and disease, including allosteric regulation of protein activity, formation of multimeric complexes, regulation of gene expression by transcription factors, and support for protein folding by chaperones. A better understanding of the genetic causes an consequence of protein evolution will allow more accurate interpretation of patterns of conservation and variability among modern-day proteins, improve our ability to predict the effects of genetic variation on health and disease, and aid in the design of proteins with desired properties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have shown that neurotensin (NT), a hormone localized predominantly to the small bowel, acts as a “thrifty” gene to efficiently absorb ingested fats; NT deficiency in mice protects against obesity, insulin resistance and hepatic steatosis associated with high fat diet consumption. Moreover, we found that elevated NT levels in humans is strongly predictive of future obesity. Our current studies, which will define the mechanisms regulating NT-mediated intestinal lipid absorption and fat metabolism in liver and adipose tissues, will significantly impact the fields of GI physiology and metabolism and may eventually lead to innovative therapies for diet-induced obesity and resultant metabolic disorders based on inhibition of NT signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project aims to elucidate which brain nuclei underlie the response to changes in whole body thermogenesis. This work will improve our understanding on thermogenesis identifying the molecular identity of neurons in premotor areas driving a thermogenic response, which could lead to the development of novel, cell type specific efficacious therapies for treating obesity. Furthermore, direct manipulation of identified neuronal subtypes will provide unprecedented information of how the coordinated sympathetic nervous system mediated thermogenesis response is produced.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Basal cancer is a complex and deadly subtype of breast cancer. In this study, we will combine next-generation sequencing technology and advanced computational methods to address some pressing issues and unmet clinical needs of basal cancer, including those related to 1) the derivation of accurate prognostic evaluation systems, 2) the delineation of the dynamic disease development process through progression modeling, and 3) the identification of pivotal, driving molecular events that present therapeutic opportunities. If successfully implemented, this study can significantly advance the basal cancer research, and pave the way for applying similar strategies to study other deadly cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arkansas is primarily a rural state that has a growing number of individuals living at or below the poverty level with limited access to health care, and many of these individuals are members of minority groups who face health care disparities that could potentially be reduced through health care workforce diversity. The goal of this project is to assist in increasing diversity among biomedical sciences' health professional students and faculty. Establishing a diverse biomedical science workforce will result in improved quality of medical education, improved access to health care for underserved populations, and accelerated advances in medical and public health research, as well as a reduction in health care disparities and improved public health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The healthcare system plays an integral role in the detection of intimate partner violence (IPV), a complex public health crisis with far-reaching consequences. Although the focus of IPV screening implementation at VHA to date has targeted women Veterans of reproductive age, the national IPV Assistance Program (IPVAP) is expanding IPV screening to Veterans of all genders and ages through a national rollout. Evaluating the implementation and clinical impact of this rollout, with a primary focus on identifying potential gender differences, is a critical priority for IPVAP. This robust and highly-partnered evaluation will (1) extend prior research conducted primarily with women Veterans; (2) provide critically needed clinical data to enhance and inform national programming; (3) result in the development of data systems essential for monitoring screening; and (4) lead to optimization of future IPV screening implementation strategies.

PHR: Linda Resnik is a physical therapist researcher whose work links the fields of rehabilitation and health services research. She focuses on three research areas: 1) design and evaluation of upper limb prosthetic devices; 2) development, evaluation, and deployment of rehabilitation outcomes measures; 3) study of delivery and effectiveness of rehabilitation services. Her research involves extensive relationships with clinician scientists, investigators, and VA clinical program leaders to maximize dissemination and implementation of findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immediate hypersensitivity reactions to drugs, foods, and other substances are diagnosed clinically based on symptoms, which is problematic due to a wide range of presentations, underlying mechanisms, and overlap with other disorders. Unfortunately, current known biomarkers are not sensitive enough to useful in all contexts of acute allergic reactions. This project will investigate the utility of circulating plasma extracellular vesicles as biomarkers for acute hypersensitivity reactions, which will provide clinicians with new tools for diagnosing these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a lung disease that affects infants born extremely premature, especially those that require mechanical ventilation. Type 1 pulmonary epithelial (AT1) cells are large gas-exchanging cells that are placed at a crucial interface of the outside environment and the underlying developing lung and have been recently found to be key contributors to the pulmonary matrisome. This proposal will identify how biophysical force on AT1 cells impacts matrisome-related gene expression and communication across the developing lung that predisposes to BPD and related comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer becomes an incurable lethal disease once it disseminates to distant organs and progresses to standard therapies. The proposed studies using patient datasets, mouse and patient-derived models will uncover targetable transcriptional mechanisms that contribute to lethal prostate cancer pathobiology. The molecular dissection of these mechanisms has the potential to generate effective therapeutic approaches for prostate cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: While the harms from psychoactive drug use are increasing among older adults in the United States, accurate estimates of the prevalence of psychoactive drug use, risk factors for use, chronic disease profile, and self- reported adverse outcomes associated with use among this population are lacking. This study testing a geriatric- based drug survey combined with biological drug testing in a diverse population of older adults will inform future epidemiology studies and provide critical prevention information to inform providers and policymakers across the spectrum of clinical care for older adults, including post-acute and long-term care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary fibrosis (PF) is scarring of the lungs that is often progressive leading to loss of lung function and death, and interstitial lung abnormalities (ILA) are common incidental findings on chest imaging that have been shown to carry adverse consequences and as such are felt to represent early PF. This project aims to identify the best method for the risk-stratification of ILA and to improve our understanding of the clinical, proteomic, and genetic factors that are associated with disease severity in ILA. The results of this work will help to identify which patients are at high-risk for adverse outcomes that may benefit from early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older persons may experience reduced physical function from a combination of frailty and heart disease. A dedicated physical rehabilitation program can lead to improvement in physical function in individuals with heart failure and frailty. We will study changes in ≈700 blood proteins in response to a rehabilitation program to further understand the human biology of impaired physical function and frailty with the goal of identifying targets to modify and follow in this critical aging process.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: African American and Hispanic Veterans use tobacco cessation treatment at lower rates than other White Veterans, despite greater tobacco use burden. Proactive outreach attempts to address barriers in initiating tobacco cessation treatment among African American and Hispanic Veterans is important. Development and implementation of health communication interventions that address barriers at multiple health care system levels that impede use of tobacco cessation treatment have been effective in increasing use among Veterans. However, few attempts have been made to develop health communication interventions specific for African American and Hispanic Veterans. Additionally, little is known about the barriers and facilitators in delivery of tobacco cessation treatment that impact African American and Hispanic Veterans, specifically. The goal of this CDA is to collaborate with Veterans, VA personnel, and stakeholders to improve initiation of tobacco cessation treatment for African American and Hispanic Veterans, while examining factors that impact their use treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will quantify sexual orientation-related disparities in unintended pregnancies and ad- verse perinatal outcomes, intersectional disparities by race/ethnicity, and the extent to which state-level poli- cies that are restrictive around reproductive health (e.g., those related to abortion and contraception) and poli- cies that are discriminatory (e.g., reflective of heterosexism and sexism) modify these disparities. There is a high potential for public health impact because the proposed research is an essential next step towards (1) identifying particular harmful policies for policy change, (2) elucidating the mechanisms by which state policies affect unintended pregnancies and their outcomes among SMW, and (3) laying the foundation for similar re- search in other stigmatized populations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Pressure injury (PrI) prevention is a major challenge for many Veterans with spinal cord injury (SCI), often leading to prolonged bedrest, hospitalization and even death. We have shown that sustained use of gluteal intermittent stimulation (iGSTIM) provides effective automated weight shifting and reduces PrI. Users said that long-term iGSTIM usage meant they no longer worried about recurrent skin problems, with daily use fitting easily into their lives. However, a fully implanted iGSTIM system was requested. We have also been contacted by many people desperate for a new alternative to PrI prevention and asking for a simple fully implanted system. We therefore developed the innovative VA-patented flexSTIM biomimetic implantable pulse generator that in combination with industry-standard intramuscular electrodes, provides a fully implanted iGSTIM system for regular automated weight-shifting at the touch of a button. This planning grant will support preparation for a pre-IDE meeting with the FDA to establish clear preclinical testing criteria for first-in-human testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Response assessment remains a prevailing challenge in the clinical management of glioblastoma (GBM) because routine neuroimaging is often insufficient to differentiate true progression from treatment effects. This project aims to establish the first line of evidence on the clinical feasibility of magnetic resonance elastography (MRE) in the accurate and timely differentiation of progressive/recurrent GBM from treatment-related false positives. Success of this project will open new opportunities for a comprehensive analysis of the cellular, vascular, and biomechanical imaging markers in GBM patients to bring novel insights into the mechanisms of GBM progression and treatment response.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food allergy is a growing problem in the United States that continues to affect millions of patients across a broad range of demographics. CoFAR will establish a national network of Clinical Research Centers to participate in multi-center clinical trials to identify and validate novel therapeutic and preventive strategies for food allergy that are safe, effective, and accessible. A CRC based in the University of North Carolina will bring experienced food allergy investigators, unique food allergy-specific infrastructure and facilities, and access to a large and diverse study population in support of the CoFAR network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Growing evidence links traffic-related air pollution (TRAP), a complex mixture of gasses and particles, to neurotoxicity and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). This study will: 1) investigate potential mechanisms by which TRAP mixtures, including ultrafine particles (UFP) with high toxic potential, may impact ADRD through neuropathologic changes; 2) combine existing and newly collect measures of UFPs to develop the first long-term UFP exposure models; and 3) investigate different timing of exposures that may be associated with ADRD neuropathologies as well as address survival biases in autopsy samples. The principal investigator will leverage extensive, state-of-the-art neuropathology measures from one of the largest community-based autopsy cohorts in the word; rich exposure models for UFP/TRAP; existing expertise in exposure assessment; and new training in ADRD neuropathologies, exposure mixtures, and advanced epidemiology to gain new insights and support targeted ADRD interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variants between humans and other mammals underlie the unique cognitive features that have evolved in the human lineage. Unfortunately, these variants and their resulting human neural specializations are also commonly dysregulated in diseases such as autism spectrum disorder. To identify and characterize genetic variants that underlie human cognition and may be mutated in neurological diseases, this study will use the human-chimpanzee tetraploid system and comparative genomics to prioritize variants for functional study, and evaluate variants in CRISPR inhibition screens in a high-throughput manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary vascular diseases, such as pulmonary hypertension, are devastating disorders that are associated with high morbidity and mortality with frustratingly limited treatment options. Endothelial cell dysfunction is a key contributor to disease pathogenesis and stem cell-based therapies to replace diseased endothelial cells holds immense promise for new therapeutic approaches to treat pulmonary vascular disease. This proposal leverages a novel approach for induced pluripotent stem cell-derived endothelial replacement therapy to dissect the mechanisms that promote cellular engraftment and to test the efficacy of this approach in genetic pulmonary vascular disease models.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with mid to later stage Parkinson’s disease (PD) may not be able to work out as hard as they need to, to prevent brain cell loss. Maybe they could work out longer and more frequently to make up for this during their good times and good weeks and then rest during the bad weeks. We will compare how effective working out a lot one week per month with a break of three weeks is to continuously exercising weekly with no breaks in people with mid stage PD. We will look at how fast they walk per minute, whether they become more physically active, the biochemicals in their blood, and at how stiff their blood vessels are before and after the exercise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The effects of rising environmental temperatures are being felt around the globe and are recognized as an emerging public health threat, disproportionately causing death of farmworkers. To best prepare farm workers and other workers to safely adapt to increased outdoor temperatures, there is a critical need to implement an effective heat-related illness (HRI) preventive hydration intervention. Utilizing community-based participatory research and implementation science, this work seeks to set the stage for developing occupational interventions that reduce morbidity and mortality related to HRIs.

PROJECT_TITLE: Backpack Hydration System Use Among Farmworkers

PHR: Narrative: Leadership Center Research Strategy The major objective of the Leadership Center is to oversee the scientific direction for CoFAR, as well as the financial, operational, and managerial aspects such that the next phase of the consortium, including both interventional trials and clinical studies, can be conducted in the most rigorous, safe, efficient, and fiscally sound manner possible. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative This renewal application proposes to validate early detection biomarker signatures comprising of pathway associated circulating transcriptomics, proteomics and metabolomics (omics) biomarkers and integrate them with machine learning method derived high resolution imaging features associated with heterogenous pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) disease subtypes. Integration of Omics data with CT/MRI imaging features will be done by developing Multimodal Integrative Analytical Models (MIAM) predictive of early stage pancreatic cancer. Validation of the integrated biomarker signatures and their association with PDAC subtypes will be investigated in Phases II, III and IV studies according to PRoBE-design while performance in phase IV study for detecting early stage disease and predicting clinical outcomes among asymptomatic patients and at-risk individuals will be ascertained with retrospective and prospective longitudinal pre-diagnostic sample cohorts, including one representing an underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Up to 70% of cancer patients utilize complementary and alternative therapies (CAM) in cancer care, which was associated with lower adherence to standard care. Unfortunately, many patients make CAM decisions without involving their healthcare providers, missing the opportunity for CAM-related information validation. Dr. Fridman develops an intervention to overcome patient and provider barriers to transparent welcoming patient-provider conversations about CAM and CAM misinformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is designed to p110β and ATR in PTEN-deficient CRPC mouse models and to investigate the underlying molecular mechanisms of combined effect of ATR inhibitor and p110β evaluate the anti-tumor activity and immunity of combined inhibition of inhibitor in DNA damage-induced cells death in PTEN-deficient CRPC cells . IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Psoriatic arthritis is a progressive, erosive, and destructive disease that often leads to disability and is strongly associated with poor sleep health. This project seeks to understand the contribution of poor sleep health to inflammation and disease activity in patients with psoriatic arthritis. Given that multiple components of sleep health are modifiable risk factor(s), the information provided through this study could support the development and testing of interventions to improve sleep health and disease activity in psoriatic arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The connecting cilium and adjacent regions of the photoreceptor cell perform a spectrum of functions vitally important for our vision, ranging from protein sorting and trafficking to biogenesis of the light-capturing membranes. However, the limited knowledge of the molecular composition of this critical part of the cell impedes our ability to elucidate the underlying mechanisms. We propose to close this knowledge gap by identifying and quantifying unique protein components of this photoreceptor region, thereby facilitating the progress in our understanding photoreceptor biology and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE MARC at Florida International University provides motivated undergraduate juniors and seniors from underrepresented groups with tools, skills, and a sense of belonging that will allow each to successfully enter, excel in, and complete a biomedical or behavioral sciences Ph.D. or M.D./Ph.D. program. This will be accomplished by immersing each MARC trainee in a supportive and stimulating research lab of an active researcher with a successful undergraduate mentoring record, who will develop the individual student’s skills and properly nurture and enhance the trainee’s interest in science. The MARC program will supplement the trainees’ FIU scientific research experience with personal advising, weekly program meetings, professional and academic development workshops, technical skills workshops, holistic wellness workshops, opportunities for scientific presentations, networking opportunities, leadership opportunities, community outreach events, and facilitate participation in a summer research program at an extramural research-intensive university.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following the recent Supreme Court ruling in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health, several states have banned or severely restricted abortion care. Just as these policies are expected to exacerbate inequities in perinatal health and reproductive autonomy, policies that expand Medicaid coverage for abortion may mitigate inequities. The proposed training will facilitate my proficiency with modernized Medicaid data, statistical and machine learning methods for causal inference, perinatal health services research, and research translation, providing me with the requisite tools to evaluate the effects of abortion bans and Medicaid abortion coverage expansions on contraceptive method use, births, and adverse perinatal outcomes in Medicaid populations on average at a population-level, and among marginalized subgroups based on race, ethnicity, age, and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a progressive disease of lung arteries that causes shortness of breath, heart failure, and death. In PAH, lung artery cells show abnormal dependence on proline, a building block of proteins, for their growth and function. Understanding how and why lung cells become dependent on proline may identify strategies to prevent lung artery destruction, shortness of breath, heart failure, and death from PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The current proposal seeks to develop single-fluorophore-based, high-performance, ultrasensitive biosensors for kinases and epigenetics. These biosensors will be used as functional multiparameter readouts to investigate kinase-epigenome coordination to develop focused ultrasound controllable CAR-T Therapy. The success of this project will revolutionize biosensor engineering and have a transformative impact on developing novel controllable CAR-T cells for the treatment of cancer and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Narrative The clinical experience with anti-PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibition in ovarian cancer has been disappointing. We have shown that a novel Th17-inducing dendritic cell vaccine markedly enhances responses to anti-PD- 1 treatment in a mouse model of ovarian cancer, thus paving the way for a phase II clinical trial for Th17-DC vaccination plus pembrolizumab in patients with advanced stage ovarian cancer. This proposal will test the paradigm-shifting hypothesis that the efficacy of anti-PD-1/Th17-DC vaccination is dependent on host B cell and antibody responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most children and adolescents with type 1 diabetes (T1D) do not meet glycemic control recommendations, which places them at risk for developing acute and long-term complications, and up to a third of youth with T1D report elevated depressive symptoms. The proposed research aligns with NIDDK’s mission to improve the health and quality of life of individuals living with diabetes by using a novel single-session intervention (SSI) approach to improve depressive symptoms and glycemic levels in youth with T1D. The proposed research and the career development plan developed by the candidate and mentoring team will result in an innovative T1D-specific depression SSI with the potential to significantly improve health and access to mental health care for adolescents with T1D who report elevated depressive symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Persisters are bacteria that have a non-inherited ability to tolerate antibiotic treatment, and they are thought to underlie the propensity of many infections to relapse. Recently, we discovered that chromosome copy number (ploidy) impacts the likelihood bacteria would give rise to fluoroquinolone persisters, with monoploids up to 40-fold less likely to be persisters compared to diploids. The research proposed will investigate how ploidy impacts the DNA repair systems persisters use to survive, assess whether ploidy influences the activities of other antibiotics, and identify compounds that can modify ploidy distributions in growth-limited bacteria, which could lead to new antibiotic adjuvants (ploidy modulators) with anti-persister activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will produce novel point-of-care assays to diagnose N. gonorrhoeae infection and predict AMR. Our work will also provide valuable insights into the genomic epidemiology of resistance mutations in N. gonorrhoeae as well as inform future efforts to implement POC testing for STI in low-resource settings. In so doing, our work will support the introduction of resistance-guided therapy in areas previously limited to syndromic management of STI, combating the global public health threat of AMR N. gonorrhoeae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most transgender men using testosterone gender-affirming hormone therapy develop vaginal atrophy and have a non-Lactobacillus dominated vaginal microbiota (i.e., vaginal dysbiosis). This study will investigate if testosterone use and vaginal atrophy severity are associated with vaginal microbiota composition, taxonomic diversity, or vaginal infections. This research will fill a critical gap in our understanding of the gynecological health of transgender men using testosterone and support the development of culturally-tailored, evidence- based interventions to prevent and treat vaginal atrophy, vaginal dysbiosis, and vaginal infections in this population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amplification and overexpression of CCNE1, the gene encoding cyclin E1, is frequently observed in aggressive subtypes of ovarian and other cancers and is associated with poor prognosis and resistance to chemotherapy. This project addresses the paucity of therapeutic options for CCNE1-driven tumors by developing first-in-class inhibitors with potential as novel drugs to effectively counteract this aberration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of “Pain Disengagement Training,” a novel, self-directed intervention for chronic pain. PDT targets pain catastrophizing, including the tendency to magnify the intensity of and ruminate on the experience of pain, which is a key predictor of the extent to which pain interferes in an individual’s life. Due to its self-directed nature, PDT has great potential to reduce the burdensomeness of pain in a large number of patients suffering from this chronic and often disabling condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall: Project Narrative The MADRC is a Center based at Massachusetts General Hospital, Harvard Medical School, devoted to understanding and ultimately contributing to the cure of Alzheimer’s disease and Related Disorders (ADRD). We support research in tracking the course of several hundred participants with an emphasis on diversity, obtain imaging studies and biofluids to develop biomarkers, and request permission for autopsy. The Center supports both clinical and basic science research, and also is a training environment for scientists and clinician-investigators to “build the future”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies have highlighted the link between fetal and early life exposures and the development of non- communicable diseases, such as cardiovascular disease and metabolic syndrome. This proposal aims at understanding how sterile inflammation at the maternal-fetal interface impacts the development of the fetal immune system. Developing a deeper understanding of the effects of maternal inflammation on fetal immune development will provide opportunities for the development of targeted therapeutics either in utero or once offspring are born.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the promise of immune checkpoint PD-1 blockade therapy in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), only a fraction of the patients can benefit from it in terms of clinical response. It is highly desired to develop an effective therapy for overcoming resistance to PD-1 blockade. Therefore, we propose to test the hypothesis that targeting CD5 on T and B cells will enhance the anticancer effects of PD-1 blockade by using TNBC patient-derived organoids and xenograft tumor model.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The knowledge to be gained from this investigation will establish whether chronic dehydration during steady- state conditions is predictive of morbidity and mortality in patients with sickle cell disease and has the potential to influence patient behavior and recommendations for care, such as at-home hydration monitoring to encourage fluid intake for the prevention of painful vaso-occlusive episodes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Syphilis affects millions of people worldwide, and its global rates are on the rise. We have developed a promising syphilis vaccine chimera that could help curtail the spread of this serious infection. In this proposal, we will study alternative formulations of the chimera vaccine candidate with the overall goals of increasing its protective efficacy against infection and generating a syphilis vaccine candidate that is ready for clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regeneration of the distal lung following severe injury (e.g. influenza or COVID-19) is an imperfect process, and frequently leads to permanently altered lung structure and chronic reduction in gas exchange function highlighting the need for a better understanding of alveolar regenerative processes. This proposal investigates how distinct mesenchymal lineages in the lung contribute to lung regeneration through their plasticity and signaling with other cells in the regenerating alveolar niche. The work that will arise from this proposal will enhance our understanding of the role of mesenchymal cells in lung regeneration and identify mechanisms which can be harnessed in the future to develop new therapies for patients with chronic lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insects can be detrimental to human populations due to the transmission of a variety of diseases and agricultural destruction. Chemosensory systems are critical for the effectiveness of these insects; olfaction is particularly important for navigating through the environment and finding human hosts and food. This project is designed to understand the molecular mechanisms by which these systems operate and could lead to new methods of controlling these insects and their impact on humans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Premature infants can spend weeks in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), where they are exposed to damaging levels of noise and light. The proposed project will establish an animal model of NICU exposure that will allow researchers to investigate the impact of the NICU on sensory system development and learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health to develop assays for diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring recurrence of patients with Upper Tract Urothelial Carcinoma (UTUC) in order to improve the overall survival benefit for these patients. There is urgent need for a novel personalized medicine approach, and this can be achieved by identifying and validating new DNA methylation biomarkers to identify a priori which patients will have favorable outcomes prior to any treatment taking place or monitor treatment responseand possible disease recurrence. The success of this proposal will minimize unnecessary chemotherapy administration for patients before surgery, reduce the associated patient morbidity/mortality, reduce delays to surgery, improve patient quality of life and reduce the overall health burden that is associated with receiving unnecessary chemotherapy. The mission of this proposal is to improve the overall clinical management for UTUC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Babies who are born extremely premature commonly have low blood platelet counts and a high risk of bleeding, usually in the brain or lungs. For this reason, they commonly receive platelet transfusions to decrease the risk of bleeding, although a recent randomized trial suggested that premature babies who received less platelet transfusions had less bleeding and mortality than those transfused with a higher threshold. This has generated uncertainty among clinicians regarding the optimal platelet transfusion thresholds for extremely preterm infants, and this trial is specifically designed to address this uncertainty by evaluating if lower thresholds for platelet transfusions will lead to improved survival without bleeding among extremely preterm infants born at 23 to 26 weeks gestational age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Food insecurity affects 13.5 million Americans and is associated with heart disease, diabetes, and poor diet quality. This project uses a community engaged approach to collaborate with food pantries to design, implement, and evaluate digital strategies to encourage pantry clients to choose healthier foods. The goal of the proposed work is to identify acceptable and effective community interventions to improve diet quality and promote cardiovascular health equity among a vulnerable US population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because of the biological significance and contribution of neural crest and placode cells to the proper formation of human bodies, including the development of the peripheral nervous system like the trigeminal ganglion, bones and cartilage of the face, skin pigment cells, and parts of the heart. How these cells contribute to these diverse structures and generate these different cell types can help us comprehend what happens when development is impaired and human disease ensues. Thus, the proposed research is directly relevant to NIH’s mission to understand the fundamental processes controlling development and the use of that knowledge to improve overall human health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Significant disparities in cancer mortality persist among adolescents and young adults (AYAs) with Ewing sarcoma (EWS) and osteosarcoma (OS), which may be partially due to unequal access to evidence based, guideline concordant care. My previous research demonstrated that 50% of AYAs with OS in California received guideline concordant care and that not receiving this care negatively impacted survival. This study seeks to increase the delivery of guideline concordant care to AYAs with OS and EWS to improve overall survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a strong need for prevention of perinatal mood, anxiety, and trauma symptoms, as they represent the most prevalent comorbidity in the perinatal period and are associated with the leading cause of maternal mortality – suicide. Patients with high-risk pregnancies and anticipated Cesarean delivery are a large population of patients at increased risk for onset of mental health symptoms in the postpartum period. This project refines and evaluates a low cost, non-pharmacologic, single-session intervention to prevent onset of perinatal mood, anxiety, and traumas symptoms, with the eventual goal of promoting scalability and applicability of the intervention to labor and delivery units across the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep is a very well conserved behavioral state across all animals and its precise homeostatic regulation is vital for maintaining good sleep quality and a healthy life. Patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) show signs of disrupted sleep architecture characterized by fragmented sleep patterns, and though the exact mechanism underlying fragmented sleep in Alzheimer’s patients remains unknown, it may involve disrupted encoding of homeostatic sleep pressures by wake- promoting hypocretin neurons of the lateral hypothalamus. In this proposal, I will investigate the impact of AD related accumulation of beta-amyloid (Aβ) on hypocretin neuron activity and subsequent impacts on homeostatic sleep pressures and increased sleep fragmentation in AD, with the aim to elucidate the underlying mechanisms driving sleep disturbances in AD – a key step in advancing our understanding of AD progression and treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Response to cardiovascular disease (CVD) medications is influenced by many factors including a patient's lifestyle, environment, and genetics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The intersection of nanomaterials and biology has produced promising tools for selective drug delivery, bio- imaging, and biosensing. This project will design structured nano- and microscale materials with topographical features similar to that of the extracellular matrix. This platform to investigate nano-bio interfaces will allow control over cellular motion, adhesion, and shape that will then enable more targeted diagnostics and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite successful treatment with blood flow restoration, ischemic stroke remains a major cause of disability in the U.S., disproportionately impacting older adults. In this study, we will examine the significance and role of neutrophils in brain injury following ischemic stroke and determine how aging affects neutrophil recruitment and persistence. Results from this work will lay the foundation for future studies examining novel treatments for ischemic stroke beyond blood flow restoration, and has broad potential translation to other aging-related brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) is a rapidly growing intervention for some of the most serious and intractable forms of psychopathology, like treatment-resistant depression (TRD). A crucial structure that regulates neuronal function is the blood-brain barrier (BBB), which has thought to be impaired in depression and capable of being influenced by TMS. The proposed training and research plan will focus on elucidating the mechanism TMS, whereby it may improve the BBB in TRD, demonstrating a modifiable target to improve depressive symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: MARC @ Georgia State University (GSU) is a thriving undergraduate (UG) biomedical research training program for students from underrepresented (UR) groups in STEM, established in 2019 and poised to launch a new MARC grant from 2024-2029. GSU has taken institutional responsibility for ensuring efficient and effective trajectories through undergraduate studies for students from all backgrounds, and MARC lends richness to this college experience through mentored research, enhanced course work, professional development workshops, and career planning. Based on institutional assessment, education science, and lived experiences among students, faculty, and staff at GSU and our partner organizations, the program plan for MARC@GSU is ready to equip and empower students with the skills and dispositions that will propel them into successful and satisfying careers in the U.S. biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Americans fear blindness more than virtually any other health problem, and the enormous impact of these conditions will accelerate as our population ages. Fortunately, advances in scientific knowledge and technology hold great promise for alleviating these problems. This proposal provides protected, start-up support for junior faculty clinicians to develop the clinical research skills necessary to make this promise a reality and reduce the suffering and impairment of blinding eye diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in four women in South Asia, including India are affected by perinatal depression. Marital-level relationship risk factors such as poor relationship dynamics, limited spousal support, and women's low decision-making, particularly in the context of early marriage and childbearing, increase women’s vulnerability to perinatal depression, yet trials investigating couples-based interventions for prevention of perinatal depression remain unexplored. The project aims to culturally adapt and pilot test a couples-based intervention to prevent perinatal depression among primiparous (first-time pregnant) couples in rural India.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We invented a Point-of-care Portable Perfusion Phantom (P4), which allows reproducible quantitative DCE-MRI measurement across MRI platforms. We demonstrated that quantitative DCE-MRI after P4-based error correction could assess the pancreatic cancer response to therapy early. In this study, we propose a clinical trial of DCE-MRI-guided neoadjuvant chemotherapy to improve the negative-martin resection for patients with borderline resectable pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Culturally grounded strengths-based interventions hold significant promise to reduce and prevent substance misuse and consequential overdoses among Native Americans. The well-established Traditional Ecological Knowledge theoretical framework informs the nature-based culturally grounded (NBCG) substance misuse intervention by positing cultural and spiritual mechanisms between nature-based experiential learning of traditional practices and cultural protocols (NBCG intervention) and resilience and resistance to substance misuse. In partnership with the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes tribal community, we aim to develop and refine the NBCG intervention, and evaluate successful implementation strategies that will set the stage for a future fully powered Hybrid type II trial to measure implementation and program effectiveness against maternal substance misuse and child problem emotional and behavioral development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Activity-dependent myelination is an emerging facet of neuroplasticity in which neuronal activity stimulates new myelin formation by oligodendrocytes. Although numerous studies have demonstrated the importance of activity-dependent myelination for learning, cognition, and memory, how neuronal activity drives myelin membrane expansion in oligodendrocytes is unclear. My proposed research will reveal fundamental cellular mechanisms of activity-dependent myelination that may be harnessed as therapeutic strategies to promote myelin regeneration and neuronal health in neurological disease and disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Whole-body MRI scanners face limited accessibility due to their high expense and specific siting requirements, which can substantially increase costs. MRI suites rely on a costly Faraday shielded room to eliminate image artifacts caused by external radio waves as well as reduce radio wave emission which can disrupt nearby hospital equipment. We aim to enhance MRI accessibility and reduce expenses by replacing the Faraday shield with a combination of strategically placed passive EM absorbers within the MRI bore and an active cancellation system based on the parallel transmission (pTx) technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Drug resistance is a major cause of therapy failure in colorectal cancer patients largely due to tumor heterogeneity and the existence of cancer stem cells. The goal of this project is to generate novel bispecific antibody-drug conjugates (BsADCs) directed against two tumor targets that can eliminate cancer stem cells and overcome therapy resistance. BsADCs will be evaluated in patient-derived tumor models and a lead candidate will be identified for the future development of a new therapeutic to treat colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Youth-onset type 2 diabetes significantly contributes to the increasing prevalence of diabetic kidney disease, yet our understanding of modifiable risk factors remains limited. This study seeks to explore the role of exposure to per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), an emerging environmental risk factor, in the onset and progression of diabetic kidney disease among youth with type 2 diabetes by integrating data on PFAS exposure with data on metabolites and proteins linked to uremic toxicity. This research project will enhance understanding of the health impacts of PFAS, thereby supporting PFAS regulation and helping develop innovative strategies for early identification and prevention of diabetic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Fat accumulation in the liver causes two major changes in liver cells: it alters the use and production of energy upsetting liver metabolism, and it drives abnormal gene expression patterns that drive malignancy. To date, no one has connected these two major events at the molecular level to define how aberrant metabolites affect the enzymes that control gene expression. We propose to do this here in order to find the metabolic Achilles heel of fatty liver and stop its development into liver cancer with inhibitors of the enzymes that are regulated by liver metabolites and control growth genes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a painful gynecological inflammatory disease with limited therapeutic options that affects up to 15% of people born with uterus. Here, we propose to validate CGRP/RAMP1 blocking drugs as well as macrophage-targeting drugs as novel non-hormonal and non-opioid approaches for the treatment of endometriosis-associated pain. The project also addresses a previous unknown mechanism by which CGRP contributes to a pro-endometriosis phenotype in macrophages and pinpoints the specific nociceptor-responsive macrophage population that drives omental colonization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atopic dermatitis is a very common disease with substantial morbidity, most prevalent among infants and children who are also colonized at high rates in the gut by Staphylococcus aureus. While S. aureus is known to contribute to atopic dermatitis pathogenesis, studies have primarily focused on S. aureus in the nares and on the skin, with little attention to S. aureus and other microbiota in the gastrointestinal tract. The proposed project aims to elucidate the contributions of gastrointestinal S. aureus and other gut microbiota to pediatric atopic dermatitis, thereby furthering our understanding of S. aureus colonization dynamics beyond the nares and skin, and potentially revealing novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of atopic dermatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative In this K99/R00 proposal, I will investigate the antagonism and bifunctionality of the dual E3 ligase TRIM25, a modulator of the innate immune response pathway. I will leverage my training in protein engineering, biochemistry, and immunology to investigate how the HPV viral protein E6 antagonizes TRIM25 (K99) and to understand the dual function of TRIM25 as a Ub and ISG15 ligase (R00). By understanding the molecular mechanism that dictates TRIM25 bifunctionality, we will gain valuable insight into the complexity and regulation of innate immune signaling as well as the mechanisms of ISG15 recognition, transfer, and substrate targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop a novel method to facilitate discussions about end-of-life options among patients with Alzheimer's Disease and related Dementias (ADRD), their informal caregiver, and clinicians. We will first conduct interviews and administer surveys to identify the most important topics related to ADRD's progression, the ideal timing for discussions, and how other factors such as health literacy, race, ethnicity, religion, and education can influence such discussions. Since end-of-life conversations related to ADRD are challenging and advance care planning discussions are usually a solitary event, we will design and evaluate a shared medical appointment (SMA), which offers a sense of community where physicians have the liberty to continuously discuss sensitive topics with a group of patients and their informal caregivers to increase knowledge, awareness, and preparedness of end-of-life approaches.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Depressive symptoms are common among Veterans and associated with significant impairment. Early intervention has the potential to improve mental health outcomes and restore functioning. Interventions delivered through the internet are ideally suited for early intervention as they can be completed remotely at any time, and thus minimize burden on Veterans, however the research examining their utility in Veterans is limited. This proposed project will examine the acceptability and effectiveness of Deprexis, a self-guided internet-delivered intervention, which targets depressive symptoms and associated functional impairments. The proposed work has great clinical utility, as it could provide a readily accessible, high- quality intervention for the many Veterans suffering from depressive symptoms, with the potential to improve functioning and long-term outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Medication overuse headache (MOH) develops when migraine patients overuse acute migraine medications, resulting in a paradoxical increase in headache frequency and severity. Our lab has identified a novel mechanism for the treatment of MOH, by inhibiting the PAC1 receptor. The aim of this proposal is to develop novel PAC1 receptor blockers that can be used as a novel therapy for MOH.
