IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Plants are the origin of many FDA-approved drugs and, as food, deliver a daily dose of drug-like compounds into our bodies. This project establishes an efficient strategy to decode the genomes of dietary and medicinal plants by activating and identifying hundreds of different biochemical programs in multiplexed assays. This work will help illuminate what molecules a plant can synthesize, allowing us to (1) make informed dietary decisions, (2) engineer the metabolic content of our food, and (3) produce high-value medicinal compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project aims to develop the next-generation photoacoustic computed tomography through an ergodic relay (PACTER) device for noninvasive monitoring of cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen (CMRO2). This research will have a significant positive impact on public health by addressing the critical gap in noninvasive CMRO2 monitoring and providing clinicians with timely and crucial information for accurate diagnosis, personalized treatment, and surgical decision-making. The development of next-generation PACTER will significantly advance brain health assessment, improve medical outcomes, reduce healthcare costs, and open new horizons for intraoperative brain monitoring and advancements in optical imaging technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cells produce non-normal protein sequences, which can be exploited for immunotherapy and vaccines for tumor prevention. We will build a novel, publicly accessible informatics resource containing software for predicting these non-normal sequences (called neoantigens) from DNA or RNA sequencing data, and confirming their presence by integration with mass spectrometry-based peptide data, thereby accelerating research in this critical area of cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite evidence that ovarian cancer is immune reactive, with tumor regression occurring in response to immune modulation, no immune therapy has advanced to routine clinical use. Here we propose to use proprietary technology to transform cancer cells into highly immunogenic pathogen mimetics. Validation of the vaccine in humanized mouse models and therapeutic efficacy of allogeneic vaccines will be studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Drug discovery hinges upon the identification of compounds that can selectively alter the activity of a target protein or proteins. A challenge in identifying such compounds is the limited chemical space that can be practically synthesized and screened due to physical mass barriers. This proposal aims to develop novel shapeshifting drug-like compounds that overcome physical mass limitations as they possess the ability to interconvert internally and spontaneously, i.e. shapeshift, between multiple chemical structures with varying pharmacophore properties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Visuomotor transformation is a critical process linking ethologically relevant visual information with appropriate behaviors, but little is known about its underlying circuit and molecular mechanisms. The objective of this research program is to establish Drosophila as a powerful model system to investigate the molecular determinants of circuit wiring underlying a visuomotor transformation using a combination of transcriptomics, connectomics, and physiology. Molecular mechanisms of synaptic specificity uncovered in this work will be applicable to brains of other animals, including mammals, and will provide a deeper understanding of human neurological disorders associated with impaired visuomotor processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This study will employ cutting edge computational modeling of cognitive, behavioral, and environmental data, generated from large-scale, national mental health studies of youth, to enhance diagnostic and prognostic prediction for children with common forms of psychopathology. Effectiveness will be evaluated within pediatric and psychiatry clinic settings from several regions of the country. If successful, this work has the capacity to dramatically improve the efficiency and efficacy of child psychopathology identification and care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K23 project examines the optimal timing and route of amiodarone administration in out-of-hospital cardiac arrest due to an initial shockable rhythm, a condition that continues to have near 75% mortality in the United States. The proposed aims have the potential to produce evidence for multiple future testable alterations to the timing, route, and dose of amiodarone administration in shockable cardiac arrest that will inform treatment guidelines learned and used by nearly every healthcare professional in the United States. This application aligns with the objectives of the NHLBI on levering data science, optimizing therapeutic strategies, and using implementation research for improving health, in addition to having synergistic training aims to develop an independent physician-scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Large craniofacial bone defects are challenging to heal without surgical intervention and often require bone grafting, which has variable clinical outcomes with limited metrics to predict healing outcomes. Patient-specific organoids and systemic immune cell profiling are promising tools to understand mechanisms regulating regenerative processes, yet to date these tools are not widely used to study craniofacial bone healing. The experiments outlined in this proposal will characterize a newly developed bone-like organoid, as well as the local and systemic immune response during healing of a craniofacial defect, to identify therapeutics to improve healing and develop predictive models of healing outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acquired and familial cardiomyopathies are common and fatal diseases in which protein mutations and other factors disrupt the function of individual components of the contractile machinery and ultimately lead to heart failure; unfortunately, standard treatment options only address disease symptoms and attempt to arrest disease progression without addressing its mechanistic origin. The project I propose here leverages a unique platform that combines computational approaches (in silico) with stem cell technologies (in vitro) to model the fundamental mechanisms of cardiac muscle contraction and identify new therapeutic small molecules by studying the structural communication pathways of proteins that comprise the contractile machinery. A multiscale, interdisciplinary approach will track how critical failures of (and corrections to) the contractile machinery at the single molecule level give rise to failure of organized contractile units (sarcomeres), subcellular contractile organelles (myofibrils), and cardiomyocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Daily maintenance dosing during oral immunotherapy (OIT) for food allergy and the risk of comorbid eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) are major burdens for food allergic individuals. Here we propose to reduce these burdens by determining the safety and efficacy of high concentration reduced-frequency OIT maintenance dosing regimens (network-wide project). Furthermore, we will characterize gastrointestinal features of food allergic individuals with and without EoE (CRC-specific project).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronary heart disease (CHD) is a leading cause of death globally, and accurate risk prediction is vital for early intervention. However, current polygenic risk scores (PRS) for CHD have limited predictive value, particularly for populations with diverse ancestries, due to underrepresentation in genomic studies. Exploiting multiple recently developed increasingly diverse biobanks with 2.1 million individuals, Dr. Tcheandjieu aims to address these disparities by developing population-specific CHD PRSs, tailoring risk prediction approaches to individuals based on their genetic background, susceptibility to traditional risk factors, and social and environmental context.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: When mobility is limited, such as during severe illness or injury, muscles undergo a rapid loss in mass referred to as disuse atrophy. Atrophy decreases muscle strength and hinders the patient’s ability to rehabilitate, leading to functional disability which is exacerbated in aged populations. We are developing biodegradable, biocompatible particles for delivery to atrophied muscle. The particles are designed to promote the release of biomolecules that enhance muscle metabolism and growth. This innovative approach complements current rehabilitation strategies (e.g. physical therapy, nutritional support) and is expected to maximize functional recovery in aged patients, a population that struggles to recover from muscle atrophy secondary to disuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative As a unique ethnic group in the US, Native Hawaiians exhibit increased incidence and mortality rates of colorectal cancer. The project addresses these disparities by using multiple approaches to define biological risk factors to improve prevention and clinical outcomes for Native Hawaiians who are stricken with colorectal cancer. This research carries the potential to make a meaningful impact on the well-being of Native Hawaiians and contribute to the overall goal of eliminating colorectal cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Low frequency rhythms in human brain activity have been studied for 90 years and correlated with changes in attention, perception, and memory. However, it is still unknown if these rhythms actually change how the brain processes information, and, if they do, what these changes are. Here we propose to answer these questions by ﬁrst examining how endogenous rhythms alter the processing of visual information at the single cell and population level, and then by directly modulating these rhythms with electrical stimulation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This study will integrate a virtual reality driver system (VRDS) into a current clinical driving assessment program to evaluate and predict long term driving performance among individuals with brain injury. The study will include a 2 year follow-up and examine driving behaviors (i.e., errors, crash involvement) using web-based self-report, a driving sample monitored by in-vehicle technologies and reports from the Department of Motor Vehicles. The findings will define the utility of VRDS to current clinical approaches and generate predictive models of driving outcome, which can serve to benefit individuals with brain injury and the safety of the general public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Somatosensation and vision are crucial for functioning in daily life and can be lost due to various neurological injuries and diseases. While these senses can potentially be restored with stimulation of the sensory cortices, it is not currently well understood how stimulation affects the brain and drives activity. By studying the mechanisms of stimulation in mouse cortex using high-resolution imaging techniques, we aim to develop a better understanding of the basic science of neural circuits underlying sensory processing and how they are impacted by stimulation, which in the long-term will inform better technologies and clinical approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Using relevant translational approaches we will dissect how GP130 signaling modulates right ventricular function via microtubules in preclinical pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Our findings will have broad implications for future treatment of PAH, a lethal disease with a median survival of only five to seven years. No current therapy targets the right ventricle directly; thus there is a critical need to define targetable molecular mechanisms that cause right ventricle disease so as to develop an effective therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: We propose to connect engineering students’ laboratory work with healthcare and help them give their discoveries the best chance to benefit clinical medicine by immersing them in a major medical center to shadow medical practitioners and participate in clinical research. When engineering students see patients’ suffering, they appreciate the urgency and importance of developing medical technology solutions to healthcare problems; when students watch in person their clinician mentor diagnosing and treating patients, students appreciate the utility of medical technology in medicine; when students see the limitations of the patients and the clinical environment, they develop a perspective on what kinds of technology solutions can be clinically workable; when students participate in clinical research, they appreciate the impact of medical technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to develop new methods for asthma risk prediction in a health plan setting by incorporating social and financial hardship data, temporal features, and machine learning. Applications of this research will directly enable U.S. health plans to better identify adults and children for enrollment in asthma care management programs in order to moderate their combined clinical and social risks for poor asthma quality. This career development award will support Dr. Alon Peltz, a physician health services researcher, in developing expertise in machine learning risk prediction incorporating expanded social data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rapid rise in untreated substance use among justice-involved young (JIY) women in low- and middle- income countries (LMIC) is a critical global public health issue and there is a pressing need to study implementation factors that hinder delivery of substance use services. Integrating substance use and mental health services is a potential efficient and sustainable means of closing the substance use treatment gap for JIY women, but there is limited research on how to effectively implement integrated services in LMIC. The current study leverages quantitative and qualitative methods to study multi-level implementation factors influencing integration of an evidence-based substance use intervention with existing mental health services for JIY women in Brazil, with the goal of informing best practices for services integration in LMIC and resource- constrained, high-income country settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By analyzing tissue samples from benign breast biopsies, we have found that more than 40% of postmenopausal women have incomplete lobular involution, and that these women are at substantially greater risk for subsequently developing cancer. Our project will provide insight into the previously unstudied mechanisms that control lobular involution and will define why postmenopausal women who have not completed the process of lobular involution are at greater risk for breast cancer development. This research will be crucial for better guiding women who obtain breast biopsies toward the most appropriate strategies of surveillance, risk management, and treatment, and will also point towards new physiologic strategies to reduce breast cancer incidence, including the induction of lobular involution in postmenopausal women for whom this process is incomplete.
PI_NAMEs: DEGNIM, AMY C;RADISKY, DEREK C (contact);SHERMAN, MARK E

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 related mitigation efforts and increased social distancing have impeded access to primary care and chronic disease management, especially for medically and socially vulnerable populations. In this study, we will use a mixed-methods approach combining established and novel data sets with qualitative interviews to understand the short- to medium-term secondary health impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The results of our study will provide crucial information to help determine how we should direct health care resources during national crises and how to rebuild an equitable health system in the post-pandemic period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project narrative Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a disease characterized by granulomatous lesions with characteristic clonal CD207+ CD1a+ mononuclear phagocytes (MNP) with activating somatic mutations in MAPK pathway genes. Optimal therapeutic strategies for patients with LCH remain a major unmet need. We therefore propose to define the roles of cell of origin, differentiation of cells harboring activating MAPK pathway mutations, and the impact of target tissue on pathogenesis in order to identify and test novel therapeutic strategies to improve outcomes for patients with LCH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The ongoing HIV endemic and the COVID-19 pandemic have disproportionately affected racial and ethnic minority groups. Increased rates of COVID-19 diagnosis and mortality among people with HIV (PWH) are likely associated with individual and community factors, that if identified, can be targeted to create better intervention strategies. This study will assess the effect of COVID-19 community-level prevention strategies and the impact of COVID-19 vaccine availability in reducing the risk of COVID-19 in PWH and related disparities and identify factors associated with co-occurring high rates of COVID-19 and HIV across communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) often manifests with cognitive impairments associated with sensory processing defects. The goal of the proposed research is to understand how a major ASD risk gene regulates the formation of brain connections during learning and how changes in sensory processing associated with ASD risk gene mutation contribute to learning related sensorimotor connectivity. The results of this research will increase our understanding of the contribution of impaired sensory processing and altered sensorimotor connectivity related to a major ASD risk gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Symptoms of withdrawal from chronic ethanol exposure are well-known triggers for relapse. While evidence suggests that both the rostromedial tegmental nucleus (RMTg) and the lateral habenula (LHb) mediate withdrawal symptoms, prior work has focused on analyses at the level of whole brain region despite the presence of a dense neural connection between the two regions. The proposed project uses circuit-specific approaches to investigate the role of input from the LHb to the RMTg in the mechanisms underlying symptoms of withdrawal.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop 3D bioprinted personalized autologous vaginal tissue constructs consisting of patient- derived vaginal epithelial and smooth muscle cells for surgical reconstruction. We will utilize clinically applicable 3D bioprinting workflow to manufacture patient-specific vaginal tissue constructs for long-term use, adapting to the needs of growing children and adults. This study will explore the potential of utilizing a 3D bioprinting strategy in a clinically relevant surgical animal model and establish a process development and batch record for regulatory approval.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because it explains how the production of dopamine by specific neuron types can control retinal vascular development and homeostasis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE-RELEVANCE Urban adolescents with asthma suffer from substantial morbidity and suboptimal preventive care. This project is expected to have a profound impact on public health because it proposes an innovative and sustainable intervention that uses specialist directed telemedicine and virtual care management, along with school-based DOT, to optimize guideline-based care and improve outcomes for high risk teens with asthma. Should this program prove successful in improving the health of urban teens with moderate to severe persistent asthma, it has the potential to serve as a sustainable model for improved asthma care in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss and balance dysfunction affect millions of people world-wide with the most common underlying reason being the irreversible loss of specialized sensory cells called hair cells that transmit information about hearing and balance. In this proposal, we use a mouse model to understand the behavior of a limited number of stem cells that are activated after injury to the inner ear, with the goal of deciphering their mechanism of regeneration. Our overarching aim is to identify what molecular pathways can be manipulated to stimulate regeneration following injury in humans to help restore hearing and balance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative: The disproportionate use of exclusionary disciplinary practices (EDPs) in schools among students of color is an important, modifiable predictor of school disengagement, a known determinant of health disparities across the lifespan. Yet, research examining how environmental and neurobiological factors interact to explain racial and ethnic disparities in the associations between EDPs, discrimination, and school disengagement is scarce. The proposed K01 training and research endeavors will support a new and early- stage investigator to become a leader in interdisciplinary research focused on school-based determinants of health and health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed experiments will systematically dissect the mechanisms by which microcircuits encode and update associations during learning at a cellular resolution difficult to achieve in other model organisms. Because the molecular mechanisms and synaptic organization of learning are conserved, these studies will provide valuable new information applicable to mammalian learning. Because failure to update internal representations is involved in several mental disorders, having a detailed mechanistic understanding of how nervous systems perform these updates would inform translational and clinical approaches to healthy and disordered learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is an acute inflammation of the lungs, usually leading to 75,000 annual US deaths, but several times that since the start of COVID-19, which can cause ARDS. In ARDS, any of several inflammatory stimuli cause the lungs’ air sacs to develop leaky capillaries and infiltration by white blood cells. Here we will deliver to these air sacs mRNA encapsulated in lipid nanoparticles, which will drive the local expression of therapeutic proteins that will ameliorate both the capillary leak and deleterious white blood cells, potentially providing a new therapy for ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: (relevance to public health) This project studies a molecular pathway that, based on studies in rodents and other model organisms, becomes activated and contributes to outcomes in multiple scenarios and axonal injury and stress, nerve damage, chemotherapy, traumatic brain injury, excitotoxicity and models of ALS and Alzheimer's Disease. By understanding the molecular mechanisms of the pathway's activation and downstream actions, which include how it activates the immune system, the findings from this project will guide future therapeutic strategies to promote beneficial outcomes and/or inhibit deleterious outcomes of nervous system damage.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The timing (age of onset) and tempo (rate of change) of puberty can significantly and negatively impact psychological, social and physical health, especially in females. Recently, the study team reported signs of early puberty in adolescent females with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), a vulnerable and understudied population. The goal of the project is to comprehensively examine and track the precise onset, course and impact of puberty in 240 females with and without ASD enrolled between 6 to 12 years and follow them for four years to derive data related to pubertal, psychosocial and physiological development to improve education, inform services, and develop interventions, which are lacking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) remains the major non-relapse complication after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantion (aHSCTs) for hematologic cancers. Using pre-clinical models, this proposal will identify how innate immune sensors are activated during aHSCT and how the resulting pro-inflammatory signals contribute to GVHD. The proposed research ultimately aims to develop a strategy to prevent or reduce clinical GVHD while maintaining anti-tumor immunity to prevent leukemic relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE In this proposal, we describe a systems biology approach to investigate tumor progression and metastasis through the lens of cancer cell states. The proposal involves a strongly complementary collaboration between Dr. White who is an oncologist with expertise in zebrafish cancer modeling, and Dr. Yanai who has expertise in analyzing transcriptional heterogeneity at the single-cell level. Overall this proposal is innovative in its integration of today’s most cutting-edge molecular and cellular methods for the analysis of transcriptomic data, and uses a tractable genetic system that allows us to functionally study and perturb tumorigenesis over space and time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE  This research is relevant to public health because it examines patterns in how lung and heart health change over time. We will use repeated imaging studies to identify the earliest, pre-symptomatic changes from young adulthood to midlife to identify susceptible individuals, track transitions from subclinical to clinical disease, and ultimately design prevention strategies for lung and heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. A current challenge in cancer research is understanding tumor heterogeneity, a major cause of resistance to chemotherapy drugs as well as metastasis development. APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B have been identified as two of the major drivers of tumor heterogeneity by promoting the deamination of cytosine to uracil on DNA and inducing genomic mutations. The goal of this proposal is to uncover the molecular mechanisms that govern APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B regulation in cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The University of North Carolina (UNC) Project Malawi Cancer Program proposes to establish the Malawi Cancer Outcomes Research Program (M-CORP) in collaboration with its primary partner, the University of Malawi College of Medicine (COM). M-CORP addresses high-priority needs identified by UNC, COM and other partners, to develop research expertise aligned with institutional and national goals. The proposal builds on a strong foundation and investment in breast cancer, cervical cancer and lymphoma research in Malawi, well- established collaborations, and engages pre-existing cancer outcomes research training programs at UNC to synergistically expand the global cancer research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The common marmoset (Callithrix jacchhus) has emerged as a critically important biomedical animal model in in a variety of study disciplines. Increased demand for marmosets in scientific research studies has been most acute in neuroscience, where the need to study cognition, behavior, and mental illness in primate models with new genomic editing and gene targeting methodologies has surged. As access to marmosets is limited, and a national strategy is needed for coordinating marmoset research populations, the proposed project will establish a marmoset coordination center that joins real-time census data on marmosets and expert marmoset neuroscientists, which together will provide information and access to animals for scientists in the broader neuroscience community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have discovered and studied three novel, inter-related mechanisms relevant to severe asthma pathophysiology, including the role of: 1) β2 adrenergic receptor regulation by S-nitrosylation; 2) airway acidification; and 3) androgen signaling. Our Program will have three Projects with strong scientific and operational synergies to study these discoveries and to translate them into new therapies. Each Project will make use of five Cores, unique in our institutions, for economy of scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The survival rates of stem cell transplants are improving allowing more children to be treated; as a result, more children are getting a form of lung injury called bronchiolitis obliterans as a side- effect of the transplant. In this study we will collect clinical and biological data to help figure out why children get this complication and how best to treat it. Children can’t perform some of the most helpful lung function tests used in adults because the tests require cooperation, so we will also test new methods to test lung function to identify lung injury more quickly in small children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative. Many adult behavioral patterns reflect experiences that occur when the individual is young, yet we have little mechanistic information about what happens to mediate this observation. Without addressing this gap, we risk missing significant opportunities to enhance positive or remediate adverse neurodevelopmental effects of experience. Here, we begin to fill this gap using a combination of epigenetic and molecular measures and manipulations of juvenile experience in males and females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Asthma exacerbations are the most serious expression of the disease, and despite available therapies, asthma exacerbations remain common and lead to substantial morbidity. In this proposal, we are using lung biopsies from asthmatic volunteer subjects and experimental self-limited models of asthma exacerbation to identify natural pro-resolving mediators and mechanisms. By understanding how the healthy lung restores homeostasis, we can better understand inflammatory diseases, such as asthma, and design novel rational therapeutic strategies that quicken the resolution of asthma exacerbations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The surge in overdose deaths in the United States, primarily due to non-medical fentanyl use, has prompted the exploration of alternative strategies to increase the uptake of buprenorphine, a highly effective medication for opioid use disorder (OUD). Low Dose Initiation (LDI) protocols have emerged as a promising approach, gradually introducing small amounts of buprenorphine to minimize the risk of precipitated withdrawal, though successful initiation using LDI protocols in the outpatient setting remains low. This research proposal aims to address knowledge gaps and enhance LDI protocols through the development of an Enhanced LDI program, with the goal of increasing buprenorphine uptake among individuals with OUD using fentanyl and reducing overdose deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute chest syndrome (ACS) is a common respiratory complication of sickle cell disease (SCD). It results in irreversible lung damage, can be prevented by standard of care practices such as incentive spirometry and appropriate opioid orders, yet adherence to guidelines is suboptimal. This research will investigate the barriers and enablers of implementing best practices by SCD providers in a vulnerable, predominantly low-income pediatric SCD population in New York. This information will inform the development of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) and subsequent pilot study in the context of a hybrid effectiveness-implementation study design.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Weight loss interventions for neurologically health individuals have established benefits for improving physical and psychosocial function. We believe that Veterans who have had a stroke would realize similar benefits and that the effects would be enhanced with concurrent exercise training. We will study the effects of a 15-week lifestyle management program to determine if it can effectively improve some of the physical and psychosocial problems common in Veterans who have had a stroke.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Our recently completed clinical trial confirms that the rates of survival and of ototoxicity are high in VA cancer patients treated with cisplatin. We found that ototoxic hearing loss, when identified, is acted on by these patients and their oncology teams. Unfortunately, we currently cannot predict which patients will experience ototoxicity. Patients and their doctors also generally lack awareness of ototoxicity, which could prompt intervention to address its many negative health and psychosocial consequences. This research program is designed to fill these gaps in knowledge and clinical care to optimize post-treatment quality of life for the ~10,000 Veterans a year who receive ototoxic chemotherapies. We will test hypotheses developed in animal studies for how tinnitus and speech understanding problems develop in humans. We will refine our tools to forecast an individual patient’s risk for ototoxicity prior to treatment, including through genetic association studies. Additionally, we will partner with patients, oncology teams, and industry to improve access to and uptake of ototoxicity management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  HMG CoA reductase (HMGCR) is the molecular target of cholesterol lowering statin drugs, and a key regulatory enzyme of the cholesterol biosynthetic pathway which is subjected to feedback regulation by sterol and nonsterol isoprenoid end products that act to induce its endoplasmic reticulum (ER)–associated degradation (ERAD). I have shown that the 1,1-bisphosphonate ester SRP3042 mimics sterols in inducing HMGCR ERAD without disrupting transcriptional feedback mechanisms, and a photoactivatable form specifically crosslinks HMGCR. This proposal aims to determine the sterol- sensing mechanisms through which HMGCR ERAD is initiated to determine whether SRP3042 induced HMGCR ERAD is a viable strategy for overcoming statin-resistance, will identify the molecular target of LY295427, and elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which LY295427 reverses the 25- hyroxycholesterol mediated transcriptional activation and post-translational regulation of lipid homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: (relevance to public health) This project studies a molecular pathway that, based on studies in rodents and other model organisms, becomes activated and contributes to outcomes in multiple scenarios and axonal injury and stress, nerve damage, chemotherapy, traumatic brain injury, excitotoxicity and models of ALS and Alzheimer's Disease. By understanding the molecular mechanisms of the pathway's activation and downstream actions, which include how it activates the immune system, the findings from this project will guide future therapeutic strategies to promote beneficial outcomes and/or inhibit deleterious outcomes of nervous system damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to identify patients with stage II-III melanoma who have been cured by surgery, are not likely to recur, and should not receive further treatment. The immune system limits cancer progression but to date no biomarkers are available to define low risk groups. We further validate previously developed immune biomarkers and combine them to create a composite biosignature defining patients who can safely be spared the expense and toxicity of therapy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The prevalence of overweight/obesity is estimated to be 78% among U.S. Veterans, substantially higher than in the general population. Given the association between obesity and comorbid medical conditions, increased disability levels, and reduced quality of life, this represents a significant health concern. As such, it is clear that new strategies for obesity management are needed. One possible strategy is targeting eating behaviors. A key obstacle in understanding how to best accomplish this, however, is our poor understanding of sex-based differences in eating behaviors, which are consistently observed. The goal of this proposal, therefore, is to better understand sex-based differences in the neurobiology of hedonic eating behaviors. By focusing on this knowledge gap, this proposal addresses both an important health issue affecting the vast majority of Veterans, and specifically seeks to improve the health of women Veterans, who are the fastest-growing population of Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The number of cardiovascular surgeons conducting research is diminishing, and a vital need exists to provide quality research training for aspiring academic cardiovascular surgeons. This formal training program addresses this shortage by providing for collaboration between basic scientists and clinical faculty to train surgery residents in basic, translational or clinical research to produce the next generation of highly trained cardiothoracic surgeon-scientists devoted to understanding the pathogenesis and treatment of cardiovascular injury and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study will incorporate new neuropathologic indices, neuroimaging, and promising blood biomarkers of AD and neurodegeneration and apply a highly innovative statistical approach to precisely identify the profile of healthy cognitive aging. Building on prior work, we will first identify healthy cognitive aging among autopsied persons with detailed pathologic data; importantly, we will then extend this approach to living persons. Finally, we will integrate new biomarker and ante-mortem neuroimaging data with our established cognitive age metric to develop and validate accurate criteria for prediction of incident MCI and Alzheimer’s dementia; thus, the proposed study offers a rare opportunity to identify healthy aging and facilitate approaches to identify individuals at high risk of developing cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROGAM NARRATIVE We show that AAV-expressed entry inhibitors can establish functional cures in rhesus macaques. We will make these functional cures safer, more consistent, and more robust, use these cures to study “kick-and- kill” eradication strategies, and ask whether a “kick” is necessary if the “kill” is potent and sustained.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of the Emory R38 program is to leverage the rich infrastructure and the interdisciplinary research environment at Emory to provide clinical and translational research training for resident physicians in the field of infectious diseases, allergy, microbiology, and immunology. The long-term goal is to expand the pool of physician scientists engaged in these areas of research. This goal will be operationalized through the development and sustained support of a structured research training program that offers an in-depth training in the fundamentals of clinical and translational research; fostering an Emory R38 specific mentoring program that is tailored to the training needs of resident physicians; and building a systematic approach for identifying and recruiting a diverse cohort of resident physicians into the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA) is an emerging, potentially fatal tick-transmitted disease caused by a bacterium that invades white blood cells called neutrophils. The proposed research will functionally dissect surface proteins of the HGA agent and assess if immunizing against them protects against infection. These studies will benefit design of strategies for preventing HGA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Multiple sclerosis is a common and disabling autoimmune disease of the central nervous system in which B cells play a central pathogenic role. The principal goal of the project is to identify the disease trigger(s), and to understand the mechanisms underlying disease progression. Central elements of this initiative include large well-characterized clinical populations, comprehensive biobanked materials, serial magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and spinal cord using novel quantitative techniques, complete genetic information, and state of the art tools to investigate B cell biology including single cell B cell transcriptomics, recombinant antibody libraries, and phage-displayed synthetic protein arrays to identify antibody reactivities against foreign and self proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Activating KRAS mutations are required for the maintenance of pancreatic cancer, the major cancer with the lowest 5-year survival rate, substantiating the need for effective anti-KRAS targeted therapies. The first FDA- approved KRASG12C inhibitor, sotorasib, is limited in PDAC because less than 2% of KRAS mutations in pancreatic cancer patients have KRASG12C mutations, and because patients who initially respond to treatment eventually relapse due to the onset of drug resistance mechanisms. My research studies address these issues by identifying resistance mechanisms to other KRAS mutations and define combination approaches to enhance the long-term patient response to KRAS inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research will elucidate how community contextual factors related to economic, social, and physical conditions work in conjunction with individual-level genetic risk factors, healthcare factors, and comorbid medical conditions in generating or mitigating risk for opioid use disorder. It will also identify program implementation factors at the individual, interpersonal, and organizational levels that influence adherence to medication-assisted treatment among patients with opioid use disorder. The research results will inform investment in preventive interventions where community conditions may increase risk for opioid use disorder as well as how health systems can increase retention in treatment programs for opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cystic Fibrosis (CF) remains the most lethal genetic disease in the Caucasian population, caused by mutation in the CFTR gene, with a wide range of disease severity. Using cutting-edge techniques of stem cell culturing, differentiation into airway epithelium, and gene-editing, this proposal seeks to establish the role of alternative ion channels in patients with extreme disease manifestations. The findings will clarify disease mechanisms in CF, facilitate individualized treatments for patients, and advance use of stem cell- derived airway epithelium to model lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE We have developed a brain-penetrant, small molecule drug candidate, called MW189, that targets dysregulated inflammation and attenuates brain dysfunction. The proposed project will fill the remaining gaps necessary to bring MW189 to a future clinical study in Alzheimer’s patients. MW189 has the potential to be a first-in-class disease-modifying therapy for Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The causes of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) in most cases are poorly understood, and there are likely many factors that influence the onset, severity, and trajectory of AD. However, many studies suggest that cardiovascular disease risk factors may act together with other genetic or environmental insults to promote AD. This project will examine the impact of the cardiovascular risk factor PAI-1 on cognition, brain vascular function, and changes in vascular gene expression in the context of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder resulting in dementia primarily in the elderly populations. The age-dependent increasing plaque load in AD has been correlated with an exacerbated loss of extracellular matrix structures called perineuronal nets (PNNs). Thus, it is imperative we determine the consequences of PNN loss in AD to gain deeper insight into pathology progression as well as the therapeutic potential PNNs may hold.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Scarcity of curative therapy and poor patient survival are critical issues involved in the treatment of highly aggressive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). We propose to develop a novel pancreatic cancer cell directed nanoformulations for the simultaneous delivery of novel class of anticancer molecules to target new blood vessels, dense tumor fibrosis and cancer cell for the treatment of PDAC. The proposed research will establish a clinically relevant platform technology for targeted delivery of drugs in lethal PDAC and supports the NIH mission of generating remedies for human diseases by designing a translational nanomedicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hemophilia A is an inherited bleeding disorder with no cure. Treatment involves repeated infusions of coagulation factor VIII throughout the life of the patient, which creates tremendous discomfort and morbidity. In response to these limitations, we seek to develop a novel technology that uses cells encapsulated in a device to deliver factor VIII into the bloodstream, correcting the clotting deficiency of hemophilia A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will inform policy discussions around state and federal proposals to cover vision services by providing rigorous estimates of the effects of routine eye care coverage on access to vision care and fall-related outcomes among dual eligibles. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to enhancing health and reducing illness and disability. This application is also relevant to the part of NEI’s mission that pertains to protecting and prolonging vision, and to the part of NIA’s mission that pertains to improving the health and well-being of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Living cells use hundreds of specific chemical reactions to produce energy, to make new components, and to signal important events, but most of these processes are invisible without specific probes. Genetically-encoded fluorescent biosensors allow us to capture real-time “movies” of biochemical processes inside individual cells, providing a vivid picture of how cells normally function and how they malfunction in disease. These sensors are difficult to develop and optimize because many candidates must be screened carefully to find a highly specific, sensitive, and robust reporter for each particular target molecule; our improved screening method dramatically improves the ability to screen for optimized versions of existing biosensors and to develop new ones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite sex differences in the clinical and biological profiles of Alzheimer’s disease with women showing a cognitive advantage yet greater Alzheimer’s pathology in early disease stages followed by a two-times steeper decline, sex is not considered in our current diagnostic methods. In this study, we will use both in-life biomarker and postmortem neuropathological data to determine how the clinical expression of AD pathology differs in women versus men and understand why these differences occur and how they impact disease diagnosis. By accounting for sex disparities in our current clinical diagnostic approaches, we can improve and tailor risk assessment and diagnostic methods to be optimal for each sex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Post-traumatic epilepsy, a seizure disorder secondary to traumatic brain injury (TBI), is among the most disabling and difficult-to-treat complications of TBI. Currently, there are no tools to identify patients a priori at highest risk for PTE. Dr. Kim's proposed career development plan has great potential to advance our knowledge of the acute biomarkers of PTE using EEG and MRI, to improve early identification and ultimately provide treatment options for this potentially preventable complication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE  People with uncontrolled hypertension have an almost three-fold increased risk for dementia, and if they are carriers of apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE4, that is, 25% of population), then they have 13 fold increased risk for dementia (female E4 carriers already have twice as much as risk as male E4 carriers). Despite the fact that 80% of people with Alzheimer's also have cerebrovascular diease (mixed dementia) and despite the knowledge that people with mixed dementia have serious adverse effects to amyloid clearing drugs, there is a paucity or lack of preclinical models and none with ApoE3 or ApoE4. We have now developed a novel rat model for mixed dementia, which has several features of mixed dementia including energy deficits, and including ApoE3 and ApoE4: rats have additional advantages over mice because of a more complex brain and larger cerebrospinal fluid and plasma volumes, making it a better preclinical model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a prevalent and burdensome neurodegenerative disease with no highly effective therapeutic to slow the progression of the disease. Since the molecular mechanisms that mediate the effects of APOE risk factors for AD progression remain unclear, there is a critical need for preclinical research to identify novel ways to diagnose and treat AD in humans. Therefore, this proposal will test the hypothesis that APOE genotype risk factors for AD impact the molecular profiles of astrocytes and change their inflammatory and metabolic phenotypes and contribute to AD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Preservation of healthy blood vessels in the brain is important strategy in protection against cognitive decline. This application is designed to determine functions of two critically important enzymes (BACE1 and BACE2) located in the brain blood vessels. Our proposed studies will define the roles of BACE1 and BACE2 in development of cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA). CAA is a disease in which proteins called amyloid build up in the walls of the arteries in the brain. CAA significantly increases the risk and can cause dementia. Currently, there is no disease-specific treatment available to patients with CAA. Successful completion of proposed studies will provide scientific basis for development of therapeutic interventions designed to prevent detrimental effects of CAA on the brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a deadly, age-related neurodegenerative disorder that has been studied for decades, but despite the identification of some key mechanisms, the molecular pathways that underlie neuronal dysfunction and degeneration in AD remain unknown. Recently, Chitinase-3-like protein 1 (CHI3L1) has been implicated in the pathogenesis of AD because AD patients have higher cerebrospinal fluid concentrations of CHI3L1 compared to healthy controls that increase in a progression-dependent manner. This proposal addresses the role that CHI3L1 plays in the central nervous system, specifically in the context of AD and neurodegeneration, thus providing critical information that can potentially be used in targeted therapeutics to combat AD and its progression or in other medical advances related to this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias affect a growing number of people as the population ages. Currently, nearly 6 million persons in the US have AD; it is estimated that by the year 2050, that number will be 14 million. With this increase in the number of AD patients, there is a corresponding growth in the number of family members and other caregivers affected by this devastating disease, as well as dramatic social and economic costs. The goal of our research training program is to prepare a new generation of investigators to translate mechanistic scientific discoveries into effective tools for diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of AD and related dementias.

PROJECT_TITLE: Neurobehavior, Neuropathology, and Risk Factors in Alzheimer's Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because it explains how light regulates the refractive function the eye. This work has implications for human health because it may provide a way to treat refractive error, including myopia, with light stimulation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pathophysiology of the noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) has been well characterized in the cochlea, but is less clear in the central auditory system. This project investigates the mechanisms of NIHL in the cochlear nucleus (CN) by identifying the pathological changes of the innervating auditory nerve synapses and their postsynaptic CN neurons, and clarifying the altered signal processing after moderate and traumatic noise exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Coxsackievirus is a major human pathogen that initiates infection in the mammalian gastrointestinal tract, home to a community of resident bacteria. These bacteria can enhance Coxsackievirus replication and pathogenesis; however, the mechanism remains unclear. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the mechanism of bacterial-mediated enhancement of Coxsackievirus infectivity and stability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness worldwide and lowering eye pressure is the only proven  treatment. We have discovered a novel pathway that is disrupted in Lowe syndrome, a rare disease  that causes glaucoma in children, and which leads to abnormally high intracellular levels of  phospholipids. The proposed studies will restore the lipid imbalance that underlies Lowe syndrome  and we anticipate that this study will lead to novel therapeutics not only for this disease, but  also for other more common forms of glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Successful treatments for atherosclerotic heart disease reduce the “bad” cholesterol in the bloodstream, but further therapies are needed, underscoring the public health relevance of this proposal. These challenges will be addressed by 1) developing a precursor to a small molecule drugs which could reduce these cholesterol levels, 2) evaluating whether there is a scientific basis to repurpose currently approved anticoagulant medications to lower cholesterol, and 3) identifying other factors responsible for elevating cholesterol which could be targets themselves for new drugs. As a result, this proposal is directly relevant to the NIH mission of promoting fundamental discoveries and innovative research designs as a basis for improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiac alternans is a recognized risk factor for cardiac arrhythmia, including atrial fibrillation, and sudden cardiac death. This study seeks to investigate the conditions that cause and sustain atrial alternans, and to determine cellular mechanisms of alternans in individual atrial myocytes, in multicellular tissue and at organ level, and to explore therapeutic interventions that reduce alternans risk.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Multiplex panels are rapid tests that can improve patient outcomes by helping clinicians start effective antibiotic therapy sooner, but false positives may lead to unnecessary antibiotics that cause harmful side effects or resistance. This project seeks to improve use of multiplex panel testing in acute care by examining when and for whom multiplex panel testing is associated with improved clinical outcomes and more efficient use of antibiotics and then developing interventions to promote testing in those situations. This project is relevant to public health and the AHRQ mission because antibiotic overuse and emerging antibiotic resistance are an urgent threat to patient safety.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Optimizing Implementation of Multiplex Molecular Panel Testing to Reduce Diagnostic Error

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) have been a target of efforts to improve quality and reduce spending under value-based purchasing initiatives, but robust gains remain elusive. The current study will examine whether physicians that specialize in SNF-based care (SNFists) improve functional outcomes and reduce healthcare utilization (such as hospital readmissions) of patients in SNFs. We will also examine patient functional outcomes and healthcare utilization of SNFists vs. non-SNFists under value-based purchasing initiatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this Training Program is to provide an interdisciplinary research-intensive training environment for individuals who wish to pursue careers in the oral sciences, with a focus on the regeneration of dental-oral- craniofacial tissues. DDS/PhD, PhD, and Post-doctoral Fellows will be trained in a comprehensive Program that spans across departmental and school boundaries, providing intensive training opportunities in both basic biomedical and clinical science. Our commitment to training oral scientists as independent researchers and life- long learners will help develop a diverse and highly qualified workforce that significantly impacts oral health.

PROJECT_TITLE: Tissue Engineering and Regeneration

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Understanding the normal physiological processes that govern proteostasis in neurons is of fundamental importance. In this proposal we are focused on understanding the BAG3-dependent mechanisms regulating vacuolar dependent pathways in neurons which facilitate tau clearance and promote synaptic health. The results from these studies will provide foundational information for understanding the mechanisms that contribute to the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease and other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Cellular heterogeneity is a defining feature of biology, but we currently lack tools that scale with the complexity of tissue heterogeneity. We developed a new method to directly measure biochemical activities in thousands to millions of single cells and will deploy it broadly to provide a more vivid picture of cell-type- specific biochemical activities.

PHR: Our research aims to improve cancer outcomes by using pharmacologic blockade of DNA damage response together with diffusing alpha-emitters radiation therapy (DaRT), a form of radiation that creates focused clusters of DNA damage, to activate the immune system to combat tumors. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the POGLUT1 gene result in a new form of muscle disease. The proposed studies use mouse genetics, stem cell culture and biochemical approaches to examine the mechanisms underlying the pathology of this disease and to identify the target proteins and pathways affected by POGLUT1 mutations, in hopes of establishing a new framework for treating muscle disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, our interdisciplinary team proposes to use novel approaches and innovative combinations of data to galvanize the use of EHR networks and population based cohorts to advance EHR-based risk predictions for 1) population level inference; 2) making individualized predictions of absolute risk, and 3) improving reproducibility and cross-site validation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent unmet need to discover new therapies for patients with residual cardiovascular risk due to inflammation despite conventional cholesterol-lowering treatments. The goal of the proposed research is to uncover novel mechanisms by which we can promote the resolution of inflammation and regression of atherosclerotic plaque. Therefore, this work is highly relevant to the mission of both the NIH and the NHLBI as it will help us understand fundamental mechanisms of disease in order to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will provide fundamental insight into how diverse layer specific neurons and connections interact to drive decision-related dynamics in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and dorsal premotor cortex to control perceptual decision-making, a process that is frequently impaired in psychiatric and movement disorders. Our results will be invaluable for the future development of biophysically realistic computational models of decision- making that incorporate multiple brain areas, layers and cell types. These insights, when combined with precise techniques to perturb neurons and networks are essential for the development of circuit level therapeutics for psychiatric and movement disorders, and the next generation of brain machine interfaces used for recovery of function following brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Vitamin K plays an essential role in the production of blood clotting factors and is important to other functions such as regulation of calcification by Matrix Gla Protein. Vitamin K is used by a protein called the gamma- glutamyl carboxylase, which modifies clotting factors and Matrix Gla Protein, and this work will determine how full modification is impacted by a genetic disease, called pseudoxanthoma elasticum-like. The drug warfarin (or coumadin) is used to interfere with vitamin K metabolism and reduces blood clotting in millions of people worldwide, and this study will determine how warfarin impacts the full modification of clotting factors and Matrix Gla protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative Arthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses) such as chikungunya (CHIKV) and Zika (ZIKV), as well as rodent- and bat-borne viruses such as Lassa fever and probably Ebola, are among the most important causes of emerging infectious diseases that can spread worldwide to threaten global public health. Many of these viruses originate in Africa, where they circulate in wildlife and mosquitoes. The West African Center for Emerging Infectious Diseases will monitor people in Senegal, Nigeria and Sierra Leone to detect infections with these and other emerging viruses, determine how these people become infected and why disease outcomes vary widely, then produce risk maps so that surveillance and control can be focused on the most important regions.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Campylobacter is the principal global cause of bacterial enteritis, and infections have been shown to be predominantly derived from poultry. This project will study the genomes of microbes to differentiate and determine the relative contribution from industrially produced and community reared poultry to human campylobacteriosis. The long-term goal of this project is to decrease the burden of drug resistant Campylobacter in human populations through the effective control of campylobacteriosis in poultry production and food processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes affects nearly 1 in 3 NH residents, yet guidelines for the management of diabetes in NH are based on sparse evidence and do not adequately consider the impacts of comorbidities, especially Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias, on diabetes management. To improve the quality of care for vulnerable NH residents, it is critical to evaluate whether Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias increases the risk of developing hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia in NH residents and whether Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias alters the thresholds of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia that can cause adverse geriatric outcomes. Our proposal will use fingerstick glucose measurements taken from routine clinical care and captured in the Veterans Affairs electronic health record system to examine the complex relationships between Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias, hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia, and adverse geriatric outcomes in NH residents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain conditions affect a large portion of the population and are often refractory to treatment, largely due to gaps in current understanding of the underlying sexually dimorphic mechanisms producing, maintaining, and resolving chronic pain. Utilizing a novel animal model of pain chronification, this project seeks to elucidate male-specific mechanisms underlying the unique plastic changes occurring in each of these phases of pain chronification. In doing so, new targets for the prevention and treatment of chronic pain conditions will be identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Making errors is typically considered a nuisance, but in fact, errors provide critical information that can help make corrections and update expectations about future events in an uncertain and ever-changing world. The goal of this proposal is to understand the way that olivo-cerebellar circuits in the brain encode and process this all-important error information. This research aims to uncover fundamental principles and provide mechanistic insight that is particularly relevant for treating neurological disorders associated with cerebellar dysfunction, like ataxia and dystonia, as well as other neuropsychiatric disorders like ADHD, autism, and schizophrenia, that have been linked to deficient communication between the cerebellum and the rest of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal investigates the role of retrotransposons and endogenous retroviruses in Alzheimer’s and related dementias, using a Drosophila model as well as mammalian cell culture. The primary hypothesis that will be investigated is that retrotransposons and endogenous retroviruses, which are virus like elements that reside in the genome, are both upstream initiators and downstream mediators of the protein aggregation pathology that is seen in subjects with these disorders. The proposal makes use of well established Drosophila models of neurodegeneration that are relevant to Alzheimer’s Related Dementias. By use of these models and of cell culture, this proposal also will test the idea that retrotransposons and endogenous retroviruses contribute to the spread of disease between neurons and glial cells in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mature primary B cells can be modified ex vivo to express HIV broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs) as functional antigen-receptors (bnBCRs). We have shown that durable bnAb responses can be elicited from these cells after immunization in wild type mice, suggesting that it may be possible to develop ‘Engineered B cell vaccines’ (EBcVs) as an functional cure or prophylactic strategy in humans. This proposal improves and characterizes EBcV function in the mouse model, and translates the approach for efficacy testing in rhesus macaques using the SHIV model of HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many disease susceptibilities are not caused by changes in the genes themselves, but rather by changes in their regulatory elements that control when and where the gene turns on and off during development. However, there are not currently high-throughput methods to understand the regulatory potential of DNA sequences during development, or how a mutation may change this function. We are developing such a method and expect this new method to lead to a better understanding of the genetic differences that lead to disease risk, and ultimately improve treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We often take for granted our ability to seamlessly combine movements of our limbs and hands with the sense of touch, yet neuroscientists do not yet have a good understanding of how this coordination is achieved. In the proposed work, we use the rat whisker system as a model to study how the muscles that allow movement, as well as the biomechanics of movement, guide the sense of touch. This work is important for two reasons: 1) it is one of the first examples of understanding the way the body and brain combine sensing and movement all the way from touch sensors to muscle control; and 2) it may help us understand why some infants and some elderly persons have trouble swallowing, chewing, and breathing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This research proposal focuses on the development and application of state-of-the-art lambda dynamics free energy simulations to provide atomistic insights into the mechanisms and thermodynamics of protein–ligand drug resistance and protein–protein binding. This information will be used to guide the discovery and design of novel small molecule and protein therapeutics to address a variety of infectious and proliferative diseases. Algorithms from the field of artificial intelligence will also be investigated in tandem with lambda dynamics calculations to automate preclinical lead optimization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: Age-related declines in muscle mass and function are important contributors to the major public health problem of frailty, which significantly increases the risk for debilitating falls and reduces mobility, independence, and quality of life among the elderly. The lack of understanding of mechanisms of muscle fiber weakness and loss represents a critical barrier to progress toward the development of successful interventions for ameliorating physical frailty and thereby improving quality of life for the elderly. Here we test the previously unstudied role of oxidized phospholipids (oxPLs) and oxylipins in mediating mechanisms of atrophy induced by loss of innervation to increase our understanding of the mechanisms underlying muscle loss and weakness that is critical for identifying therapeutic targets with maximum effectiveness.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Healthcare-associated infections are a common post-cardiac surgical complication, impact a patient’s risk of morbidity and mortality and vary in rate across hospitals. Provider care delivery networks that support coordination of patient disease management and care optimization vary in their performance across hospitals and contribute to higher rates of postoperative infections in some settings. The objective of this proposal is to identify areas of intervention within care delivery networks that enhance infection outcomes after coronary revascularization and valve surgery by: (1) Evaluating provider care delivery networks as significant determinants of postoperative infections after cardiac surgery; (2) Developing a comprehensive understanding of structural barriers and facilitators to optimal care delivery and (3) Developing a best practices toolkit to address the impact of provider care delivery networks on infections after cardiac surgery.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Understanding and Addressing Variation in Healthcare-Associated Infections After Adult Cardiac Surgery
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  Neuron to (astro)glia communication is essential for brain functions and alterations of their communication has been commonly found in neurological diseases. Recently, Exosome signaling has emerged as a novel and important intercellular communication pathway in the CNS. This project will investigate the fundamentally important but currently lacking cell biology of the emerging exosomal miR-mediated neuron to glia communication. Outcome will provide much-needed cell biological knowledge and insights for understanding exosome signaling in neuron to glia communication. This new knowledge can significantly help understand how this pathway is involved in CNS diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall aim of this study is to employ Community Health Workers (CHWs) to screen for depression in 30 Black churches and compare the effectiveness of Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT) (Intervention arm) to Referral As Usual (Control arm) on treatment engagement. We will assess patient-level outcomes (Mental-Health Related Quality of Life and depressive symptoms) at 3- and 6-months post-screening and conduct a mixed-methods process evaluation to assess multi-level facilitators and barriers of screening uptake. This research addresses the NIMH Division of Services and Intervention Research (DSIR) area of high priority to “employ strategic partnerships and community engagement / participation to enhance research capacity and infrastructure in underserved and diverse populations.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinal ganglion cell (RGC) transplant holds excellent promise in regenerating or replacing damaged retinal tissues to treat otherwise incurable eye diseases, but a low transplant success rate and inconsistent treatment efficacy hamper its clinical application in ophthalmology. In this project, the PI will develop OCT contrast agents to achieve longitudinal and non-invasive cell tracking in the eye, and use advanced imaging to understand and optimize the factors affecting RGC transplant efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: C. difficile is the leading cause of healthcare-associated infection, yet no single test or validated model is capable of reliably telling which patients are at risk of dying from the infection. New research suggests that a patient's immune system, and possibly other factors such as Binary Toxin, may be the key to understanding how they will respond to C. difficile. This work will combine known risk factors with new markers from the blood and stool into an integrated scoring system that predicts which patients will develop severe or life-threatening C. difficile infection.
